text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who wants to attach himself to the Holy One—so that his thoughts travel from one chamber to the next, seeing these chambers with his mind’s eye—should avoid speaking falsely, even accidentally.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: One is permitted to distort the truth in order to preserve peace.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Those who tell lies are not worthy of receiving the Divine Presence.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: A Tzaddik is permitted to act deceitfully with one who deceives others.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Telling lies brings one to thoughts of idolatry.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: By being truthful, a person will not die before his time.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: The breath from a liar’s mouth gives rise to the evil inclination. When Mashiach comes, falsehood will cease to exist and so there will be no evil inclination in the world.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: A person of truth can recognize in another if he is speaking falsely or not.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: A sign that something is false is that it is opposed by the majority. The liar is one of the three types of people whom God despises.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Reason cannot tolerate a rich person’s deceit. Even he finds himself despicable.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Truth protects the world from all manner of harm.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: A person who gives charity merits attaining the truth.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: One can tell from a person’s servants whether he is fond of falsehood. This is because the one is dependent upon the other. There are times when a person’s servants fall into sin because he is a liar, and other times when he stumbles into falsehood because his servants behave improperly.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: One who lacks truth lacks kindness. Such a person cannot deal {kindly} with people.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: Falsehood delays redemption, for it brings a person’s sins out into the open, thus preventing him from being saved.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: A person should rather die, than live and be considered a liar by others.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: Where there is truth, there is peace.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: One who is far from the truth is far from charity.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: Truth protects the sign of the brit.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: By telling the truth, a person earns everlasting esteem.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: When a husband and wife accustom themselves to lying, their children will be rebellious and sexually immoral.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: A person will speak falsely when he is afraid of other people.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: Falsehood causes a person to forget God.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: A person who does not trust in God speaks falsely, and by telling lies becomes incapable of trusting the truth.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 29_Paragraph: The further a person is from truth, the more he considers one who turns away from evil to be a fool.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: Seeing that there is no truth in the world, a person who wants to turn away from evil must play the fool.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: When a person does not speak falsely, God saves him in a time of misfortune. He will also be blessed with children.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: Idle talk brings harm to one’s children.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: A person steeped in idleness becomes forgetful.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: Falsehood leads to immorality and strengthens the hand of evildoers so that they do not return to God in repentance.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: A person who lies has no cure even with numerous medicines.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: A person who tells lies is cut down. He also becomes a fool.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: Fear of God brings a person to truth.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: A person who guards himself from falsehood is always victorious.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: It is permissible to alter the truth in order to save oneself from harm.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: A person who is fond of falsehood will disgrace the Tzaddik, and will himself be shamed.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: Truth saves a person from slander. By telling the truth his prayers are accepted, and when judged on high, he will be judged according to his merits.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: A person can tell from his dreams whether his heart is true with his God.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: A person who keeps his word can accomplish great things.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: One who has no haughtiness is saved from lies.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 46_Paragraph: Whoever guards against frivolity is clearly a person of truth.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: When someone who was a liar in a previous lifetime is reincarnated, he comes back left-handed.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: When a person is careful and always speaks truthfully, it is like he created heaven and earth, the seas and all that they contain.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: Falsehood applies only to the spoken word, not the written one.
text.2_Truth, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: The Torah, the Prophets and the Sages made use of hyperbole [in their teachings].
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: People don’t listen to one who speaks falsely. Lying also causes a person to be widowed from a number of wives, God forbid.
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Truth reveals God’s Oneness in the world.
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: When you see a liar, you should know that his spiritual leader is also false.
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Falsehood leads a person to immorality and murder. It also causes the upright to err in sexual and homicidal matters, and teaches permissiveness in the Torah.
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: When a person does not distort his words, he is able to humble the haughty and elevate the meek.
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: A person who does not speak one way with his lips and another in his heart has no fear of drowning.
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: The disorders of diarrhea and constipation come from lying.
text.2_Truth, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: Truth will bring the Final Redemption.
text.3_Hospitality, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: An inhospitable person strengthens the hand of evildoers so that they do not return to God in repentance.
text.3_Hospitality, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: [The inhabitants of] a city in which hospitality is not practiced will turn to immoral behavior, and this in turn will bring murder into their midst.
text.3_Hospitality, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Hospitality brings a woman to be blessed with children.
text.3_Hospitality, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Receiving guests is like receiving Shabbat.
text.3_Hospitality, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person who welcomes a Torah scholar into his home is considered as having offered the daily-sacrifice.
text.3_Hospitality, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Hospitality is even greater than arriving early at the house of Torah study and receiving the Divine Presence.
text.3_Hospitality, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Jews who have no rabbis in their midst are like Samaritans.
text.3_Hospitality, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person’s hospitality causes people to revere him.
text.3_Hospitality, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Hospitality is a segulah for restoring a woman’s menses.
text.3_Hospitality, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: God’s holiness validates and affirms the prominence of the generation’s leaders. This in turn brings everyone to value the mitzvah of hospitality, and the Torah scholars to merit having the law follow their opinion.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: When there is no love between people, they bear tales. Their tale-bearing brings them to mock one another, and their mockery then leads them to telling lies.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Hatred leads to turmoil and fires.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: One’s love for God protects his soul from misfortune.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Achieving love for God requires that you first repent for your sins.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Everyone loves a person who is completely given over to praying for the Jewish people.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Encouraging someone in his service of God will bring him to love you.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: You can merit loving God by reciting the Hallel prayer in a loud voice.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: When engaged in ligation with a mute who refuses to reach a compromise, guarding against unwarranted hatred will bring him to settle with you.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: A person who guards against swearing falsely will certainly not transgress the precept of “not taking revenge nor bearing a grudge” (Leviticus 19:18).
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: The merit earned by a person who serves God out of love stands as a lasting protection for two thousand generations.
text.4_Love, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: God is present wherever pacts and agreements are made.
text.4_Love, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: When the earth’s plant life reaches full size, there is love in the world.
text.4_Love, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: The measure of a woman’s love for her husband is [in inverse proportion to the number of] flies and gnats in their house. Also, from their love we can tell whether the evil inclination’s power [over them] has been weakened.
text.4_Love, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: The wise men of the generation who love each other and visit each other from time to time have the power to judge the entire world. Their judgment is lasting and no one will be able to change or nullify it, for God Himself is the head magistrate of their court.
text.4_Love, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Unwarranted hatred causes a person to unintentionally eat unkosher food.
text.4_Love, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: A person’s lust for food causes him to favor one child over the others.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: One’s belief in God must come through faith and not because of miracles.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: You can achieve faith by being humble.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: When you see something out of the ordinary, don’t say that it is coincidence; rather, believe that it is Divine providence.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: There are things that bring great harm to the world and it is difficult to understand why they were created. You should know that they most certainly have some aspect of good.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Finding the words of a heretic pleasing will bring a person to thoughts of idolatry, even if those words are not heretical in and of themselves.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: A person’s faith endears him to God much like a wife is dear to her husband.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Without first preparing his heart, a person cannot achieve faith.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: One who loses something has clearly fallen from his faith.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: One who has lost his faith should visit Jewish graves and recount the kindness that God has performed for him.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Faith is dependent upon a person’s mouth. [Speaking about faith not only increases faith—it is faith! (Likutey Moharan II, 44)].
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Overeating leads to a fall from faith.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: Gazing at the sky when it is clear and bright will bring you to faith in the Sages.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Should you find yourself questioning God, keep silent. By virtue of this silence, your very thoughts will provide you with an answer to your questions.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: Remaining silent when you are insulted will earn you an answer to your questions and you will merit a spirit of understanding.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: You should know that when a person’s opponents are wise and very wealthy, it is because he has repeatedly fallen from faith.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: Belief in God makes one wise.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: It is first necessary to have faith in God, and only then will you be worthy of understanding Him with your intellect.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: The unification of the Holy One comes about through the souls of the Jewish people.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: A person’s sins bring him to entertain heresy.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: When a person falls from his belief in God, he will cry.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: Faith comes by remaining silent [in the face of criticism].
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: A person’s jealousy causes him to fall from his belief in God.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: A person with no faith clearly belittles the words of the Torah.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: A person who is always cleaning his hands is purifying his heart.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: When a person falls from faith, he should know that he is being judged on high.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: One who has fallen from his belief in God will experience a seminal emission, and be plagued with promiscuous thoughts and thoughts of idolatry.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: By means of faith one can come to understand God.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: Through faith one can come to trust in God.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: Because of faith, God will forgive all your sins.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: There are times when God sends a person suffering and punishment, but He does not weaken him. This is only in order to foster faith.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: Swearing falsely causes a person to fall from faith.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: A person without faith does not accept rebuke.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: A person who does not believe in the words of the Tzaddik will in the end have no benefit from them, even though he will see [them coming true].
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: A person without faith certainly despises God’s statutes.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: Mashiach will come suddenly and, because of their joy, the Jews will fear.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: When Mashiach comes, all the ministers on high and also those below in this world will be weakened. But now, whenever there is an ascent by any minister, the Jews are weakened.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: In the World to Come, the “younger” one is the higher the level to which he will ascend.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 41_Paragraph: Jerusalem was destroyed only because the Jews: desecrated Shabbat; neglected reciting both the morning and evening Shema; were lax in educating their young schoolchildren; felt no shame in each other’s presence; equated the lowly with the great; did not rebuke one another, but ridiculed Torah scholars; and there were no longer any men of faith in the city.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: Jerusalem will be redeemed only through charity.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: War is the beginning of redemption.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: A person who raises pigs delays the redemption.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: Jerusalem will not be rebuilt until there is peace among Jews.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 46_Paragraph: That the Jews wander in exile from nation to nation is a sign that Mashiach will come.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: When the nations insult us a great deal, it is a sign that Mashiach’s arrival is imminent.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: The House of God will not be built until haughtiness ceases to exist.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: The spirit of oneness that will exist among Jews will bring Mashiach.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: Mashiach will come in a year of blessing.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 51_Paragraph: Mashiach won’t come until all the souls have been emptied from the body [of Primordial Man].
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 52_Paragraph: When a person marries his daughter to a Torah scholar, or benefits a scholar with his possessions, or engages in business on the scholar’s behalf, he merits being resurrected from the dead.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 53_Paragraph: The breath from a liar’s mouth gives rise to the evil inclination. When Mashiach comes, falsehood will cease to exist and so there will be no evil inclination in the world.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 54_Paragraph: A person of truth can recognize in another if he is speaking falsely or not.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 55_Paragraph: A majority of people will not agree to something false.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 56_Paragraph: The Holy One despises a person who speaks one way with his lips and another in his heart.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 57_Paragraph: Reason cannot tolerate a rich person’s deceit. Even he finds himself despicable.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 59_Paragraph: Truth protects the world from all manner of harm.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 61_Paragraph: A person who gives charity is rewarded with attaining the truth.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 62_Paragraph: A person who lies will certainly despise humble people.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 63_Paragraph: One can tell from a person’s servants whether he is fond of falsehood.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 64_Paragraph: When there is no truth, there is no kindness.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 65_Paragraph: If you are in any way false, then when God desires to save you, this falsehood brings your sins out into the open so that He should not save you.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 66_Paragraph: For telling the truth, God will redeem you from all suffering.
text.5_Faith, 0_Part I, 67_Paragraph: A person should rather die, than live and be considered a liar by others.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: There are times when a person comes to some place where he experiences anguish. He should know that his ancestors were in that place and came to some form of heresy, or that his descendants will one day be there and come to some heresy. This is the reason he is now suffering.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: The Holy One performs miracles only for a person who believes in both worlds.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Our faith in God nullifies the evil decrees that the nations issue against us.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Know! each and every herb has its own unique power to heal a specific illness. But this is only for a person who did not guard his faith and sexual purity, and did not keep from transgressing “Do not despise any man” (Avot 4:3). However, when one has complete faith and also maintains sexual purity and fulfills “Do not despise any man,” his cure is not dependent upon particular types of herbs. Rather, he is healed by all food and drink, as in “And He blessed your bread” (Exodus 23:25). He does not have to rely upon receiving particular herbs to be cured.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: The future salvation will come about only because of faith, the measure of which is in accordance with the leaders of the generation.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: Going from one teacher to another requires that a person strengthen his faith in the unity of God. Learning from many teachers detracts from belief in His Oneness. Nevertheless, the teacher who has faith in His Oneness is able to enlighten each and every student according to his ability, as each student hears only that which is necessary for him and no more.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: Consolation comes through faith in God.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: Flies multiply in the world because there is a lack of faith.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: A person who is careful not to transgress the prohibition against coveting will be saved from anger and haughtiness, and from the lack of faith that results from those two evil traits.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 10_Paragraph: Because the Jews do not make His Godliness known to the peoples of the world, they are lured by the nations into following foreign ideologies.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 11_Paragraph: Corruption of faith gives rise to stern judgment. Thoughts of idolatry awaken doubly strict judgments. That is, even the judgments that have already been issued are reviewed to ensure that they were properly issued, without leniency.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 12_Paragraph: A person suffers childlessness, God forbid, when he causes another to fall from faith.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 13_Paragraph: When a woman is heedful of the mitzvah of challah, her sons will be masters of faith.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 15_Paragraph: Torah brings to faith, and faith brings to sanctifying the Name of God.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 16_Paragraph: A person who finds that he cannot sleep should think about his belief in the resurrection of the dead.
text.5_Faith, 1_Part II, 17_Paragraph: Those with only a small measure of faith have difficulty gaining new insights into the Torah.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: Leave over a bit of your meal so that your sustenance will receive God’s blessing.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: A person’s table purifies him from all his sins.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: A person’s table earns him the World to Come as well as a livelihood [in this world]. He is inscribed for good in the uppermost worlds and is also rewarded with increased power and strength when he needs it.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: The sins of delaying justice, distorting and corrupting judgment, and neglecting Torah study bring drought. People will eat, but will not be satiated; they will partake of their bread in measure.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Eating just a little causes one’s heart to want more food; more so than when one has lost hope of eating and has eaten nothing at all.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Why were the Jews deserving of destruction? Because they delighted in the feast of that wicked one, [Achashveirosh].
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: The Altar abolishes evil decrees, atones for sin, nourishes and endears. One’s table is comparable to the Altar.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: When a person eats without first washing his hands [as Torah law prescribes], it is as if he visited a prostitute. Whoever ridicules this religious requirement is uprooted from the world.
text.6_Eating, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: One should not drink water in public.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person whose being reflects the Godly image is elevated through eating living things. The inverse is also true, [as one who does not reflect the Godly image is brought down by eating living things].
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Eating fish arouses the desire for marital relations.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: God is made known in the world through Grace after Meals.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Reciting Grace after Meals brings the country’s government relief from disputes and wars.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: When a person studies Torah with pure thoughts, so that he eats with such holiness that he is nourished by the sustenance of the angels, his enemies are sentenced to strangulation. This is alluded to [by the verses], “And it was on the third day, in the morning...” (Exodus 19:16); “then in the morning there was a layer of dew” (ibid. 16:13); “And it was at the morning watch...” (ibid. 14:24). (I heard this explanation from the Rebbe’s holy mouth: ‘“And it was on the third day, in the morning’ was said during the Giving of the Torah and refers to a person who studies Torah with pure thoughts. ‘Then in the morning there was a layer of dew’ was said about the manna, the food from which the angels draw sustenance, as our Sages taught (see Yoma 75b). ‘And it was at the morning watch’ was said at the splitting of the Red Sea, when the Egyptians were drowned, which is an aspect of strangulation, as our Sages taught (see Ketuvot 30b).” Rebbe Nachman learned from one “morning” and applied it to the other, thereby deriving the above {insight} from the Torah.)
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: Whoever cannot taste the food he eats should know that God has removed Himself from him.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: When Tzaddikim eat, it is [an act of holiness] even greater than bringing sacrifices, and on a higher level than even their marital relations.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: Fish grow fatty in the merit of the sacrifices.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: A person bitten by a dog clearly has had Heaven’s mercy removed from him. It is also a sign that he has eaten forbidden food.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: Whoever is careful not to eat forbidden foods is saved from wild beasts.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 10_Paragraph: One whose enemies have gained prominence succumbs to a lust for food.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 11_Paragraph: A person’s lust for food causes him to favor one child over the others.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 12_Paragraph: “L’chu lachmu v’lachmi u’shetu b’yayin masakhti (Come eat of my bread and drink of the wine that I have mixed)” (Proverbs 9:5). The first letters of L’chu Lachmu V’Lachmi U’shetu spell LULaV (לולב). B’yayin (ביין), with its four letters, has a numerical value (76) equivalent to that of the first letters of etrog (אתרוג), hadas (הדס) and aravah (ערבה); and maSaKhTi is similar to SuKkoT. By fulfilling the mitzvot of the Four Species and sukkah, a person is rewarded with food, drink, clothing and a revived spirit. Through the mitzvah of sukkah he merits clothing, as in “When I made a cloud its garment” (Job 38:9). By virtue of the willow branch he merits sufficient drink; through the myrtle branch he brings vitality to the soul; and through the palm tree and the citron tree, both of which bear edible fruit, he merits having enough to eat.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 13_Paragraph: One’s food and drink come from observing the Torah’s statutes and laws.
text.6_Eating, 1_Part II, 14_Paragraph: Drinking rouses a person to sing and play musical instruments, whereas eating does not. This is because [in the wilderness] the Jewish people sang the praise of God over the well, but not over the manna.
text.7_A Widower, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person whose wife died should recite daily the chapter of the guilt-offering (Leviticus 7:1-7) until he remarries.
text.7_A Widower, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: People do not listen to someone who speaks falsely. Lying also causes a person to be widowed from a number of wives, God forbid.
text.7_A Widower, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: When a man’s wife dies, it is like losing one of his bones. But this is not so for the Tzaddik when his wife dies, as hinted by the word ALMan (widower), whose letters stand for “Achat Mehaynah Lo Nishbarah (not one of them [the bones] was broken)” (Psalms 34:21).
text.8_The Land of Israel, 0_Part II, 0_Parag: By settling in the Land of Israel, a person gains insight into God’s providence over the world.
text.8_The Land of Israel, 0_Part II, 1_Parag: A person draws from the holiness of the Land of Israel in accordance with the original insights that he finds in the Torah.
text.8_The Land of Israel, 0_Part II, 2_Parag: One’s yearning to come to the Holy Land brings him great blessing in his livelihood.
text.8_The Land of Israel, 0_Part II, 3_Parag: Whoever provides support for many people draws blessing from the Land of Israel to the Diaspora.
text.8_The Land of Israel, 0_Part II, 4_Parag: One’s yearning for the Holy Land arouses yearning in the souls of his father and mother, which then come to the Land of Israel. And God comes with them, so that together they look forward to and yearn for his arrival.
text.8_The Land of Israel, 0_Part II, 5_Parag: The charity a person gives to the poor people of the Land of Israel causes him to prosper monetarily.
text.8_The Land of Israel, 0_Part II, 6_Parag: Anyone who knows of the Holy Land, who has really tasted the Land of Israel, can recognize in another whether he has been with the {true} Tzaddik for Rosh HaShanah. For when a person merits being with the true Tzaddik for Rosh HaShanah, wherever he focuses his attention he transforms the air there into an aspect of the air of the Land of Israel. Therefore, one who knows the taste of the Holy Land, each according to his own level, will of necessity feel the Land of Israel when he comes together with this person who has been with the true Tzaddik for Rosh HaShanah, through whom the air becomes an aspect of the Holy Land.
text.9_Lost Objects, 0_Paragraph: The same faculty that enables one to return a lost object to its owner enables him to win converts for God.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: When one cries in mourning for the passing of an honest person, he merits raising his children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Care must be taken that a baby boy does not go bareheaded.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: A person need not worry about having enough to support his children. As they grow, so does his income.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Anyone who prevents another person from ‘being fruitful and multiplying’ (Genesis 1:22) will descend into hell childless.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A man who forces his wife to have marital relations will have indecent children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: A woman whose menstrual flow is heavy will find the difficulties of child rearing a great burden.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: The daughter of a Kohen who marries a regular Jew (Israelite), or the daughter of a Torah scholar who marries a boor, will bear no offspring.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Fasting on Thursdays is a segulah for raising children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: A modest woman is rewarded with good children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: When a man joyously celebrates the holidays, or properly dons tefilin, his wife bears him sons.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: There are times when praying for children on behalf of a person who has none will bring about that person’s death.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: For the sin of unfulfilled oaths, children are punished with death.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Moving from one place to another causes a person to be blessed with children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: Older children do not die for the sins of their fathers. However, where the desecration of God’s Name is involved, even older children die.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: One who eats meat and drinks wine will conceive healthy children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: A person who stares at the heel of a woman, or at his own wife when she is ritually impure, will have indecent children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: A man who has lived in the Land of Israel for ten years and has remained childless should divorce his wife; it would seem that he is unworthy of building himself [a family] through her.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: What should a person do to have male children? He should marry a suitable woman, sanctify himself when he is with her, and beseech the One to whom the blessing of children belongs.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: Whoever bears children does so in his own likeness.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: A person should be careful not to cut down a tree before its time, because doing so is detrimental to the raising of children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: Whoever exerts himself to be charitable will have children who are rich, wise and masters oiAggadah.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: What should a person do to have children? He should distribute his money to the poor and make his wife happy before having marital relations.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: Just as it is forbidden to kill a person, it is forbidden to chop down a fruit-bearing tree before its time.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: We find the term “death” applied to Joab because he left no progeny like himself. Of David it is said that he was “laid to rest” because he left a son like himself.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: The evil-eye does not rule over one whose first child is a girl.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: Whoever raises an orphan in his home, it is as if he fathered him.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: Whoever teaches Torah to the son of a fellow Jew, it is as if he fathered him.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: Forty days prior to the formation of the embryo, a man should pray that his wife bear a son.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: The wife of a man whose thoughts are immoral will also have such thoughts. When she entertains immoral thoughts, the forces of evil come to her in her dreams, and because of this her children die.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 29_Paragraph: When a man is unfaithful to his wife, she will be unfaithful to him.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: Whoever burns a fellow Jew’s produce will leave no son to inherit him.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: A woman who loses her children in birth should put an apple on her head [while delivering them].
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: Whoever begins a mitzvah but does not complete it buries his wife and sons.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: A man who marries a woman for money will have indecent children and also lose the money in no time at all.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: A person who occupies himself with Torah and acts of kindness is rewarded with many children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: Children do not die for the sin of their fathers unless they carry on in their fathers’ ways.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: Marital relations are beneficial for the fetus; purifying and providing the child with alertness, strength and a distinguished appearance.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: A person who has no children should accept upon himself the travails of exile.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: Taking away a fellow Jew’s means of income is like violating his wife.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: Being given over into the hands of one’s enemies is like being bereaved of one’s sons.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: A person who has sexual relations with a gentile woman, or with another man, or who entertains thoughts of idolatry, will not have a Torah scholar for a son. Even if he should teach his son Torah, he will forget it.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 41_Paragraph: Good children bring great healing for their ancestors.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: Falsehood causes one’s children to die.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: Whoever does not separate from his wife close to the expected time of her menstruation, his sons—even if they are like those of Aaron—will die. But a man who does separate will have male children who are fit to render judgments in Torah law.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: Whoever uses wine in performing the Havdalah service separating Shabbat from the week, will have male children who are fit to render judgments in Torah law.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: A person who sanctifies himself by behaving modestly during marital relations will have male children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 46_Paragraph: Care should be taken not to allow a baby to nurse from an evil woman, because the milk he suckles has the power to make him either pure or impure.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: Warm water and oil are good for an infant’s health.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: By not holding back when nature calls, a person’s prayers on behalf of his children will be accepted.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: Offspring take after their father and mother in height.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: Indecent behavior in one’s house is more destructive than the war of Gog and Magog.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 51_Paragraph: Coming early and staying late in the synagogue lengthens the days of one’s children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 52_Paragraph: A person should not favor one of his children over the others.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 53_Paragraph: Lighting Chanukah and Shabbat candles makes one worthy of having sons who are Torah scholars.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 54_Paragraph: A person who shows love for the Sages will have sons who are sages. By honoring the Sages, his sons-in-law will be sages.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 55_Paragraph: One’s children die in youth for his sins of not fulfilling his oaths, neglecting to study Torah, failing to keep the mitzvot of mezuzah and tzitzit, and for the sin of unwarranted hatred.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 56_Paragraph: If a person tithes his wealth, his children will be saved from diphtheria.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 57_Paragraph: Schoolchildren die for the sins of their generation.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 58_Paragraph: Obtaining myrtle branches for Shabbat makes one worthy of having children who are Torah scholars.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 59_Paragraph: A segulah for a woman who miscarries is to bathe a bride before her wedding.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 60_Paragraph: The food one eats influences his sons and daughters [at the time of their conception].
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 61_Paragraph: A person whose children die should not have marital relations during the week, but only on the night of Shabbat.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 62_Paragraph: Drawing a bow and arrow on Lag B’Omer is a segulah for having children, as is singing the prayers while leading the congregation in worship.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 63_Paragraph: Proper behavior must be taught from infancy.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 64_Paragraph: The songs and praises of God that are recited before the light of day are a segulah for having children, for increasing the milk of a nursing woman, and for being spared from a wife with an angry nature.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 65_Paragraph: A person who humbles himself in the presence of his teacher and turns to his teacher with all his doubts even though his teacher shames him, will merit having a son who is even greater than his teacher in the study of Torah.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 66_Paragraph: Aperson who accepts his suffering with love merits offspring who will live long.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 67_Paragraph: God performs great deeds for a person in accordance with his name. This is because a person’s name influences [all aspects of his life.]
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 68_Paragraph: A person who raises his voice in order to show off causes his children to be taken captive.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 69_Paragraph: A person who is childless should use oil regularly.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 70_Paragraph: There are times when changing one’s place of dwelling saves the life of his children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 71_Paragraph: By pursuing peace, a person saves his sons from death and exile.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 72_Paragraph: When a person does something that is afterwards a hindrance for other people, all good is severed from his offspring.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 73_Paragraph: There are times when the great love between husband and wife prevents her from bearing children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 74_Paragraph: Most barren women who later conceive will give birth to a son.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 76_Paragraph: The Tzaddik has the power to curse a person so that he will not have decent children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 77_Paragraph: A person in whose house the Tzaddik takes lodging is blessed with children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 78_Paragraph: A person who desires to perform some mitzvah but does not merit fulfilling it, will be rewarded with children. They will inherit his greatness and will accomplish that mitzvah.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 79_Paragraph: When a person interferes with another’s livelihood, in the end his children die.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 80_Paragraph: A magnet is a segulah for having children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 81_Paragraph: A person’s children die when he uses names of impurity or sorcery, of if he just believes in them.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 82_Paragraph: When a husband and wife wash their hands and give charity before engaging in marital relations, they remove the spirit of impurity from the children that they conceive.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 83_Paragraph: There are women who bear females, but not males.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 84_Paragraph: By reciting the chapter of tzitzit (Numbers 15:37-41) with devotion and great fear of God, and by clothing the naked, a person merits having sons.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 85_Paragraph: When the year has been a prosperous one, take it as a sign that the Jews will “be fruitful and multiply” (Genesis 1:22).
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 86_Paragraph: The children of a woman who uses sorcery will die, and she will become a widow.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 87_Paragraph: A segulah for increasing the milk of a nursing mother is for her husband to mourn the destruction of Jerusalem.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 88_Paragraph: Falsehood brings harm to one’s children. The place in which they live can also cause them harm.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 89_Paragraph: If a person brings joy to a groom and bride, or—
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 90_Paragraph: if he is heedful [of the mitzvot that involve] lighting candles, his wife will bear sons.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 91_Paragraph: An abundance of rain is a sign that many sons will be born during that year.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 92_Paragraph: Husband and wife who curse each other will not raise their children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 93_Paragraph: A segulah for raising children: plant some type of produce, and when you harvest it, give it to the poor without having any pleasure from it yourself.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 94_Paragraph: A person who instills excessive fear in the people of his generation will not have progeny whose hearts contain wisdom.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 95_Paragraph: Whoever has no compassion for his children clearly has no understanding of holiness.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 96_Paragraph: Not reviewing one’s studies {and forgetting them} causes one’s children to die.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 97_Paragraph: A person who has acted immorally will not raise his children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 98_Paragraph: The Name of God — Elo'ah — אלוה - protects children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 99_Paragraph: Whoever makes an effort to secure a livelihood for those who seek God, his children will not follow evil ways.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 100_Paragraph: Through faith in the Tzaddikim a person’s children live and endure.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 101_Paragraph: When a male child comes into the world, so does lovingkindness.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 102_Paragraph: One who causes grief to his parents is not worthy of raising sons.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 103_Paragraph: By pursuing peace, a person lives to see his children’s children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 104_Paragraph: Damage to a door or window is a sign that one’s children will suffer sickness.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 105_Paragraph: When there is strife, it is a bad sign for one’s children; whereas peace is a good sign for them.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 106_Paragraph: A person who cannot control his temper will have foolish children.
text.10_Children, 0_Part I, 107_Paragraph: One who shows respect for his father is rewarded with sons.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person who feels the pains of child rearing should recite daily the Torah sections that depict Creation (Genesis 1). Reading this also saves one from being falsely accused of stealing.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Humbling oneself is a segulah for having children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Planting a vineyard is harmful for the raising of infants.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: The effort one makes to redeem captives is a segulah for having children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Reciting the Maamadot is a segulah for having children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: A woman whose children die from diphtheria should bathe her [other] children in oil and then light this oil at the time of her ritual immersion.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: Whoever defends his faith against many people, countering them with convincing arguments, will, because of this, be worthy of many children. His progeny will fill the world.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: Silver shaped into the Hebrew letter ה (heh) is a segulah for being fruitful and multiplying.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: Sometimes, the structure of a house prevents the woman [living there] from bearing children. When the beams in the structure are not positioned in the manner designated for them since the six days of Creation, the house is considered a ruin even while standing. This ruin harms the woman and she cannot bear offspring.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: One should seek out a mohel who is both righteous and God-fearing. For when the mohel lacks expertise, the circumcision can, God forbid, cause the infant to be sterile, or an epileptic.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 10_Paragraph: When a person’s son engages in Torah study, it is as if that person never dies.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 11_Paragraph: The milk of a righteous woman provides the child with the fear of Heaven and gives him mastery in this world.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 12_Paragraph: A person who causes a fellow Jew to fall from faith suffers childlessness.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 13_Paragraph: When there is peace in the country, the Jewish people are blessed with children who will be instructors of Torah law.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 14_Paragraph: When one is careful that his marital relations are at a time when neither he nor the time itself are exceedingly hot or cold, the children born to him will be very wise.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 15_Paragraph: When a person controls his evil inclination, his children do not follow evil ways. Because of this his money is plentiful, and consequently he will not come to be tested.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 16_Paragraph: Even if she herself is righteous, a woman lacking distinguished lineage might have indecent children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 17_Paragraph: When grain is abundant in the world, it is a sign that males will be born; when wine is abundant, it is a sign that females will be born.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 18_Paragraph: One who has no son should regularly bring gifts to Torah scholars and recite the portion of bikkurim (Deuteronomy 26:1-11). He should also learn a great deal of Talmud and minimize his study of Aggadah, which is a segulah for having daughters.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 19_Paragraph: Mastering the study of Halakhic codifiers so that one is able to instruct others causes many barren women to conceive.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 20_Paragraph: Being taken captive sometimes spares a person the loss of his children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 21_Paragraph: By giving charity one merits having children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 22_Paragraph: A segulah for eliminating the difficulty a woman has in childbirth is to hang the cemetery key around her neck. This key is also a segulah for healing barrenness.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 23_Paragraph: A man who experiences a seminal emission [should be concerned that] his children will die.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 24_Paragraph: When used in building a bed, there are certain types of wood that will hinder conception and child rearing, and other types that are beneficial for conception and raising one’s children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 25_Paragraph: A man whose children die young should have the mother of a remaining child make a garment for that child to wear until he grows up.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 26_Paragraph: When the Jewish people are fruitful and multiply, the nations issue new decrees against us.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 27_Paragraph: The suffering that a person endures is beneficial for bearing children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 28_Paragraph: Thorns are a segulah for bearing children.
text.10_Children, 1_Part II, 29_Paragraph: Whoever is born circumcised clearly has a good and wholesome imagination.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person should avoid entering an abandoned house, because it is a place of evil spirits.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: One who suffers misfortune in a certain town should move elsewhere.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: When the Tzaddik enters a house that is destined for blessing, the blessing comes as well.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: There are places that are designated to have good things to happen in them. The opposite is also true, [as there are places designated for bad to happen there].
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: All the seemingly natural occurrences that befall a person, for good or bad, are influenced by time and place.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Avenging one’s jealousy destroys a person’s home.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: A person has no desire to benefit a place from which he departs.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Don’t live in the vicinity of a boor who behaves piously.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Any house where the words of Torah are heard at night will never be destroyed.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: People age twice as fast in a city with many hills.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: There is blessing in a house where wine is poured like water.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: Do not enter a house in which there are crosses.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: A person who wants to move into a house should first recite the entire Five Books of Moses and then move in.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: One who owns no property is not a man.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: There are locations that induce one to sin.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: A woman’s anger and immorality destroy her home.
text.11_A House, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: It is a bad sign for a house when its threshold and entrances are destroyed.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Living in the upper storey of a house is better for serving God than living in a lower storey.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Sometimes, the structure of a house prevents the woman [living there] from bearing children. When the beams in the structure are not positioned in the manner designated for them since the six days of Creation, the house is considered a ruin even while standing. This ruin harms the woman and she cannot bear offspring.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: At the entrance of a person’s house one can determine if the owner’s ancestral merit has ceased or if it is still in effect.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: One should take care that the wood of a fruit-bearing tree was not used in the construction of his house.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Concerning the beams of a building: If one is worthy, they are like the standing seraphim, and the building will remain standing for a long time. If he is not worthy, the seraphim are consumed; this being a most common reason for fires.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: It is a bad sign for one’s offspring when he builds a wall and its top part falls off.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: A person has pleasure only when he lives in a place where his ancestors once lived.
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: A segulah for a person moving into a new house is to bring into it a sword, a knife, or some other type of weapon. A hint to this is found in the verse, “A house is built with ChoKhMah (wisdom)” (Proverbs 24:3); the letters standing for “Klei Chamas Me’cheiroteihem (weapons are their wares)” (Genesis 49:5) —[me’cheiroteihem referring alternatively to] “their swords” or “their dwelling places.”
text.11_A House, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: A house’s roof is indicative of what will happen to the group or family living there.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 0_Paragraph: Whoever embarrasses a fellow Jew becomes dumbstruck and forgetful.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 1_Paragraph: It is permissible to embarrass those rabbis who purchase their position for self-pride. It is appropriate to disgrace them and make light of their honor. Do not stand up for them or call them rabbi. The mantle they wear is like a donkey’s saddle.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 2_Paragraph: It is better to neglect Torah study than to embarrass a fellow Jew.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 3_Paragraph: Whoever embarrasses a Torah scholar, or shames a fellow Jew in the presence of a Torah scholar, will become a heretic. He is referred to as one who acts insolently toward the Torah.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 4_Paragraph: The Tzaddik’s coat atones for the spilling of blood.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 5_Paragraph: When people ridicule you, you should fast and cry.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 6_Paragraph: The reason you suffer shame is only so that you should repent for those transgressions that you take lightly.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 7_Paragraph: Embarrassment also comes when you rejoice in the troubles of a fellow Jew.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 8_Paragraph: Picture the letters of the word emunah—אמונה—and you will never be disgraced.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 9_Paragraph: Whoever has to offer an object as collateral in order to borrow money clearly must have despised that object in a previous incarnation.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 10_Paragraph: A person who suffers shame can hope for salvation.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 11_Paragraph: One who wants to be modest should picture his mother’s image.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 12_Paragraph: To attain the quality of modesty, give charity for the sake of Heaven.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 13_Paragraph: One who suffers some shame clearly lacks trust in God.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 14_Paragraph: A person who digs a pit will eventually suffer some shame. Sometimes, it even causes him to become the topic of everyone’s conversations.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 15_Paragraph: Having trust in God will spare one from being shamed.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 16_Paragraph: One who steals from the poor will suffer embarrassment.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 17_Paragraph: Accept and bear the disgrace and shame you receive from a person who is not your enemy. His disgracing you certainly comes from Heaven; with it you will be hidden and protected from Satan, who is your enemy and is always rising up against you with accusations. By accepting embarrassment at the hands of one who is not your enemy, the real enemy, Satan, will not rise against you.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 18_Paragraph: Flattery will cause you to be despised in the eyes of the nations. They will curse you and vent their anger against you.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 19_Paragraph: When someone embarrasses or ridicules you, clearly it is because you disgraced his ancestors.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 20_Paragraph: When everyone embarrasses you and causes you anguish, remain silent and don’t leave your house.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 21_Paragraph: When they shame you, give charity.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 22_Paragraph: By giving charity you will acquire the quality of modesty.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 23_Paragraph: The Holy One exacts payment for a king’s shame, even from a nation that embarrasses the king of another nation.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 24_Paragraph: In the World to Come, the sinner will be ashamed to face his teachers {ancestors}.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 25_Paragraph: One who embarrasses a Torah scholar will find no cure for his wounds.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 26_Paragraph: Don’t jump to embarrass a fellow Jew when you hear him saying something false. Rather, make some gesture so that he will recognize that it is not so.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 27_Paragraph: It is a mitzvah to publicize the wicked.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 28_Paragraph: One who tends to get embarrassed will not easily sin.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 29_Paragraph: If a person has no modesty, clearly his ancestors were not present at Mount Sinai.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 30_Paragraph: It is better to let oneself be thrown into a flaming furnace than to publicly shame a fellow Jew.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 31_Paragraph: When a fellow Jew embarrasses you, admit to his words.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 32_Paragraph: Publicly embarrassing a fellow Jew is like spilling his blood. A person who does this descends into hell and does not emerge.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 33_Paragraph: It is better for a man to have sexual relations with a woman whose marital status is in doubt, than to embarrass a fellow Jew in public, for which he loses his portion of the World to Come.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 34_Paragraph: Do not embarrass a fellow Jew who keeps the Torah and mitzvot. However, it is permissible to shame and verbally deceive a committed sinner.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 35_Paragraph: All heaven’s gates have been sealed, except for the gate [that receives the cries] of those who have been cheated.
text.12_Embarrassment; Modesty, 36_Paragraph: All retribution is exacted through a messenger other than in cases involving deceit, [for which the cheater is punished directly by God]. The curtain of heaven is never sealed to [the prayers of] a person who has been cheated.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: The clothing that a person wears is indicative of his character.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Whoever must go barefoot clearly must be a sinner.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: A person who is insolent, or who fails to fulfill his oaths, loses his clothing.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: A person who does not refrain from staring at his father’s nakedness will, in the end, see his children going unclad and barefoot.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Anyone who eats before praying will lose his clothing.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: A haughty person loses his clothing.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: A person who lures a fellow Jew from the good path to the evil one will not have what to wear.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Whoever stands as a guarantor for a gentile loses his clothing.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: There will come a time when the Holy One will exact punishment from those who dress in the clothing of the gentiles.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: A person whose poverty forces him to wear torn clothing can rectify this by crying out to God.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Whoever disrespects clothing will in the end have no pleasure from them.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: By providing clothing for the poor, one is spared embarrassment.
text.13_Clothing, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: One who is careful not to embarrass any person is rewarded with clothing.
text.13_Clothing, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Telling stories about the Tzaddikim draws the light of Mashiach into the world. It also dispels much darkness and pain from the world. And the storyteller is rewarded with beautiful clothing.
text.13_Clothing, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: A person who is accustomed to cursing will lack clothing for Shabbat.
text.13_Clothing, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Anyone who pays undue attention to adorning his feet, such as by wearing exquisite footwear or pants, will become duplicitous.
text.13_Clothing, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: One who shows disrespect for the mitzvah of tzitzit will not merit burial.
text.13_Clothing, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Whoever provides clothing for a fellow Jew can alter his will in any way he wishes, in both physical and spiritual matters.
text.13_Clothing, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: When a person wears his father’s clothing, it is easier for him to follow in his father’s ways.
text.13_Clothing, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: “L’chu lachmu v’lachmi u’shetu b’yayin masakhti (Come eat of my bread and drink of the wine that I have mixed)” (Proverbs 9:5). The first letters of L’chu Lachmu V’Lachmi U’shetu spell LULaV (לולב). B’yayin (ביין), with its four letters, has a numerical value (76) equivalent to that of the first letters of etrog (אתרוג), hadas (הדס) and aravah (ערבה); and maSaKhTi is similar to SuKkoT. By fulfilling the mitzvot of the Four Species and sukkah, a person is rewarded with food, drink, clothing and a revived spirit. Through the mitzvah of sukkah he merits clothing, as in “When I made a cloud its garment” (Job 38:9). By virtue of the willow branch he merits sufficient drink; through the myrtle branch he brings vitality to the soul; and through the palm tree and the citron tree, both of which bear edible fruit, he merits having enough to eat.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who trusts in God fears nothing.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Trust in God comes from fearing Him.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Faith brings to trust in God.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person who does not trust in God tells lies.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Telling lies prevents one from trusting in the truth.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: When one trusts in God, the Holy One saves him from all anguish, and particularly from being killed.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: When a person trusts in God, he is free from having to rely on others. No one can insult him.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Trust in God saves one from worry.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: By trusting God a person will merit knowing the Holy Names.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: A person who does not possess the attribute of trust in God should guard against shaming anyone. He should also take care to pray with an attentive heart.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: The life of a person who trusts in God will not be cut short.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: One who does not trust in God should rise before the morning’s light and recite supplications in a loud voice.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: Through silence one merits trusting in God.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Not sealing one’s business agreements with a handshake enables one to attain trust in God. This can also be achieved by not associating with wicked people.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: A flatterer loses his trust in God.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: The waters of the Jordan River are a segulah for trust.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: By trusting in God a person comes closer to Him.
text.14_Trust in God, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: When a person trusts in gentiles, what is his is theirs.
text.14_Trust in God, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: When in the course of doing something with faith a person encounters adversity, he should trust that the Holy One will save him. God arranged this obstacle for him so that he should pave the way for his sons to be saved from this same adversity.
text.14_Trust in God, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: A person who guards against idolatrous thoughts will always trust in God, never worrying about tomorrow. He is on the level of “Blessed is God who day after day bears our burden” (Psalms 68:20), and because of this, “{the Holy One} observed no iniquity and saw no misery in him” (Numbers 23:21). Whoever lays a hand on him, it is as if he were “harming the apple of God’s eye” (Zekhariah 2:12).
text.15_Tidings, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: By making it a habit to be the bearer of good tidings, one clothes oneself in the attribute of the prophet Elijah.
text.15_Tidings, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Don’t be the bearer of bad news. Many people have died after receiving bad tidings.
text.15_Tidings, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: A person who performs a mitzvah correctly is not brought bad news. The Holy One’s decrees and he annuls.
text.15_Tidings, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Relating bad news causes a person to fall into constricted consciousness.
text.15_Tidings, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: By making it a habit to be the bearer of good tidings, a person’s feet will not cause him pain.
text.16_Blessing, 0_Paragraph: One who receives a blessing should give some gift to the person who blessed him.
text.16_Blessing, 1_Paragraph: Don’t take the blessing of a gentile lightly.
text.16_Blessing, 2_Paragraph: One who draws those who are far from God into serving Him is given the power to bless others.
text.17_Crying, 0_Paragraph: A person who cannot bring himself to cry should gaze at the firmament, because it was the firmament that caused the waters to cry [by separating between the lower and upper waters of Creation].
text.17_Crying, 2_Paragraph: Crying over the destruction of the Holy Temple is a segulah for healing a neck ailment.
text.18_Haughtiness, 0_Paragraph: Mashiach will come only when {all} haughtiness is eliminated from the world.
text.18_Haughtiness, 1_Paragraph: Pride leads a person to homosexual desires and anger. There are times when a woman cannot become pregnant because she glamorizes herself and is haughty.
text.18_Haughtiness, 2_Paragraph: Haughtiness brings hunger to the world.
text.18_Haughtiness, 3_Paragraph: Pride leads a person to drunkenness, and vice versa.
text.18_Haughtiness, 4_Paragraph: A person’s haughtiness causes him to be afraid.
text.18_Haughtiness, 5_Paragraph: Giving charity is a segulah for eliminating pride.
text.18_Haughtiness, 6_Paragraph: The Holy One incites enemies against a rabbi who haughtily rules over people against their will.
text.18_Haughtiness, 7_Paragraph: When a person feels his heart is uplifted, he should know that this is an opportune time for him.
text.18_Haughtiness, 8_Paragraph: One who saves the poor has the power to humble proud people by [merely] staring at them.
text.18_Haughtiness, 9_Paragraph: A person who falls while walking in public clearly is haughty.
text.18_Haughtiness, 10_Paragraph: A segulah for eliminating one’s pride is to empathize with the suffering of the Jewish people.
text.18_Haughtiness, 11_Paragraph: You should know that when a wicked person persecutes a pauper, it is on account of the poor man’s pride.
text.18_Haughtiness, 12_Paragraph: A person’s pride causes him to fall from his faith.
text.18_Haughtiness, 13_Paragraph: Haughtiness prevents one’s heart and eyes from seeing God’s wonders and thus fearing Him.
text.18_Haughtiness, 14_Paragraph: A person should not take pride in his intellectual achievements and good deeds, which all stem from the Tzaddik of the generation. He is to the Tzaddik like a pen in the hand of a scribe.
text.18_Haughtiness, 15_Paragraph: Eating and drinking lead to haughtiness.
text.18_Haughtiness, 16_Paragraph: Pride can be rectified through fasting.
text.18_Haughtiness, 17_Paragraph: A segulah for eliminating pride is to gaze at the heavens.
text.18_Haughtiness, 18_Paragraph: A person is sent confusing dreams in order to remove his deep seated haughtiness, which is hidden from him and of which he is unaware.
text.18_Haughtiness, 19_Paragraph: When a person is haughty, his wisdom and foresight depart.
text.18_Haughtiness, 20_Paragraph: Reason cannot tolerate the poor person who exhibits pride. He will one day regret his behavior and be ashamed of himself.
text.18_Haughtiness, 21_Paragraph: A proud person is incapable of humbling his opinions. He will experience forgetfulness.
text.18_Haughtiness, 23_Paragraph: There are certain circumstances in which one is permitted to behave in a manner that appears haughty.
text.18_Haughtiness, 24_Paragraph: A person’s pride eventually leads him to immoral behavior with another man’s wife. When a person is haughty, it is as if he serves idolatry and denies God’s existence, and as if he engaged in sexual relations with all the women forbidden to him by the Torah. He is likened to one who builds an altar [for unlawful worship]. His importance diminishes and disappears entirely, and it would be right to cut him down like a tree used for idolatry. The Divine Presence laments over him and he will not rise from the dust [at the time of the Resurrection].
text.18_Haughtiness, 25_Paragraph: Wearing the Tzaddik’s hat is a segulah for removing pride.
text.18_Haughtiness, 26_Paragraph: Having faith will give you the strength to break your pride; you’ll have mastery over the trait of haughtiness.
text.18_Haughtiness, 27_Paragraph: The plans of a proud person will prove unsuccessful.
text.18_Haughtiness, 28_Paragraph: Should you sin unwittingly, you can be sure that you possess pride. This is to show that you are not yet righteous.
text.18_Haughtiness, 29_Paragraph: When you experience some feelings of haughtiness, beware of trouble.
text.18_Haughtiness, 30_Paragraph: A humble pauper, though he does not give charity, is better than a haughty rich man, even if he is generous.
text.18_Haughtiness, 31_Paragraph: When beset by feelings of pride, picture the image of your father.
text.18_Haughtiness, 32_Paragraph: Haughtiness is a portent for disaster, God forbid.
text.18_Haughtiness, 33_Paragraph: Pride stems from a person’s not having rectified the sins of his youth.
text.18_Haughtiness, 34_Paragraph: When one’s wine ferments, clearly it is because he is haughty.
text.18_Haughtiness, 36_Paragraph: God says of a haughty person: “He and I cannot live together in the world.” Even a small wind causes him trouble. His prayers are not heard and he has no cure. He will be wanting in Torah and even his own wife will disgrace him.
text.18_Haughtiness, 37_Paragraph: One who undeservingly wears the mantle of a Torah scholar is not allowed to enter into the sanctum of the Holy One.
text.18_Haughtiness, 38_Paragraph: Haughtiness delays Mashiach and drives a person from the world.
text.18_Haughtiness, 39_Paragraph: Reciting the verses, “Though his excellence rises to the heavens...” (Job 20:6), and “For riches are not forever...” (Proverbs 27:24), is a segulah for breaking one’s pride.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 0_Paragr: Once a person whose heart is tempted to steal permits himself that which belongs to another, he is capable of committing any sin. There are no means to rectify this, to turn him from his evil ways.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 1_Paragr: The sin of theft brings locust and famine, and people will even eat their own children’s flesh.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 2_Paragr: Whoever has not allowed others to benefit from his wealth will be robbed.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 3_Paragr: Stealing a penny’s worth from a fellow Jew, even indirectly, is akin to taking his soul and the souls of his children.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 4_Paragr: Whoever shows no concern for another’s possessions is clearly a thief.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 5_Paragr: Financially defrauding an idol-worshipper is permissible.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 6_Paragr: A person who closes his hand to giving charity will be robbed.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 7_Paragr: One who places his trust in gentiles will in the end have his possessions forcibly taken from him.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 8_Paragr: Appointing unqualified judges, teachers or ritual slaughterers causes the livelihood of the Jewish people to be devoured by their enemies.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 9_Paragr: Whoever dilutes the wine he sells will be attacked by thieves.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 10_Parag: A person who shares in stolen property will eventually be exposed.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 11_Parag: When thieves populate a city, clearly the rabbi there favors bribery.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 13_Parag: Deceiving people is permitted in order to save a Jewish soul.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 14_Parag: A person who embarrasses a fellow Jew will eventually testify falsely in order to steal money.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 15_Parag: A person whose trust in God has been nurtured from childhood will be saved from robbers.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 0_Part I, 16_Parag: Thieves come when foolish matters are discussed.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 1_Part II, 0_Parag: Deceit brings disease to one’s lungs and chest, God forbid.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 1_Part II, 1_Parag: Deceit leads one to sexual thoughts for a gentile woman.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 1_Part II, 2_Parag: A person who steals loses his wisdom.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 1_Part II, 4_Parag: Reciting Tikkun Chatzot saves one from thieves.
text.19_Theft and Robbery, 1_Part II, 5_Parag: A person who feels the pains of child rearing should recite daily the Torah sections that depict Creation (Genesis 1). Reading this also saves one from being falsely accused of stealing.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 0_Paragra: There are times when God causes a person to experience certain things so that through them he will appreciate His Godliness and mercy.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 1_Paragra: A person who is confused should regularly recite the prayer of the prophet Habakkuk (Habakkuk 3:1-9).
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 2_Paragra: Studying the Halakhic codifier known as Siftei Kohen is also especially beneficial for this; as is eating wheat.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 3_Paragra: The foods that a person eats give rise to a nature in him similar to their own.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 4_Paragra: The taste of grains brings one a capacity for knowledge.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 5_Paragra: Wine and fragrance sharpen the mind.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 7_Paragra: The suffering a person feels from something he has seen is greater than what he feels from something he knows only intellectually.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 8_Paragra: One who studies Torah and engages in acts of kindness merits understanding.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 9_Paragra: Eating bread in the morning makes one wise.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 10_Paragr: II The Holy One rests His prophecy on a prophet for a specific mission, even if he is not a person of wisdom.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 11_Paragr: With their wisdom, the wise are able to ascertain many things that one with normal intellect cannot comprehend.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 12_Paragr: One who desires wisdom should turn southward [while praying],
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 13_Paragr: When a person wants to know how to proceed in a particular situation, let him open a holy book and he will understand what to do.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 14_Paragr: Olive oil makes the heart clever.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 15_Paragr: Following the path of simplicity makes one intelligent.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 16_Paragr: One who has faith will afterwards merit serving God with great wisdom.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 17_Paragr: Fear of God will earn you wisdom.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 18_Paragr: Recognizing Tzaddikim will earn you understanding and daat.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 19_Paragr: When a person conducts himself with modesty, his thoughts are clear.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 20_Paragr: It is easier to understand something when one sees it with his own eyes.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 21_Paragr: Whoever is careful not to eat the cooked foods of gentiles, or drink their wine, merits wisdom and gains understanding in all the holy works.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 22_Paragr: A haughty person cannot comprehend God’s sovereignty over everything.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 23_Paragr: Not performing acts of kindness causes you to lack daat.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 24_Paragr: Being the cause of any sort of damage should make you realize that you have blemished your intellect.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 25_Paragr: One to whom some insight has been revealed clearly will soon experience some elevation.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 26_Paragr: When a person wholeheartedly repents, the Holy One enables his heart to know His desire and will.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 27_Paragr: A person who has not rectified his sins cannot truly know God.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 28_Paragr: Through truth you will merit knowing the way of God.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 29_Paragr: You can also come to this by being hospitable.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 30_Paragr: By performing deeds of true kindness for Tzaddikim, you will merit knowing that all paths—be it prayer, eating, or any of the physical pleasures—are the way of God.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 31_Paragr: Expressing your happiness in song will make you wise.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 32_Paragr: When a person is repaid with bad for the good he has done, God shows him mercy and grants him great wisdom in serving the Creator.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 0_Part I, 33_Paragr: The more good deeds a person does, the more the Holy One deepens his thought; that is, He gives him a greater mind.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 0_Paragr: Know! each world and every creation has its own particular form and unique construction. For example, the build of the lion differs from that of the sheep in its strength and in its bone structure {also in its voice}. This is also true within the lion species {itself}; there being differences between one lion and the next. These distinctions between creations are alluded to in the forms of the letters and their combinations. One who merits understanding the Torah is able to understand these differences between all the creations. He will also know what they have in common—namely, their origin and their end, in which they are identical, without distinction.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 1_Paragr: Know! a person has mastery over the world in direct proportion to his knowledge of Torah and Nature. This is why Daniel was able to subdue the lions, since he was very wise and “no secret escaped him” (Daniel 4:6). He knows the lion’s nature, and Nature itself follows and is under the dictates of Torah knowledge. (Reb Nachman Tulchiner said: “I heard from Reb Noson that this teaching relates to the one preceding it, to what is written there, ‘One who merits understanding the Torah...’ Thus, his understanding of the combinations of the letters in the Torah is in direct proportion to his knowledge of the natural behavior of things in the world. Understand this! For a wonderful and very pleasing explanation of this, see Likutey Halakhot, Yoreh Deah, Milah 5:23ff. The truth is that one who looks with a positive and true eye and with an upright heart will find no difficulty in comprehending this. One the contrary, he will see the wonders of God’s greatness and that of the true Tzaddikim.
