These opponents, who arrogantly speak against the Tzaddik and from the very outset view the Tzaddik’s holy writings with an eye to finding fault, will never find a satisfying explanation. Even after all these explanations and truths, they continue to look for pretexts and devise false charges with which to haughtily speak against the Tzaddik and his disciples, may their merit protect us. Nevertheless, I could not hold myself back from presenting a bit of what I heard regarding this. For truth stands! ‘But a lying tongue is for a moment’ (Proverbs 12:19), ‘and the truth of God is forever’ (Psalms 117:2). He will save us from the double-edged sword; and, as His mercy has supported until now, so will it support us evermore. Amen! Study Likutey Moharan 1,17 and 19, and you will understand a little.”)
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 2_Paragr: When a person attains the insight that God is One and that there is no other, this enables him to force corporeality upon the angels on high, so that they go and do his bidding.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 3_Paragr: When a person uses his faith to banish thoughts of idolatry, those thoughts are transformed into the aspect of “the dew of blessing.” This also results in his mind remaining firm and never becoming confused. Even when it is taxed by deep concentration on a complex subject, the Holy One provides him with thoughts that relieve his mind.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 4_Paragr: The merit of those who support the poor saves the masses from plague. Also in their merit, expanded consciousness precedes [rather than follows] constricted consciousness.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 5_Paragr: Even within foolishness and folly there is wisdom.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 6_Paragr: Hearing the voice of a person who is wise in the ways of holiness is especially beneficial for acquiring the fear of God.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 7_Paragr: Confusion of the mind corrupts one’s fear of God. It also diminishes his authority.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 8_Paragr: The sages of a generation are its wings. The generation’s closeness to and understanding of God, or conversely its distance from Him, is in direct proportion to the wisdom of these sages. But in the future, people will not require wisdom in order to perceive His Godliness, for then, “And your Teacher will not withdraw Himself anymore” (Isaiah 30:20) will be fulfilled in us.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 9_Paragr: One who wants to use his intellect to delve into and investigate some subject should bind his intellect to the Holy Temple. This is alluded to by the verses, “I will fetch my knowledge from afar” (Job 36:3), and “He saw the place, [the Temple Mount,] from afar” (Genesis 22:4).
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 11_Parag: When people convert, daat is increased in the world.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 12_Parag: Even the prophets know only that which the Holy One reveals to them.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 13_Parag: A physically strong person has only mediocre intelligence.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 15_Parag: A person who steals loses his wisdom.
text.20_Knowledge of God, 1_Part II, 16_Parag: When a person’s thoughts are on the physical needs of a fellow Jew, and that person’s thoughts are on his physical needs, this forms the crossbeams of the world.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: When traveling across a sea, take along a bird and a sea fish, as this is a segulah for reaching one’s destiny in peace.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: A person who rejoices together with the groom and bride as they emerge from their wedding canopy will not be harmed when traveling.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: The Traveler’s Prayer should be recited while the coachman is preparing the wagon and horses.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: When traveling on the sea, taking along limestone is a segulah to save one from harm.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person who arranges livelihood for Tzaddikim is assured that God will protect him on the road and at sea.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: A person who rides a horse should take along willow branches.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Before traveling, attach yourself to the trait of trust in God and your feet will not stumble.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Give charity before setting out on a journey.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: All the paths that a person follows come from and are the will of God. But it is only the humble person who can understand His way.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Carrying stones found in the fields will save you from wild beasts.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Reciting the prayer of the prophet Jonah (Jonah 2:2-10) is a segulah when traveling on the sea.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: The escort a person receives when leaving a place protects him from harm on the road.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: One who has no one to escort him should study Torah.
text.21_Traveling, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: A person possesses the ground on which he treads.
text.21_Traveling, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: On account of those who confess their sins, the Holy One provides schoolteachers who instruct faithfully.
text.21_Traveling, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Confession also brings about the repairing of roads from obstacles.
text.21_Traveling, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: The perils of traveling come about when a person blemishes the brit, as hinted in the verse, “You have measured my going about and my lying down, [and You are acquainted with all of my ways”] (Psalms 139:3).
text.21_Traveling, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Travel provides a person with understanding.
text.21_Traveling, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: After a frightening dream at night, don’t take to the road on the following day.
text.21_Traveling, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: Being on the road brings a person to slander, idolatry, immorality and bloodshed. These sins also diminish one’s livelihood.
text.22_A Judge, 0_Paragraph: The decision of a truthful judge is never annulled. His verdict is carried out, even against the will of the litigants.
text.22_A Judge, 1_Paragraph: A decline in adherence to legal rulings based on the Torah causes a decrease in livelihood. The inverse is also true, [as an increase in adherence to Torah law brings an increase in income].
text.22_A Judge, 2_Paragraph: The appointment of unqualified judges gives rise to thoughts of idolatry.
text.22_A Judge, 3_Paragraph: When people choose Torah scholars for their daughters to marry, proper judges are appointed.
text.22_A Judge, 4_Paragraph: Proper judges cause the Torah to become valued in the world.
text.22_A Judge, 5_Paragraph: The land’s produce is cursed when judges are treated with contempt.
text.22_A Judge, 6_Paragraph: When Jewish judges are disgraced, the world is beset by inflation.
text.22_A Judge, 7_Paragraph: Whenever a wicked person prospers, it becomes difficult to develop new logical arguments in disputed matters of Halakhah. Judges’ verdicts also become unacceptable to the litigants.
text.22_A Judge, 8_Paragraph: A city’s taxes and property fees are raised on account of its judges.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 0_Para: The afflictions dispatched against a person are made to take an oath that they will begin only on a set date and end only on a set date, and at a set time, and [carry out their mission] only through the designated means. Nevertheless, repentance, prayer and charity have the power to nullify their oath.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 1_Para: Despair, that is to say, depression, opens a person to bad fortune, and through bad fortune the attribute of severe judgment rules.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 2_Para: Reciting the Torah chapters about the choshen (Exodus 28:15-30; 39:8-21) is a rectification for harsh judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 3_Para: A person who suffers affliction should give charity. This charity will be like a fee paid to a judge for his services, which, if accepted, invalidates the judge’s verdict. The person’s severe judgments are thus mitigated.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 4_Para: What is the least amount of suffering [that can still be considered suffering]? [See Arakhin 16b: “Even just reaching into one’s pocket for three coins and coming up with only two is a form of suffering.”]
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 5_Para: Whoever goes forty days without suffering has already been given his share of the World to Come. Misfortune is on the way.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 6_Para: One who rebukes a fellow Jew for the sake of Heaven has a thread of lovingkindness drawn over him.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 7_Para: There are three things that call to mind a person’s sins: a shaky wall, expectation in prayer, and an informant who brings judgment upon another.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 8_Para: There are four things which abolish harsh decrees against a person: giving charity, crying out to God, changing one’s name, and improving one’s conduct.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 9_Para: Crying out to God helps an individual only prior to the final decree.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 10_Par: A final decree accompanied by an oath is not abolished, even for the sake of an entire community.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 11_Par: Fasting during a year of hunger saves a person from an unnatural death.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 12_Par: When judgments are decreed against a person, they are decreed for a specific place. This way, he can save {himself} by changing his place.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 13_Par: When one feels pain in his eyes or intestines, clearly harsh judgments have settled upon him.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 14_Par: A person should tell others about his anguish so that they will pray for mercy on his behalf.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 15_Par: When there is some harsh judgment against Israel, God forbid, the Holy One informs the Tzaddikim of this so that they should pray for the Jewish people. Whoever does not pray for them incurs God’s anger.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 16_Par: Seeing that he has been beset by harsh judgments, a person should talk about his enemies and justify their actions.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 18_Par: God punishes a person who makes a vow and does not carry it out. Then, if he remains silent, it is considered as if he fulfilled his vow.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 19_Par: Accepting suffering with love is like bringing a sacrifice.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 20_Par: When a person falls while walking, it is a sign that on high he has been designated for a downfall.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 21_Par: Immersing in a mikvah relieves suffering and brings salvation.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 22_Par: As long as a harsh decree against a person has not yet become public knowledge, it can be easily overturned.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 23_Par: Whoever falls from faith should know that he is being judged on high.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 24_Par: A person suffering from harsh judgments should regularly gaze at the heavens.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 25_Par: The Holy One exonerates a person who teaches righteousness to the wicked.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 26_Par: Through truth one receives God’s lovingkindness undisguised by judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 27_Par: The Holy One hides His face from you because of the heresy that you have within.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 28_Par: Trust in God mitigates judgment and draws down lovingkindness.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 29_Par: Through faith it is possible to convince God to follow your will.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 30_Par: Charity turns justice and judgment into lovingkindness.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 31_Par: When a person has no faith, clearly God has removed His lovingkindness from him.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 32_Par: When lovingkindness is dear and scarce, you should know that crying helps for this. (Reb Noson adds: “When I transcribed this from the Rebbe, I heard from his holy mouth that this aphorism is alluded to in the verse, ‘How dear is Your lovingkindness, God; therefore the children of man take shelter under the shadow of Your wings’ (Psalms 36:8). ‘How dear is your lovingkindness’—that is, lovingkindness is dear and scarce since harsh judgments are prevalent, God forbid. The solution then is for ‘the children of man [to] B’tzail K’nafekha Yechesayun (take shelter under the shadow of your wings).’ The first letters spell Be’KhY (crying), since crying helps for this.”)
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 34_Par: Giving charity to a worthy person enables you to draw lovingkindness also upon your loved ones.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 35_Par: A person who does not accept rebuke will experience suffering.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 36_Par: To mitigate harsh judgments, recite Psalm 39.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 37_Par: A person who girds himself and makes many preparations before praying is relieved from suffering, even if in the end he does not pray as he should.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 38_Par: To mitigate harsh judgments, recite the Mishnayot of the tractate Zera’im.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 39_Par: There are times when the Holy One will put an end to a father’s suffering so that his son finds peace.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 41_Par: To mitigate harsh judgments, recite Psalm 77.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 42_Par: Whoever binds himself to the quality of faith at night mitigates the harsh judgments that are upon him.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 43_Par: Haughtiness causes lovingkindness to depart heavenward.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 45_Par: Remaining awake throughout the night saves a person from harsh judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 46_Par: From the suffering that he experiences, a person can determine and understand his sins.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 47_Par: Visiting the Tzaddik is in itself sufficient to mitigate harsh judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 48_Par: Likewise, giving charity to the Tzaddik is in itself sufficient to mitigate harsh judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 49_Par: When a person is depressed, on high they consider ways to cause him harm.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 50_Par: A person’s accusers are beaten off by the study of Torah.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 51_Par: Falling down while walking sometimes nullifies a sentence of death that has been issued against a person.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 52_Par: When the nations issue an evil decree against the Jews, Psalm 62 should be said.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 53_Par: Remaining underwater in the mikvah until you can no longer hold your breath mitigates harsh judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 54_Par: There are times when drinking wine will arouse harsh judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 55_Par: Whoever gives his bread to someone with no daat will experience suffering.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 56_Par: A person who lacks daat will in the end be exiled.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 57_Par: Postponing harsh judgments causes them to be nullified.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 58_Par: Whoever studies Torah for its own sake brings peace to the Divine agencies of both heaven and earth.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 59_Par: One who recites a Torah verse at its appropriate time brings good to the world.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 60_Par: There are certain times and places that are designated to have good things happen in them. The opposite is also true, [as there are times and places designated for bad].
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 61_Par: There are times when harsh judgment can be staid by the leader of the generation, and other times by the people of the generation.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 62_Par: From one’s enemies it is possible to determine the harsh judgments that are on high.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 63_Par: When hearing a fellow Jew speak of his suffering, one must listen wisely so that this suffering does not then befall him.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 64_Par: When a person studies Torah at night, the Holy One draws a thread of lovingkindness upon him during the day.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 65_Par: One should give money to charity for a pidyon.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 66_Par: As long as it is possible to save yourself with money, don’t make use of the power of prayer.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 67_Par: Whenever there is a dispute on high over some matter, the final decision follows the opinion of the Tzaddik who is alive in this world.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 68_Par: When a person is judged on high, he is judged by his name, it sometimes happens that the heavenly messengers substitute another’s name, so that the decree of death or suffering falls upon someone else.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 69_Par: Whoever does not plead for mercy on behalf of his generation is punished.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 70_Par: If you have someone sick or suffering in your home, go to a sage so that the sage will plead for mercy on his behalf or will bless him.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 71_Par: Those who hear accusations against the Jewish people must speak well of them and endeavor to find their good points.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 72_Par: The Holy One removes His wrath when He sees His honor jealously defended.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 73_Par: The best time for a pidyon or for prayer is only during the day.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 74_Par: Not everyone is sufficiently worthy of performing a pidyon.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 75_Par: A person who wants to mitigate harsh judgments should not drink wine that entire day.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 76_Par: Through humility we appease the Holy One.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 77_Par: In times of harsh judgment, a person should pray fervently.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 78_Par: Building a stone house is mortally dangerous.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 80_Par: Immersing in a mikvah mitigates harsh judgments.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 81_Par: Once the final decree has been passed, it is necessary to veil one’s prayer in stories.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 82_Par: By opening a Torah scroll, harsh judgment is mitigated and returned to its place of origin.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 84_Par: Fasting and donning sackcloth are a segulah for nullifying a decree.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 85_Par: To mitigate harsh judgments, recite the Torah sections about the eleven curtains of goat-skin (Exodus 26:7-14, 36:14-19), the incense-offering (Exodus 30:34-38), the eleven blessings that Moses blessed the Jewish people (Deuteronomy 33:6-25), and the Vision of the Chariot in Ezekiel (Chapter 1).
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 86_Par: Also, recite the Torah section on vows (Numbers 30), and the Mishnayot of the tractate Shavuot.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 88_Par: Reciting the Song of Songs mitigates harsh judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 89_Par: A person who can study Torah but does not, experiences suffering.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 90_Par: Studying the tractate Ohalot is a segulah for mitigating harsh judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 91_Par: A person who raises dogs arouses harsh judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 92_Par: There are times when God will bring suffering upon a wicked person so that he should turn to the Tzaddik to pray on his behalf.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 93_Par: Harsh judgments can be mitigated by drawing lots, as was the case with the Azazel (see Leviticus 16). <small>(Reb Noson writes that he heard the following explanation from Rebbe Nachman’s holy mouth at the time of transcribing this aphorism: “A person should take two coins and draw lots—one for God and the other for Azazel. The coin that is designated for God should be given to charity; the other one, designated for Azazel, should be thrown away. This will mitigate harsh judgments.”)</small>
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 94_Par: Sometimes, the leading Tzaddik of the generation will get angry at you in order to mitigate harsh judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 95_Par: When a new king or minister rises to power among the nations, harsh judgment is aroused.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 96_Par: When a person stubbornly refuses to repent, he brings irreparable harm upon himself.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 97_Par: It is not good for two people with the same name to live in the same apartment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 100_Pa: A person should let others know of his suffering.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 101_Pa: When permission has been granted to the powers of destruction to act, no distinction is made between the righteous and the wicked. Indeed, the Tzaddik is the first to suffer.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 102_Pa: A change of place eradicates a decree of judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 104_Pa: There are times when a person dies from fright or some other cause of sudden death. You should believe that his time had come.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 105_Pa: Humility enables a person to nullify a decree of judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 106_Pa: Tending to the needs of the Tzaddikim mitigates harsh judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 107_Pa: In reward for having visited the sick, a person dies without suffering.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 0_Part I, 108_Pa: Once judgment has been passed against a person on high—even prior to its going into effect—it can be detected through the flies in the house.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 0_Par: A person who works to mitigate harsh judgments can easily and without hindrance sanctify the Name of God. His eyes do not grow faint.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 1_Par: The suffering a person experiences elevates him.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 2_Par: A person who accepts suffering in order to alleviate the suffering of the Jewish people is rewarded with Divine spirit.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 3_Par: Reciting the Torah sections about the holidays, found in the portion of Pinchas (Numbers 28:15-31; 29:1-39), is a seguldh for nullifying harsh judgment and for success in one’s dealings in secular courts.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 4_Par: Giving charity mitigates the harsh judgment destined for the Future, that is, for the Day of Judgment in the future to come.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 5_Par: There is a person who, when he sees harsh judgments affecting the Jewish people, knows how to transfer them onto one of the nations, as in, “I shall put another in your place” (Isaiah 43:4). Through this, {all} creations return their energy and become encompassed in this person in order to renew their strength. [Turning harsh judgments onto the nations] also opens the gate of parables in the world.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 6_Par: There are those whose acts of kindness sometimes have a negative effect. This corresponds to the warning given to the Kohanim— who personify the aspect of lovingkindness—not to take large steps [while performing the Temple service]. When people pretend not to see the harm brought on by their kindness, they cause the harsh judgment from on high to be without moderation. The inverse is also true. When care is taken that no harm comes from their kindness, it fosters moderation in the judgment.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 7_Par: A person who rejects his suffering is in effect telling God, “Get away from me!”
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 8_Par: When a person labors in Torah study to the point of exhaustion, he mitigates harsh judgments and arouses compassion, even for his father who has passed away.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 9_Par: It is impossible to appease harsh judgment with empty hands.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 10_Pa: A person bitten by a dog clearly has had Heaven’s mercy removed from him. It is also an indication that he has eaten a forbidden food.
text.23_Mitigating Judgment, 1_Part II, 11_Pa: There are times when a Tzaddik’s priding himself with one of his followers conceals that person from the attribute of judgment.
text.24_Seclusion, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who secludes himself and separates himself from people is purified from on high.
text.24_Seclusion, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Isolation and turning one’s attention to idleness lead a person to anger.
text.24_Seclusion, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: The private conversation a person has with God later becomes a means of redemption and salvation for his children.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 0_Paragr: A person’s humility saves him from idolatrous thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 1_Paragr: When bothered by thoughts of idolatry while praying, picture God’s Name Eloheinu—אלהיט—in your mind.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 2_Paragr: Confessing in the presence of a Torah scholar brings to good thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 3_Paragr: Good thoughts are drawn to a person who tells stories about the Tzaddikim.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 4_Paragr: Anyone who has evil thoughts should always look to find good in others.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 5_Paragr: A person’s tears cause him to view all passions with contempt.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 6_Paragr: When a person does not believe in the Tzaddik, his heart is not right with God.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 7_Paragr: Wearing a gartel once worn by a Tzaddik is a segulah for dispelling improper thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 9_Paragr: If after being prideful for having sanctified himself a person breaks that pride, he will attain and acquire the Torah.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 10_Parag: Crying out to God eliminates distracting thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 11_Parag: Studying the four sections of the Shulchan Arukh eliminates distracting thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 12_Parag: Thinking about a Torah insight that you originated is a segulah for eliminating undesirable thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 13_Parag: A person who has unholy thoughts should speak to himself in a degrading way.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 14_Parag: Eating and drinking make the mind sluggish.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 16_Parag: Idolatrous thoughts plague a person who shows disrespect for the Jewish Festivals.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 17_Parag: Sitting in the company of promiscuous people, or in a place where an immoral act was performed, leads one to unholy thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 18_Parag: The evil inclination desires only what is forbidden to it.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 19_Parag: All the passions contain an element of God’s lovingkindness.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 20_Parag: Through forgiveness for sin, you will be rewarded with a pure heart.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 21_Parag: Showing compassion will eliminate your lustful desires.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 22_Parag: The eyes cause the heart to desire.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 23_Parag: The passions of the heart make blemish unavoidable.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 24_Parag: Laxatives are a segulah against immoral thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 25_Parag: Prayer prayed with an attentive heart opens all the doors on high.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 26_Parag: A person with idolatrous thoughts should not wear any gold jewelry.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 28_Parag: A passion for women causes one to lose respect. His wife will not conceive, or she will miscarry, or the child will die in birth.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 29_Parag: Strife leads to idolatrous thoughts. A house in which quarrel is present will be a place in which idolatry is practiced.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 30_Parag: A person beset by untoward thoughts can eliminate them by raising his voice as if to cry.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 31_Parag: Swearing and cursing bring on evil thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 32_Parag: Your trust in God will save you from evil thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 33_Parag: Gritting one’s teeth is a segulah against evil thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 34_Parag: The particular way in which the holy sparks veil themselves in distracting thoughts and then come to a person for rectification depends upon where he is up to in the prayer.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 35_Parag: The tractate Yadayim is a segulah for dispelling evil thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 36_Parag: Whoever prays only for the sake of the Divine Presence will be spared from untoward thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 37_Parag: Through peace God’s Name is exalted.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 38_Parag: When a husband or wife has amorous thoughts for a non-Jew during their marital relations, the child conceived will become an apostate.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 40_Parag: Visiting the sick saves a person from the evil inclination.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 41_Parag: A person’s evil inclination rules over only that which he sees.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 42_Parag: A person not married by age twenty will be bothered by sinful thoughts for the rest of his life.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 43_Parag: Whoever commits a sin and then thinks about doing it again is made to pay for the thought even without having repeated the action.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 44_Parag: To chase away the evil inclination say: “O God, rebuke Satan” (paraphrase of Zekhariah 3:2).
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 45_Parag: A person is not punished for a sudden lust or evil thought that he cannot prevent, unless he goes over it in his mind.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 46_Parag: Cupping is helpful against most bad character traits.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 47_Parag: Eating fish increases one’s sexual desire.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 48_Parag: When a person’s livelihood comes in the merit of his ancestors, he experiences thoughts of idol worship.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 49_Parag: Homosexual practices lead to idolatrous thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 50_Parag: A Jew whose thoughts are for a non-Jewish woman will have thoughts of idolatry.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 51_Parag: Staring at nakedness brings one to an aroused state.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 52_Parag: Disgracing the Festivals is comparable to idol worship.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 53_Parag: When a person has faith, God protects him from improper thoughts and helps him. He departs for the next world free of sin.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 54_Parag: At the time people study Torah and do acts of kindness, they have mastery over their evil inclination.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 55_Parag: A person who has pleasure from anything heretical will eventually be forced to worship idolatry.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 56_Parag: When a person keeps himself from transgressing and seeks forgiveness, he will consequently not sin—even in thought.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 57_Parag: A Jew who has relations with a non-Jewish woman pollutes himself. The child he later conceives with his wife will be an apostate.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 58_Parag: A belt is a rectification for improper thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 0_Part I, 59_Parag: A person plagued by sexual fantasies can dispel them by not deceiving people, or by giving charity.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 0_Parag: When a person uses his faith to banish thoughts of idolatry, those thoughts are transformed into the aspect of “the dew of blessing.” This also results in his mind remaining firm and never becoming confused. Even when it is taxed by deep concentration on a complex subject, the Holy One provides him with thoughts that relieve his mind.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 1_Parag: A person who guards against idolatrous thoughts will always trust in God, never worrying about tomorrow. He is on the level of “Blessed is God who day after day bears our burden” (Psalms 68:20), and because of this, “[the Holy One] observed no iniquity and saw no misery in him” (Numbers 23:21). Whoever lays a hand on him, it is as if he were “harming the apple of God’s eye” (Zekhariah 2:12).
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 2_Parag: To dispel idolatrous thoughts, a person should think about and obligate himself to perform acts of kindness.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 3_Parag: Idolatrous thoughts shorten one’s breath, and he has no enjoyment from hearing good news.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 4_Parag: A person beset by idolatrous thoughts should know that he is being judged on high.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 5_Parag: Studying the Halakhic codifiers nullifies thoughts of idolatry.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 6_Parag: The appointment of unqualified judges gives rise to thoughts of idolatry.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 7_Parag: When a person is beset by idolatrous thoughts, he can expect to either suffer illness or be falsely accused by a government official.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 8_Parag: On account of idolatrous thoughts a person will eventually need to make use of God’s Holy Names.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 9_Parag: Tithing one’s wealth eliminates immoral thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 10_Para: There are times when a person finds himself thinking about a particular disease. This comes from God, so that he should remind himself to rectify the evil thought that brings on this malady.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 11_Para: Thoughts of idolatry, immorality, killing and slander beset a person who is in the habit of taking vows. However, they are eliminated when the city’s comptroller sets the appropriate amount of taxes to be collected from each inhabitant of the city.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 12_Para: A person who is afraid of immoral thoughts because of the beautiful women he sees while out in the street should recite the verse: “Behold, the mighty ones will cry outside” (Isaiah 32:7). This will save him from wandering eyes.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 13_Para: A person with idolatrous thoughts should know that the hand of the gentiles will rule over him.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 14_Para: Idolatrous thoughts abound in a city that has large markets and special shopping days. A segulah for avoiding such thoughts is to immerse oneself in Torah study on those days.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 15_Para: All a person’s sins are forgiven when he dispels thoughts of idolatry.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 16_Para: Gazing to the east eliminates immoral thoughts.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 18_Para: Idolatrous thoughts can be nullified through religious fervor.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 19_Para: Deceiving people brings one to immoral thoughts for a non-Jewish woman.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 20_Para: Whoever desires a non-Jewish woman clearly will suffer some downfall, or some illness will befall his wife and children.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 21_Para: Thoughts of idolatry enable one’s enemies to overpower him.
text.25_Improper Thoughts, 1_Part II, 22_Para: In order to dispel immoral thoughts, a person should picture in his mind his father’s image. A practical solution for preventing improper thoughts is to become angry at something, as hinted by the verse, “Become angry and do not sin...” (Psalms 4:5). (Reb Noson adds: I specifically heard from the Rebbe that the intent here is to become angry with oneself. This is alluded to in the Rabbinical teaching: “A person should always incite his good inclination against his evil inclination, as is written, ‘Become angry and do not sin...’” In other words, he should become angry with himself, but not, God forbid, real anger, which everyone knows is a most serious sin.) Also a segulah [for dispelling immoral thoughts] is uprooting oneself and going elsewhere. It is also good to jump from one’s place.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 0_: When one’s reason for instilling abundant fear in people is not for the sake of Heaven, he will not have a Torah scholar for a son.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 1_: A person who starts a mitzvah but does not complete it has his prestige diminished.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 2_: To exact punishment from the enemies of the Jewish people, God appoints unsuitable leaders to lead them.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 3_: People afford prestige to the Tzaddik’s son who does not follow in his father’s ways so that he might change for the better.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 4_: A person gains prestige when he gives charity.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 5_: A person does not attain greatness unless all his sins have first been pardoned.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 6_: Once an important person has gained prestige, it is not taken from him.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 7_: One’s wisdom, humility and geniality cause his words to be carried out on high.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 8_: When the Holy One wants a Tzaddik to gain prestige and fame, He promotes conflict and strife among the wicked.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 9_: When someone humiliates you and you accept it joyfully, you will be celebrated with honor and prestige.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 10: Whoever cannot accept rebuke does not advance.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 11: Prestige comes to a person who constantly reviews his studies.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 12: A person gains prestige by accepting rebuke.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 13: When God is with a person, he rises in stature.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 14: A change in name changes one’s fortune.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 15: When someone travels from town to town and from city to city, people don’t pay attention to what he says.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 16: Whoever favorably judges the Jewish people is rewarded with great prestige.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 17: When a person of status fears that he will have to die because the time has come for another to gain importance, he should abdicate his position, or else devise a plan causing that other person to flee from town.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 18: When people turn to someone and say, “Teach us the ways of God,” clearly his prestige will grow.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 19: A person’s fame does not grow unless the Holy One first rests His spirit upon him.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 20: A person gains prestige when, in times of trouble, he shows his trust in God.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 21: An intelligent person will certainly be quickly elevated.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 22: When the Tzaddik gains eminence, the world wonders about him.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 23: A person who despises thievery rises to greatness.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 24: It is either a person’s wisdom or his good fortune that causes him to become famous.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 25: One who receives gifts from gentiles should see it as a sign that God considers him deserving of that prestige.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 26: Reciting the Psalms raises a person’s stature.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 27: When a person gains prestige, it is as though he was just born.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 28: Mentioning the names of idols prevents a person from gaining prestige.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 29: A person gains prestige by studying Aggadah at night.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 30: Prestige comes to a person who despises falsehood.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 31: A person gains prestige by loving Tzaddikim.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 32: A person will certainly gain prestige when he serves God consciously and not out of habit.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 33: Speaking to God brings a person prestige;
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 35: Sanctifying God’s Name causes a person to gain importance.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 37: Faith enables a person to rule over haughty people.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 38: Whoever appoints an unworthy judge will eventually fall into the hands of gentile magistrates.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 39: A person merits prestige when his rebuke of others is for the sake of Heaven.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 40: By erecting a building in the Land of Israel, a person is rewarded with prestige.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 41: A person merits prestige when he honors the Torah.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 42: One cannot always exercise his authority. Certain times can come about only under another leader.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 43: Show respect for, and spend time in the presence of, a person to whom God has granted prominence.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 0_Part I, 44: A person gains prestige in opportune times.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 0: A person who trespasses the domain of another has his importance diminished.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 1: The Holy One does not grant importance to a person unless He has first tested him in some minor matter.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 2: When a person’s mind is confused, it ruins his fear of Heaven. It also causes his authority to diminish.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 3: When a person is zealous, he merits becoming a faithful leader. This is alluded to in the verse, “Go to the NeMaLaH (ant) you lazy one” (Proverbs 6:6). NeMaLaH is written with the last letters of “mi’shaM ro’eH eveNyisraeL (from then on he became a shepherd, a builder in Israel)” (Genesis 49:24).
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 4: Bribing an official in order to gain appointment in place of another person is comparable to sorcery.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 5: Thoughts of idolatry, immorality, killing and slander beset a person who is in the habit of taking vows. However, they are eliminated when the city’s comptroller sets the appropriate amount of taxes to be collected from each inhabitant of the city.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 6: Whenever a wicked person prospers, it becomes difficult to develop new logical arguments in disputed matters of Halakhah. Judges’ verdicts also become unacceptable to the litigants.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 7: A religious person must humble himself when the wicked are in control.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 8: When a person’s authority is self-appointed, his daughter will prostitute herself.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 9: When a person refrains from working for the common good and is concerned only with his own well being, it is as if he were accepting a bribe.
text.26_Prestige and Importance, 1_Part II, 1: A person who confesses his sins gains prestige.

God’s holiness validates and affirms the prominence of the generation’s leaders. This in turn brings everyone to value the mitzvah of hospitality, and the Torah scholars to merit having the law follow their opinion.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 0_P: Whoever properly tithes his wealth loses nothing.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 1_P: Attach yourself to a successful person and you will succeed.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 2_P: Blessing is found only in that which is hidden from the public eye.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 4_P: When a person whom Heaven has designated for success fails to succeed, he will afterwards find it difficult to do so.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 5_P: The endeavors of Torah scholars receive an immediate blessing.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 6_P: Torah study is a segulah for success.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 7_P: Whoever doesn’t leave over a piece of bread on his table will never see the signs of blessing.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 8_P: [Asking God for an omen that what one is about to do will succeed] is not considered divination if he mentions only the positive outcome.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 9_P: A home, a child and a wife are signs of a man’s success.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 10_: A man who divorces his wife does not prosper.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 11_: A person whom fortune favors turns proud. People tend to fear him [on account of his good fortune].
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 12_: Whoever refrains from idle chatter succeeds at everything he does.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 13_: Anyone who always speaks the truth prospers.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 14_: Confessing your sins will bring prosperity.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 15_: Prosperity comes to a person who hosts a Torah scholar at his table.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 16_: When you lack truth, your prosperity is taken away and given to the gentiles.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 17_: In order to prosper, listen as a Tzaddikperforms a unification of God’s Name by reciting the Shema Yisrael.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 0_Part I, 18_: Faith in the Sages brings prosperity.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 1_Part II, 0_: A person who is always happy succeeds.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 1_Part II, 1_: One should honor a person upon whom fortune smiles.
text.27_Success and Prosperity, 1_Part II, 2_: When a person is successful, time is his to control.
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 0_Part I, 0_Pa: Telling lies causes a woman pain in pregnancy.
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 0_Part I, 1_Pa: A woman who wants to conceive should carry a small piece of wood from the roof of the tomb built around a Tzaddik’s grave, or carry a magnet. She should also give charity.
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 0_Part I, 2_Pa: Eating small fish causes one to “be fruitful and multiply” (Genesis 1:22).
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 0_Part I, 3_Pa: Pregnant and nursing women should avoid eating garlic and onions.
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 0_Part I, 4_Pa: A woman who sees the deeds of the wicked as despicable will be blessed with a child.
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 0_Part I, 5_Pa: Accepting the hardships of exile is a segulah for conceiving a child.
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 0_Part I, 6_Pa: Eating the meat of a lean animal and drinking olive oil are a segulah for conception.
text.28_Conception; Pregnancy, 1_Part II, 0_P: A woman who cannot conceive should look at the circumcision blade after it has been used.
text.29_Instruction, 0_Paragraph: When an instructor of Torah law humbles himself before others greater than himself, the Holy One protects him from making mistakes in his instruction.
text.29_Instruction, 1_Paragraph: A courthouse of Torah law inspires the fear of God.
text.29_Instruction, 2_Paragraph: When a person’s kosher food becomes mixed with forbidden food, if the kosher food is insufficient for nullifying the prohibition, the entire mixture is rendered unkosher. This happens in order to show him that he has blemished some supernal unification, because a supernal unification is spiritually akin to nullifying the forbidden through the permitted. This is “motzeeASiRIMbaKOShaRote (He releases prisoners at the most opportune times)” (Psalms 68:7), [which can also be read as: “He removes the forbidden”—ASuRIM—through the permissible—KOSheR],
text.29_Instruction, 3_Paragraph: When there is peace in the country, the Jewish people are blessed with children who will be instructors of Torah law.
text.29_Instruction, 4_Paragraph: A rabbi who is stringent when advising others but lenient with himself, and who claims to be versed in a matter when he is not, will not merit seeing the splendor of the King. This is because the evil force of Edom—namely, improper fear—dims one’s sight and prevents him from seeing the splendor of the King’s countenance.
text.29_Instruction, 5_Paragraph: Sexual immorality leads to incarceration or pain in one’s legs. A student who, despite being unqualified, instructs others, will also be punished with one of these afflictions, and he will be placed at the mercy of harmful forces.
text.30_Confession, 0_Paragraph: On account of those who confess their sins, the Holy One provides schoolteachers who instruct faithfully.
text.30_Confession, 1_Paragraph: Confession also brings about the repairing of roads from obstacles.
text.30_Confession, 2_Paragraph: A person who confesses his sins gains prestige.
text.30_Confession, 3_Paragraph: A person who does not confess his sins will be beset by fears.
text.31_Easygoing, 0_Paragraph: When a person is easygoing, his sins cannot nullify the good that he has done.
text.32_A Fraud, 0_Paragraph: A fraudulent person is punished with incarceration.
text.32_A Fraud, 1_Paragraph: A person’s fraudulence causes him to join up with those who oppose the righteous.
text.33_Ancestral Merit, 0_Part I, 0_Paragrap: Immersion in a mikvah causes one’s ancestral merits to be recalled.
text.33_Ancestral Merit, 1_Part II, 0_Paragra: The outstanding and sharp minds of the generation cause the fear of Heaven to shine. This fear sparks the merit of ancestors, which in turn awakens the world to repentance.
text.33_Ancestral Merit, 1_Part II, 1_Paragra: At the entrance to a person’s house it can be detected whether his ancestral merit has ended or carries on.
text.33_Ancestral Merit, 1_Part II, 2_Paragra: A person whose deeds are filled with kindness has no need of ancestral merit.
text.34_Memory, 0_Paragraph: A person who embarrasses a fellow Jew becomes forgetful.
text.34_Memory, 2_Paragraph: Reciting the words while studying helps one remember them.
text.34_Memory, 4_Paragraph: Picturing the image of your father and mother will improve your memory.
text.34_Memory, 5_Paragraph: Through mitzvot that require active performance a person is freed from forgetfulness and bonded to memory.
text.34_Memory, 6_Paragraph: Sexual immorality destroys a person’s memory.
text.34_Memory, 8_Paragraph: A person with a poor memory should encourage others to return to God in repentance.
text.34_Memory, 9_Paragraph: One whose memory is weak clearly has not rectified the sins of his youth.
text.34_Memory, 10_Paragraph: A forgetful person should give charity.
text.34_Memory, 11_Paragraph: A person with a poor memory should work to achieve a high level of holiness.
text.34_Memory, 12_Paragraph: Being humble will help you improve your memory.
text.34_Memory, 14_Paragraph: A person who expresses his erudition modestly does not forget [his studies].
text.35_Elders, 0_Paragraph: Elders give strength to the Jewish people, and their advice is beneficial for us.
text.35_Elders, 1_Paragraph: The quality of a generation’s elders determines its economic well-being.
text.35_Elders, 2_Paragraph: The prestige of elders who lack wisdom comes mainly from young women.
text.36_Zealousness, 0_Paragraph: When a person is zealous, he merits becoming a faithful leader. This is alluded to in the verse, “Go to the NeMaLaH (ant) you lazy one” (Proverbs 6:6). NeMaLaH is written with the last letters of “mi’shaM ro’eH eveNyisraeL (from then on he became a shepherd, a builder in Israel)” (Genesis 49:24).
text.37_Dreams, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: After a nightmare, a person should say: “Dreams are meaningless” (Zekhariah 10:2).
text.37_Dreams, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: After a good dream, a person should rhetorically ask: “Are dreams meaningless? Is it not written, ‘I will speak to [the prophet] in a dream’” (Numbers 12:6)?
text.37_Dreams, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: When a person behaves modestly in the bathroom, his dreams have a calming effect.
text.37_Dreams, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Speaking badly about a Tzaddik who is no longer alive causes one to have disturbing dreams.
text.37_Dreams, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Disturbing dreams indicate that either a person’s son or student will disgrace himself in public.
text.37_Dreams, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person who wants his dreams to be fulfilled should record them in a notebook, including the date, time and place they occurred.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: Giving charity earns a person grace.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Grace is also a reward for humility.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: To acquire grace, welcome guests into your home.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: One should also guard against forbidden foods, and keep his mouth from forbidden speech.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person who spends his money liberally in order to acquire a teacher from whom to learn will find grace.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: One who possesses forbearance will find grace.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Olive oil is a segulah for acquiring grace.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: A segulah for grace is to write the following on a piece of parchment: כסף וזהב חסד ואמת אלוף (kesef v’zahav chesed v’emet aluph).
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Reverence for a Torah scholar earns one grace.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Words spoken calmly are accepted by those for whom they are intended.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: Certain fish are a segulah for acquiring grace.
text.38_Grace, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Studying Torah while traveling brings grace.
text.38_Grace, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: When a person moves to a new place, he should distribute meat to the poor inhabitants there. Doing so will earn him favor in the eyes of the town’s officials.
text.39_Flattery, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: Flattery brings a person to use vulgar language. The inverse is also true, [as proper language keeps one from flattery].
text.39_Flattery, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Flattery causes a person’s wife to become a widow and his children to become orphans, and yet no one will show them any mercy.
text.39_Flattery, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: A person who falls while walking in public clearly is guilty of flattery.
text.39_Flattery, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: A person who places his trust in others will turn to flattery.
text.39_Flattery, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Whoever guards against flattery finds salvation.
text.39_Flattery, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Flattering the wicked is permissible in this world.
text.39_Flattery, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: It also causes a person’s prayers to be rejected, and everyone finds him repugnant.
text.40_Philosophical Investigation, 0_Paragr: Investigating the World of Emptiness—namely, what is above and what is below, what preceded this world and what follows it—brings a curse. But guarding against such investigation brings blessing.
text.40_Philosophical Investigation, 1_Paragr: Through investigating what is above and what is below, etc., a person will experience much difficulty in earning a living.
text.40_Philosophical Investigation, 2_Paragr: A person who deeply ponders the Works of the Chariot will pass away before his time.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 0_Paragraph: The radiance that a person receives from the holiness of the Land of Israel is commensurate with the insights he originates in the Torah.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 1_Paragraph: Supportive proofs from the Torah for Rabbinical enactments bring abundant prosperity to the world. This is because there are a number of things for which we find no explicit verse in the Torah on which to base them, and the Sages labored to find some supportive reference [as proof for their enactment].
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 2_Paragraph: Original Torah insights increase the revelation of Divine providence in the world.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 3_Paragraph: When a Jew is taken captive, his aspect of the wellsprings of wisdom becomes sealed from the sages of the generation. The reverse happens when a person is freed from captivity.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 4_Paragraph: Original Torah insights bring an increase of converts.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 5_Paragraph: When a person wants to gain deeper insight into the Torah, great opposition is aroused against him and he is in grave danger. He must clothe himself in the image of the patriarch Abraham [the exemplar of lovingkindness], and so will be saved from the opposition.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 6_Paragraph: Those who would reveal original Torah insights must study the Codifiers beforehand and then again afterwards. This study of Torah law will protect their insights from foreign influences. This same procedure should also be followed when a person wants to perform some act of charity.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 7_Paragraph: Originating Torah insights arouses the giving of charity, and vice versa.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 8_Paragraph: Insights are gained into the mysteries of Creation in proportion to the insights into the Torah that are originated.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 9_Paragraph: Not all the Torah insights that a person originates may be written down. There are certain insights that are meant to be given over only verbally. One who knows which insights are to be written down and which are not also has the ability to detect the lone Jew from among a thousand gentiles.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 10_Paragraph: A person should refrain from teaching Torah at a time or in a place where it will not be appreciated. And even at a time or in a place that his words will draw the proper attention, he must be careful to say only as much as is appropriate—unlike “The fool [who] speaks everything” (Proverbs 29:11). When one says everything on his mind, his body becomes swollen with an excess of liquid in the blood. [The need for restraint can be derived from the verse,] “He makes a weight for the wind and weighs the waters by measure” (Job 28:25).
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 11_Paragraph: Through his Torah insights a person merits having a beautiful talit.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 12_Paragraph: There are times when the Tzaddik strives to achieve something, or struggles to comprehend a certain aspect of the Torah, only to later find that it has come to someone less righteous than himself, without that person having to work to achieve it. This is only because the door had already been opened [through the Tzaddik’s efforts].
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 13_Paragraph: Whenever a wicked person prospers, it becomes difficult to develop new logical arguments in disputed matters of Halakhah. Judges’ verdicts also become unacceptable to the litigants.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 14_Paragraph: People approve of a person who has satisfactorily revealed some aspect of the Torah’s reasoning.
text.41_Original Torah; Sights, 15_Paragraph: A person of little faith finds it difficult to attain Torah insights.
text.42_Marriage, 0_Paragraph: A person who has difficulty finding a marriage partner should recite “The Song at the Sea” (Exodus 15:1-19) with concentration.
text.42_Marriage, 1_Paragraph: Reciting the Sanctification of the New Moon is a segulah for finding one’s match. This is hinted at by the Hebrew word for moon—LeVaNaH—which is spelled with the first letters of “B’tulah Ni’sait L’yom Har’ve’ee (A virgin marries on the fourth day of the week)” (Ketuvot 2a; see Glossary, “B”).
text.42_Marriage, 2_Paragraph: A person gains prosperity and blessing by taking a Torah scholar as his son-in-law.
text.42_Marriage, 3_Paragraph: Taking a Torah scholar as one’s son-in-law saves a person from the punishment he deserves for giving harmful advice to a fellow Jew.
text.42_Marriage, 4_Paragraph: Taking a Torah scholar as one’s son-in-law brings to the appointment of proper judges.
text.42_Marriage, 5_Paragraph: A person who has difficulty finding a marriage partner should recite the Torah section about the Temple sacrifices brought by the princes of the twelve tribes (Numbers 7).
text.42_Marriage, 6_Paragraph: The pairing of potential marriage partners, even if only discussed and never actualized, is also from Heaven. Mere suggestion of the match has an effect on each of the potential partners.
text.42_Marriage, 7_Paragraph: The veil used to cover a bride before the ceremony carries with it a blessing for children.
text.42_Marriage, 8_Paragraph: Through prayer a person can exchange the marriage partner decreed for him in heaven.
text.42_Marriage, 9_Paragraph: When a husband and wife are careful not to share sleeping quarters with another couple, even for one night, they merit having Kohanim and prestigious individuals for sons-in-law.
text.42_Marriage, 10_Paragraph: When a widower remarries, his first wife suffers in the grave.
text.43_Nature, 0_Paragraph: A person’s physical health, lifespan and nature all follow those of his father and mother.
text.43_Nature, 1_Paragraph: An abnormally hairy person is susceptible to much harm and misfortune at the hand of the Other Side. A segulah for protection is for him to recite the Torah section read on Yom Kippur (Leviticus 16).
text.44_Wandering, 0_Paragraph: Wandering from place to place earns one a good name.
text.44_Wandering, 1_Paragraph: In general, the livelihood of God-fearing people comes as a result of their wandering and moving from place to place.
text.44_Wandering, 2_Paragraph: There are times when a Tzaddik must wander from place to place so that he can later recall all of these places when he enters the World to Come; bringing them benefit by doing so.
text.44_Wandering, 3_Paragraph: Not all places are conducive for studying Torah and performing good deeds. Because of this, God brings about circumstances that cause a person to leave one’s place and go elsewhere.
text.44_Wandering, 4_Paragraph: There are times when a person’s sins require that he suffer some form of exile, but instead [of wandering from place to place] he is beset by illness.
text.45_Purity, 0_Paragraph: A woman’s piety purifies her house from leprosy.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 0_Paragraph: Miracles are performed only for a person who is willing to sacrifice himself to sanctify God’s Name.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 1_Paragraph: A person who rejoices in his suffering brings salvation.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 2_Paragraph: Hitbodedut, private conversation with God, brings salvation.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 3_Paragraph: Miracles are performed for a person who has undergone a test.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 5_Paragraph: Modesty restores to a person all the good that another person has taken from him through prayer.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 6_Paragraph: Miracles are not performed for an immoral person.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 7_Paragraph: Do not rely on a miracle as long as it is possible to save yourself by using money or some other means.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 8_Paragraph: Before God performs a miracle for a person, he first falls upon hard times—the extent of which is determined by the magnitude of the miracle.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 9_Paragraph: God does favors for a person who does not allow the names of idolatry to pass his lips.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 10_Paragraph: A person in need of some salvation should bring joy to the Tzaddik.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 11_Paragraph: Through trust in God one is spared from suffering.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 12_Paragraph: Giving charity frees you from having to rely on a human being for help.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 13_Paragraph: Trust in God enables you to understand that your salvation is from Him, and not from any human being.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 14_Paragraph: Truthfulness also enables you to realize this.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 15_Paragraph: When a person finds himself being tested, he should know that if he withstands the test God will perform a miracle for his sake.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 16_Paragraph: By trusting in God one merits rejoicing in His lovingkindness.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 17_Paragraph: Standing while studying Torah overturns the machinations of the gentiles
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 18_Paragraph: Fasting saves a person from death.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 19_Paragraph: Trust in God and He will reward you with lovingkindness.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 21_Paragraph: A person who prays joyously will merit rejoicing in His salvation.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 22_Paragraph: Miracles are the result of truth.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 23_Paragraph: Miracles are the result of the fear of God.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 24_Paragraph: The Holy One will save anyone who teaches God’s ways in public, even if he is among gentiles.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 25_Paragraph: Whoever prays all day long is rewarded with salvation.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 26_Paragraph: When Jews speak truthfully, they are blessed with lovingkindness from heaven.
text.46_Salvation and Miracles, 27_Paragraph: Singing the songs particular to a gentile nation arouses God to investigate that nation, to see why they are persecuting you.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who does not consider himself clever can become God-fearing.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Whoever is close to an elder and endures his wrath is rewarded with the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: When a person is given the opportunity to perform an act of kindness and fails to carry it out, his fear of God diminishes.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Whoever keeps his conversing to a minimum merits fearing God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: All the words a person speaks in order to convince a fellow Jew to be God-fearing are transformed into a holy book.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: The words of a God-fearing person are heeded.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Crying over a devout person’s death is as important as the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: The fear of God brings a person more than his mazal would dictate. The inverse is also true, [as a lack of fear will diminish his good fortune].
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Attending to the needs of the Tzaddikim brings one to fear God. The inverse is also true, [as not assisting the Tzaddikim diminishes one’s fear].
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Humility leads to the fear of sin.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Reward for the fear of God lasts a thousand generations.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: A person who leaves neither a son nor a student is said to be lacking the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Wearing a head covering leads to the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: When people bless each other by saying, “May you be like so and so,” clearly that individual fears God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: One who is God-fearing is able to break another person’s haughtiness.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: He draws the Divine Presence into the world.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: [One’s fear of God] brings him humility,
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: and no one can lure him away [from God].
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: The Holy One performs miracles for a person who always cleaves to the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: A person who constantly binds himself to the fear of God and is always conscious of Him is forgiven for all his sins.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: A person who is God-fearing will certainly listen to the Tzaddikim.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: He will also attain trust in God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: Those who fear God, He rewards with peace.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: A person who lacks the fear of God does not follow in His ways.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: Through fear of God one attains truth.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: A God-fearing person never falls from his spiritual level, but consistently advances.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: When a person has the wisdom of God in his heart, people revere him.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: When something happens that frightens everyone, the God-fearing person remains unafraid. He even sees this thing as a reason to rejoice.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: A God-fearing person will certainly humble himself before the Tzaddik.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 29_Paragraph: Haughtiness prevents a person from fearing God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: To acquire the fear of God, go to the mikvah.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: By sanctifying God’s Name you will come to fear Him.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: A person’s sins remove the fear of God from him.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: Whoever does not think about the day of death consequently has no fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: When a person’s fear of God diminishes, clearly he is being judged on high.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: By giving gifts to the Tzaddikim one is rewarded with God-fearingness.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: Immersing in a mikvah 310 times is a segulah for achieving the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: The desire that a person shows for performing a mitzvah indicates that he is God-fearing.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Fear of God and acts of kindness save one from fire and bring him his livelihood.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: A courthouse of Torah law inspires the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Studying the Shuchan Arukh brings one to the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: The outstanding and sharp minds of the generation cause the fear of Heaven to shine. This fear sparks the merit of ancestors, which in turn awakens the world to repentance.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: An individual has the ability to throw off the yoke of Heaven; a community does not.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: Hearing the voice of one who is wise in holiness is a segulah for acquiring the fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: Confusion of the mind destroys one’s fear of God. It also diminishes his authority.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: Charging usury decreases one’s fear of God.
text.47_Fear of God, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: Those close to God-fearing people will also merit the fear of God and daat.
text.48_Distinguished Ancestry, 0_Paragraph: A curse has no effect on a person of distinguished ancestry.
text.48_Distinguished Ancestry, 1_Paragraph: Even if she herself is righteous, a woman lacking distinguished lineage might have indecent children.
text.48_Distinguished Ancestry, 2_Paragraph: God cannot easily overlook or nullify the advantage of distinguished ancestry.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 0_Paragr: In order to keep a person from serving God he is given honor and prestige to preoccupy him.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 1_Paragr: Whoever speaks against the Tzaddik will eventually be viewed disparagingly by all.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 2_Paragr: A person who belittles himself daily is rewarded. His name is never forgotten from people’s lips and they name their children after him.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 3_Paragr: Reciting Tikkun Chatzot is a segulah for gaining respect.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 4_Paragr: A person through whom God’s honor is elevated gains fame.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 5_Paragr: Whoever shows disrespect for the Tzaddikim falls ill.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 6_Paragr: Hugging a Torah scroll is a segulah for gaining respect.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 8_Paragr: There are times when a person receives respect and prestige in the merit of a member of his household.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 9_Paragr: A person who says, “I have not sinned,” is viewed by everyone with contempt.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 10_Parag: Most of the embarrassment that a person suffers is on account of the sins of his youth.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 11_Parag: An unquenchable thirst is a sign of diminished honor.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 12_Parag: Whoever saves a Torah scroll from being destroyed is rewarded with honor.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 13_Parag: The words of a prestigious person are fulfilled.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 14_Parag: When you show respect for a person, honor his attendant as well.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 15_Parag: When dead bodies are exhumed, clearly the Holy One intended to disgrace the living, but an exchange has taken place.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 16_Parag: Whoever transgresses the instructions of the Tzaddik has his prestige diminished.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 17_Parag: Running after glory brings thoughts of idolatry.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 18_Parag: An important person need not be disgraced, even though he is wicked.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 19_Parag: One must show respect for the leader of a country even if he worships idolatry.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 20_Parag: The respect a person shows for the Torah saves him from his enemies.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 21_Parag: The covertness of a miracle is its glory.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 22_Parag: A person who is disgraced clearly has a penchant for falsehood.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 23_Parag: A person’s clothing brings him respect.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 24_Parag: Honor is connected to the soul.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 25_Parag: Honor is dependent upon what the heart desires.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 26_Parag: A person who is persecuted will be rewarded with prestige in this world.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 27_Parag: When a person visits the sick, everyone wants to share in his glory.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 0_Part I, 28_Parag: A person who gains glory at a fellow Jew’s expense will not merit having a holy book bear his name.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 1_Part II, 0_Parag: People who show each other respect clearly are devout individuals. The inverse is also true, [as disrespecting one another indicates their lack of devoutness].
text.49_Honor and Respect, 1_Part II, 1_Parag: The glory of all the different nations is encompassed in the Four Empires (Babylon, Persia, Greece and Rome). Through the Menorah, the new moon, the Temple incense-offering and guarding against impure foods, the Four Empires are made to return the glory to God.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 1_Part II, 2_Parag: Going out to greet an important person summons forth the Ten Statements through which the world was created. Bringing Jews who are distant from God closer to Him does this as well.
text.49_Honor and Respect, 1_Part II, 3_Parag: Honor the person upon whom fortune smiles.
text.50_Anger, 0_Paragraph: When a person keeps from getting angry, his enemies will have no control over him.
text.50_Anger, 1_Paragraph: He will reside in his own home, and no one will replace him.
text.50_Anger, 2_Paragraph: A person’s anger brings him disgrace.
text.50_Anger, 3_Paragraph: Avoid becoming enraged and you will not sin.
text.50_Anger, 4_Paragraph: Anyone who gets angry loses his wisdom and foresight. Even if he is destined for greatness, he loses that as well.
text.50_Anger, 5_Paragraph: The Holy One loves a person who keeps from getting angry, and also one who does not insist on retribution.
text.50_Anger, 6_Paragraph: The life of a hot-blooded person is no life at all.
text.50_Anger, 7_Paragraph: All the punishments of hell rule over him,
text.50_Anger, 8_Paragraph: as do the evil forces of the lower worlds.
text.50_Anger, 9_Paragraph: [A hot-blooded person] has no regard for the Divine Presence.
text.50_Anger, 12_Paragraph: Clearly, his sins outweigh his merits.
text.50_Anger, 13_Paragraph: Getting angry after eating is physically very harmful.
text.50_Anger, 14_Paragraph: A woman’s anger destroys her home.
text.50_Anger, 15_Paragraph: A person who loses his temper humiliates himself.
text.50_Anger, 16_Paragraph: Eating bread for breakfast is a segulah for controlling anger.
text.50_Anger, 17_Paragraph: A person who does not complain about others gains people’s respect.
text.50_Anger, 19_Paragraph: An angry person should take a vow and immediately fulfill it. This will eliminate his anger.
text.50_Anger, 20_Paragraph: Whoever looks into the face of a liar loses control of his temper.
text.50_Anger, 22_Paragraph: When a person gets angry, he incites harsh judgments against himself.
text.50_Anger, 23_Paragraph: Getting angry causes one to have foolish children.
text.50_Anger, 25_Paragraph: A segulah for eliminating anger is to make a haughty person suffer a downfall.
text.50_Anger, 26_Paragraph: When you are devoid of any anger, you can humble the haughty by merely staring at them.
text.50_Anger, 27_Paragraph: An angry person clearly covets honor, and all his good deeds are only for self-glorification.
text.50_Anger, 28_Paragraph: When a person gets angry at a pauper whom others respect, it is as if he provoked the Holy One.
text.50_Anger, 31_Paragraph: A person who breaks his angry nature earns himself a good name.
text.50_Anger, 32_Paragraph: There are times when a person gets angry as a result of bearing a heavy load.
text.50_Anger, 34_Paragraph: [Even though hitbodedut is a very good thing,] improper seclusion leads to anger.
text.50_Anger, 35_Paragraph: Where there is strictness there is no peace.
text.50_Anger, 36_Paragraph: Eating helps a person dismiss anger.
text.50_Anger, 37_Paragraph: Guard yourself against anger, particularly on a day you have been saved from some misfortune.
text.50_Anger, 39_Paragraph: Anger causes a woman to have difficulty in childbirth.
