text.50_Anger, 40_Paragraph: Anger causes a person to become frightened.
text.51_Sorcery, 0_Paragraph: Children born through the use of unholy names or sorcery will be guilty of immorality.
text.51_Sorcery, 1_Paragraph: Whoever makes use of unholy names will be harmed by everything [around him].
text.51_Sorcery, 2_Paragraph: Witchcraft can harm only the haughty.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who brings his father pleasure and happiness will have a desire and love for learning.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: If you want the Torah that you teach to be inspirational, don’t expound on evil topics, but on those verses and topics that speak of good.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: A person who teaches new insights into the Torah causes the Holy One to rejoice.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: You should know that when a wicked person teaches Torah, he corrupts those who listen to his words.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Whoever interrupts a fellow Jew’s Torah study clearly has turned away from God’s path.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: It is good to study Torah, even when half asleep.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: A person who accepts suffering with love will not forget his studies.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Whatever a person studied but failed to fully comprehend in this world, he will merit understanding its true meaning in the World to Come.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Those who stand in honor of a Torah sage merit [the wisdom of] Torah.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: All knowledge of the Torah’s precepts—whether of the commandments between a man and his fellow man, or those between a man and his Maker—the very knowledge itself is beneficial for the soul.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: A holy book that was written with ink containing olive oil is especially beneficial for study.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: Fear of a Torah scholar is especially beneficial for study.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: When one studies Torah at night, the Divine Presence stands by his side.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: What should a person do to acquire wisdom? Let him increase his study, limit his business activities, and ask for God’s compassion. One without the others is not enough.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Reciting the words of Torah in a loud voice instills feeling and motion into all a person’s limbs.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: One who studies in a loud voice is blessed with long life and his studies remain with him.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: Whoever has no haughtiness retains his studies.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: This is also true of one who teaches others.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: A person benefits most when he hears his studies directly from a teacher.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: The study of Torah is even greater than offering the daily-sacrifice.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: By saying “This teaching is pleasing and that one is not,” one loses out on the Torah’s treasures.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: It is easier to learn something new than to recover what one has forgotten.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: Whoever [willfully] forgets a single detail of his studies causes his children to be exiled and has his prestige diminished.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: A Torah scholar whose inside is not like his outside is considered an abomination.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: Those who live in the same town as a Torah scholar are responsible for seeing to his needs.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: When Torah study is lax, God, figuratively speaking, becomes poor.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: Torah study is even greater than saving lives, than building the Holy Temple, and than honoring one’s parents.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: There are three things over which God cries each day, one of which is a person who has the ability to study Torah but does not.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: It is forbidden to teach the wonders of God to a wicked person.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: Only a great person may learn from a wicked individual; others may not.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: Diligent study surpasses the fulfillment of even all the mitzvot.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: Whoever has no wife has no good [namely, Torah].
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: That which a person studies on his own cannot match that which he learns from a teacher.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: The Holy One takes no pleasure from the Jews being judged unfavorably.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: When a person feels love for a Torah scholar, the Torah returns that love to him and his descendants.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: A person should study Torah even without understanding.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: Seeing your teacher’s mouth while he teaches is very beneficial.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: Studying by the side of a river is very beneficial.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: When a person studies Torah at night, it is as if he performed the Temple service.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 41_Paragraph: When one studies the laws of the Temple service, it is as if the Holy Sanctuary was built in his lifetime.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: Whoever teaches Torah to an improper student descends into hell, and it is as if he worshiped idols.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: The Torah itself was given to all Jews, but engaging in polemical analysis of Torah law was given to Moses alone, and he benevolently passed this privilege on to all of Israel.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: When a person makes himself available for teaching Torah to anyone [who wishes to learn it], the Torah is given to him as a gift.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: The Torah endures only with one who “stands naked” [of all he has] for its sake, or who makes himself as if he knows nothing.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 46_Paragraph: Study is a prerequisite for attaining the fear of sin, and the fear of sin is a prerequisite for analytical Torah study.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: By eating bread for breakfast a person retains his studies and merits both studying and teaching Torah.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: Torah study must be verbal. That which one studies in thought alone is forgotten and does not lead to actual practice.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: One who studies but does not review his studies is like a person who plants but does not reap.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: When a person reviews his learning, the Torah itself asks God to reveal its reasoning and secrets to him.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 51_Paragraph: Whoever doesn’t have set times for Torah study will be bothered by immoral thoughts.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 52_Paragraph: Whoever fails to review his studies will find it difficult to raise his children.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 53_Paragraph: A person who studies Torah for its own sake brings peace to the hosts of angels above and below, and protects the entire world with his merit. It is as if he built a palace in both worlds, and he hastens the Final Redemption.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 54_Paragraph: Whoever teaches Torah to the son of a fellow Jew, Scripture says that it is as if he created the child, created the words of Torah, and also created himself.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 55_Paragraph: When one blackens his face in this world {for the sake of Torah}, the Holy One causes his face to shine in the World to Come.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 56_Paragraph: When one denies himself the pleasures of this world for the sake of Torah, God rewards him with great contentment in the World to Come.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 57_Paragraph: A person who reads the books of heretics is called an apostate.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 58_Paragraph: One who recites a Torah verse at the right time brings good to the world.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 59_Paragraph: Given a choice between two verses, one that you can interpret as speaking favorably and positively, and one that you can interpret as saying the opposite, you should choose to expound the former.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 60_Paragraph: A person who cannot understand his studies should spend time in the company of the Tzaddik. This will also enable him to study Torah for its own sake. Alternatively, he should endeavor to please the Tzaddik in some way, or he should study with joy, or greet the Shabbat with joy, or greet the Tzaddik with joy.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 61_Paragraph: Analytical study of the Torah enables one to pray.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 62_Paragraph: A person who has numerous obstacles interfering with his Torah study should refrain from drinking alcohol.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 63_Paragraph: Laxity in Torah brings one to laxity in prayer. The inverse is also true, [as diligence in Torah brings diligence in prayer].
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 64_Paragraph: A person who has no time for study other than on Shabbat and the new moon still manages to restrain the spirit of impurity [through the Torah he does study].
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 65_Paragraph: A person who cannot understand his Torah studies clearly has been beset by harsh judgments.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 66_Paragraph: It is easier for a person to understand a complex Torah subject when he is on a mountain or some other high place.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 67_Paragraph: Waking up early to study Torah is a segulah for repairing one’s hearing.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 68_Paragraph: Teaching Torah to schoolchildren promotes peace.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 69_Paragraph: One should pray to be worthy of proper students.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 70_Paragraph: Expounding the Torah positively enables a person to bring salvation.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 71_Paragraph: A person’s bigheartedness gives him the ability to deduce one thing from another.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 72_Paragraph: A person who has no desire to study Torah study should never say anything bad about anyone.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 73_Paragraph: Learn only from a person who is God-fearing.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 74_Paragraph: Through Torah study you will be rewarded with peace.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 75_Paragraph: When the Torah you teach is consistent with your level, and not above it, the Holy One carries out your wishes.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 76_Paragraph: Heresy destroys a person’s desire for learning.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 77_Paragraph: By giving charity for the sake of Heaven, you will merit studying Torah for the sake of Heaven.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 78_Paragraph: By waking up from sleep to recite Tikkun Chatzot a person merits understanding the Torah and expounding its meaning.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 79_Paragraph: Whoever has neglected Torah study for idleness and nonsense should rectify this by waking up for Tikkun Chatzot.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 80_Paragraph: Whoever despises falsehood like he would despise an abomination will have a desire to study Torah.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 81_Paragraph: Don’t study from a book that a wicked person studied from, because the letters themselves will turn you to evil.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 82_Paragraph: When you hear a person teaching Torah or ethics and yet gain no respect for him, it is an indication that he is a fool.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 83_Paragraph: When you pay a price for a Torah insight, you won’t forget it.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 84_Paragraph: When a person chases after his heart’s desires, each and every Torah verse can be interpreted as alluding to his shame.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 85_Paragraph: Whoever separates himself from the path of Torah attaches himself to Satan.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 86_Paragraph: When two Torah scholars show mutual respect and humbly dispute Halakhah for its own sake, the Holy One sees to it that they are successful and gain prestige. They merit Torah, which was given with the “right hand,” and are rewarded with those things that emanate from the Torah’s “right side.”
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 87_Paragraph: A Torah scholar is as vindictive as a snake. Attach yourself to him so that eventually you will derive benefit from his learning.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 88_Paragraph: It is forbidden to learn from someone who draws people to idolatry. One who learns from him deserves death.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 89_Paragraph: Torah without mitzvot is like a myrtle branch, which has a good smell but no taste.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 90_Paragraph: With whom will you find the various branches of Torah? With a person who arrives early to the study hall and stays late in order to study them, and who on their account resembles a raven, blackening his face [with deprivation] and bringing himself to be unpitying with his children.
text.52_Torah Study, 0_Part I, 91_Paragraph: A person cannot successfully learn from everyone. This is the reason people travel great distances in order to study.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: There are afflictions that one suffers whose appointed time is determined by the astronomical factors that require those afflictions. However, the will and yearning aroused in the students at the time set for them to go and learn Torah from their teacher nullifies these afflictions before their appointed time.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Studying Torah, giving tithes, and observing Shabbat provide material benefits as well.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Studying the Shulchan Arukh brings one to fear God.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: When a person studies Torah with pure thoughts, so that he eats with such holiness that he is nourished by the sustenance of the angels, his enemies are sentenced to strangulation. This is alluded to [by the verses], “And it was on the third day, in the morning...” (Exodus 19:16); “then in the morning there was a layer of dew” (Exodus 16:13); “And it was at the morning watch...” (Exodus 14:24; see above, Eating B:5).
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: The outstanding and sharp minds of the generation cause the fear of Heaven to shine. This fear sparks the merit of ancestors, which in turn awakens the world to repentance.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: Studying Halakhic codifiers nullifies thoughts of idolatry.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: Going from one teacher to the next requires that a person strengthen his faith in the unity of God. Learning from many teachers detracts from belief in His Oneness. Nevertheless, the teacher who has faith in His Oneness is able to enlighten each and every student according to his ability, as each student hears only that which is necessary for him and no more.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: The teacher who teaches his students in a way that allows each one to hear only that which he needs to know—no less and no more—merits producing students who reveal the finest and choicest aspects of the Torah.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: When a student hears a Torah lesson from his teacher and finds his will negated to that of his mentor’s, he can be certain that he has truly heard the teaching. For if his will was not negated, then, even if he heard—he did not hear. Another way for him to determine if he truly heard is if he experienced a total negation of self while listening [as the lesson was being given].
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: At the time a student comes to hear a Torah lesson from his teacher, the kelipot created by the student’s evil also come along to listen and draw sustenance [from the holiness]. But, as a result of each student hearing only that which applies to his soul, the kelipot flee and are thus prevented from hearing the lesson. There is, however, one semi-refined kelipah that is very close to holiness and flees only when the lesson includes an instance of Jewish salvation. Then it, too, runs away. This is alluded to in, “And Moses sent away his father-in-law” (Exodus 18:27); according to the opinion that Jethro [personifying the evil force that is very close to holiness] came and left before the Torah was given.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 10_Paragraph: Verbally reciting the words of Torah saves one from punishment by stoning.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 11_Paragraph: Not all places are conducive for studying Torah and performing good deeds. Because of this, God brings about circumstances that cause a person to leave one place and go elsewhere.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 12_Paragraph: When a person labors in Torah study to the point of exhaustion, he mitigates harsh judgments and awakens mercy, even for his father who has passed away.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 13_Paragraph: Torah brings to faith, and faith brings to sanctifying the Name of God.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 14_Paragraph: Those with clear vision can tell who a person’s Torah teacher is merely by looking at him, provided they already know what his teacher looks like. When a student learns the Torah’s laws from his teacher, his face takes on a resemblance to the one teaching him. This is because Halakhah is the wisdom that makes a person’s face shine (cf. Ecclesiastes 8:1). By receiving the law, he receives a portion of his appearance, their resemblance increasing with each additional law the student receives.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 15_Paragraph: God’s holiness validates and affirms the prominence of the generation’s leaders. This in turn brings everyone to value the mitzvah of hospitality, and the Torah scholars to merit having the law follow their opinion.
text.52_Torah Study, 1_Part II, 16_Paragraph: A rabbi who is stringent when advising others but lenient with himself, and who claims to be versed in a matter when he is not, will not merit seeing the splendor of the King. This is because the evil force of Edom—namely, improper fear—dims one’s sight and prevents him from seeing the splendor of the King’s countenance.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: When a person is guilty of slander, the Holy One says to the ministering angel of hell, “I [will judge him] from above and you from below.” His rectification is to engage in Torah study and humble himself. This will also keep him from slandering further.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Slandering others increases the measure of one’s guilt equivalent to the three cardinal sins (idolatry, immorality and murder).
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Speaking negatively about a person in his presence, or in the company of three other people, is not considered slander.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Although words of slander should not be accepted, one has to be wary [that they may be true].
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Whoever speaks badly of the Jewish people will in the end suffer from a diseased mouth.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: When there is no love among Jews, they gossip about each other, and then turn scornful on account of their talebearing.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: When there is love between fellow Jews, one is permitted to tell the other something that he heard from a third party. The one who hears it can accept what he was told without being guilty of accepting slander.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: A person guilty of slander loses his desire for Torah study and also shames the Tzaddik.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Truth saves one from slandering others.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Guarding against slander keeps one from plotting evil against his fellow Jews.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Whoever refuses to accept slander about the Tzaddik merits being counted among the righteous.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: Haughtiness leads a person to speak disparagingly of others.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: One does not speak slander unless he has first been guilty of denying the Holy One. He thus sins against God and man.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: It is permissible to speak slanderously of a person who instigates strife and conflict.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: A person guilty of giving a fellow Jew a bad name is never pardoned.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: A person guilty of slander cannot receive the Divine Presence.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: Both the one who speaks slander and the one who accepts it deserve to be thrown to the dogs.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: Reciting the Torah section on the Temple incense-offering (Exodus 30:34-38) is a rectification for slander.
text.53_Slander, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: A person guilty of slander will be afflicted with leprosy. His crime is so great, that it reaches the heavens and he deserves to be stoned.
text.53_Slander, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person guilty of slander will suffer imprisonment.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 0_Paragraph: A person’s derisiveness causes him to have many accusers exercising control over him. He will also be guilty of immoral behavior, and have a domineering wife.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 1_Paragraph: Being derisive causes a person to lose prestige. He also turns to falsehood, and strays from place to place.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 4_Paragraph: A derisive person has no wisdom.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 5_Paragraph: A person’s derisiveness causes him to be detested by God and man.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 7_Paragraph: A person who ridicules the words of the Sages will burn in hell.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 8_Paragraph: All mockery is forbidden other than that which is directed at idolatry.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 9_Paragraph: [The punishment for] derision and mockery is most severe: beginning with suffering and ending with destruction.
text.54_Derision and Mockery, 10_Paragraph: A derisive person has his livelihood diminished. He is destined for hell and his mockery brings destruction to the world.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 0_Para: Victory in battle cannot be achieved when an oath has been broken.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 1_Para: When anyone persecutes a fellow Jew, God brings evil upon him so that he forgets that other person and stops persecuting him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 2_Para: By reciting the Hallel prayer, the Holy One will save you from your enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 3_Para: The respect a person shows for the Torah saves him from his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 4_Para: Praying to God is a necessary preparation for battle.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 5_Para: Any time a person falls from faith, the opposition he brings upon himself comes from an individual of importance and wealth.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 6_Para: A person who prays for help against his enemies should do so in the morning hours.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 7_Para: Repeatedly gazing heavenward will nullify your enemies’ hatred.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 8_Para: When a person forgets the poor, he cannot be victorious.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 9_Para: You should know that when a wicked person persecutes a pauper, it is because of the pauper’s pride.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 10_Par: God ignores a contentious person and hides His face from him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 11_Par: When a person suffers misfortune, his enemies are exalted.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 13_Par: A person invites conflict when he has the opportunity to perform some mitzvah, but lets it pass unfulfilled.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 14_Par: One who quarrels with the Tzaddikim clearly has entertained evil thoughts.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 15_Par: There are times when it is one’s location that causes him to encounter conflict and strife.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 16_Par: Whoever has enemies should humble himself, and this will cause God to save him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 17_Par: A person with enemies can rid himself of them by seeking every way possible to show them affection.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 18_Par: When a person does not seek revenge against his enemies, but instead focuses on rejoicing in God, the Holy One gives him the strength to avenge their wickedness.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 19_Par: Immoral people tend to be in conflict with the Tzaddikim.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 20_Par: A person’s humility causes him not to fear in battle, as if he was sitting inside a fortress.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 21_Par: A contentious person will be afflicted with incurable diseases.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 22_Par: When litigants turn to a gentile magistrate to adjudicate their dispute, the Holy One afflicts them with an incurable disease.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 23_Par: There are times when the Holy One hardens the hearts of the wicked against the Tzaddikim so that the wicked suffer a downfall.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 24_Par: Whoever honors an elderly sage is saved from war.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 25_Par: Whoever tells God of his strife merits seeing his revenge exacted against his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 27_Par: A person who quarrels with his fellow Jews will in the end be an object of scorn for his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 28_Par: One who hears himself shamed and remains silent is considered righteous, and the Holy One will protect his soul.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 29_Par: When a person prays with such great fervor that it can be detected on his face, his enemies are defeated and set ablaze.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 30_Par: A person who has been good and upright from his youth wins the hearts of many. They will lend him their support in any quarrel or conflict against him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 31_Par: Whoever leads a fellow Jew astray and prevents him from following the path of good will not be able to overcome his enemies in battle.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 32_Par: By confessing your sins, the evil plans of your enemies will be nullified.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 33_Par: A quarrelsome person clearly favors sin.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 34_Par: A person who is sparing with his words cannot be overcome by anyone.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 35_Par: Those who quarrel with the righteous and want to prevent them from serving God will suffer defeat and be repugnant to themselves.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 36_Par: To be victorious in battle, recite Psalm 6, “upon the sheminit-instrument.”
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 37_Par: When a person visits the sick, God does not hand him over to his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 38_Par: Whoever has enemies should spend his entire day reciting prayers and entreaties, without stopping. As a result, God will save him, and his enemies will be disgraced.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 39_Par: A person who is persecuted is rewarded with children and grandchildren.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 40_Par: A person with enemies should ask numerous people to pray for God to show him mercy. This will bring him peace from his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 41_Par: When you have enemies below, clearly you also have enemies on high.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 42_Par: The study of Torah turns away one’s enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 43_Par: By trusting in God, your enemies will not be able to harm you.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 44_Par: By being humble, your enemies will fall into the trap that they set for you.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 45_Par: When a person prays all day, disgrace will come to his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 46_Par: Whoever brings harm to an enemy of a Tzaddik merits always being victorious.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 47_Par: When people talk against you, study Aggadah nightly.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 48_Par: Two Tzaddikim cannot live harmoniously in the same city unless they both possess truth.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 49_Par: When a person trusts in God, his enemies will never rejoice in his suffering.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 50_Par: When one never embarrasses a fellow Jew, his enemies will never rejoice [in victory] over him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 51_Par: The hatred of many enemies is clearly unjustified, since it is impossible for all of them to be avenged.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 52_Par: When a person has enemies and then one of his friends and confidants also turns against him, it is a sign that those opposing him will fail and suffer defeat.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 53_Par: Whoever has faith has no fear of enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 54_Par: Crying out in prayer prevents one’s enemies from rejoicing [in victory] over him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 55_Par: A person with enemies who is uncertain whether he will fall into their hands should look inward. If he has fallen from his level of serving God, he can be certain that he is destined for defeat.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 56_Par: To guard against conflict, study the tractate Sukkah.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 57_Par: When the wicked come together, quarrel ensues.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 58_Par: When you are depressed, even your loved ones turn against you.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 59_Par: Strife is not found in a person’s home until the food runs out.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 60_Par: There are times when God will side with a group of Tzaddikim in their dispute against a single Tzaddik. Even if the truth is with the lone Tzaddik, the Tzaddikim draw God’s favor to them.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 61_Par: [Charging usury for lending money to a fellow Jew is considered wicked.] The borrower may then call him wicked, and is permitted to cut into his means of income, diminishing it by up to a third.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 62_Par: A person would rather die than have no friends and loved ones.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 63_Par: All things are created male and female, even kings. There are kings who embody the male aspect, and kings who embody the female aspect. They Holy One distances one from the other so that they do not [come together and] destroy the world.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 64_Par: Do not honor a contentious person, even if he is an accomplished Torah scholar.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 65_Par: Satan is found wherever there is conflict and dispute.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 66_Par: A person who fulfills the obligation to recite Shema Yisrael morning and evening will not be handed over to his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 67_Par: When a person studies Torah and performs acts of kindness, his enemies suffer defeat at his hands.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 68_Par: The persecution that a person suffers transforms him into a fitting sacrifice for God.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 69_Par: Always side with the oppressed and help them.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 70_Par: The world exists only in the merit of a person who seals his mouth in a time of dispute.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 71_Par: When a person forgets a single detail of his studies, opposition rises up against him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 72_Par: Quarreling with a Tzaddik leads to an outbreak of war.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 73_Par: When people talk against a person, the evil inclination is able to overpower him. He must ask for God’s compassion regarding this.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 74_Par: A person who is difficult to appease is from the Feminine World.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 75_Par: When confronted by conflict, you should arrive early to the study hall and stay late in order to study Torah. If this is not possible, then through prayer you can bring judgment upon your oppressors and God will see to their downfall. You must never hand them over to a government official.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 76_Par: When a person has the right to take revenge against a fellow Jew but instead remains silent, the Holy One makes certain that he sees justice.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 77_Par: Don’t argue with someone stronger than yourself, even if he forces you to do something improper. If, however, that person is afraid of a government official, report him to that official rather than doing that which is improper.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 78_Par: Slander causes a person to fall in battle.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 79_Par: Whoever refrains from speaking slander will be victorious.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 80_Par: Studying Torah and then stopping causes one’s enemies to persecute him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 81_Par: When one’s wife experiences a show of blood outside her menstrual period, clearly some animosity has been aroused against him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 82_Par: Wherever possible, the Tzaddik should use money rather than his righteousness as a means for overcoming his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 83_Par: All participants in a quarrel have in them sparks from the souls of Datan and Aviram, [the two men who repeatedly sought to foment strife against Moses].
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 84_Par: When two Tzaddikim are at odds over an issue concerning the good of the Jewish people, you should know that there are two corresponding angels in heaven that also dispute the matter. It takes God Himself to arbitrate between them.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 85_Par: Whoever hears himself shamed and remains silent eliminates many of the evils that were meant for him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 86_Par: God consistently sides with the majority opinion. But if the majority is comprised of wicked individuals, His opinion does not follow theirs.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 87_Par: We do not seek merit in one who turns others astray.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 88_Par: When two people disagree, each is often supported by others who side with his point of view. Should there then be a decree in heaven that one of those involved in the dispute must die, the judgment begins with the least of them and not with one of the original disputants.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 89_Par: There are times when being handed over to one’s enemies saves a person from a decree that would have destroyed all his offspring.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 90_Par: When one person causes another to distance himself from serving God, his offspring will suffer at the hands of the other’s descendants.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 91_Par: When a person is in a position to protest against the actions of the wicked but does not, it is as if he himself was guilty of their evil deeds.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 92_Par: Whoever takes part in a quarrel transgresses a prohibitive commandment of the Torah and deserves to be punished with leprosy.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 93_Par: Whoever disputes the royal lineage of the house of David deserves to be bitten by a snake.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 94_Par: Torah study enables one to remain firm in combat.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 95_Par: A person should take courage against his enemies and use cunning in battling them. God will then do as He sees fit.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 96_Par: A segulah when encountering conflict is to recite the verse: “And Asa cried out to God, his Lord, and said ‘It is nothing for You to help, whether the many or those who have no power. O God, our Lord, help us for we rely on You and in Your Name we go against the multitude’” (2 Chronicles 14:10).
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 97_Par: A person who does not trust in his God invites battles and conflicts.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 98_Par: Studying Torah instills fear into the nations so that they refrain from waging war against the Jews.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 99_Par: When encountering conflict, recite the words of Yehoshafat, “And he said, ‘God, Lord of my fathers...for our eyes are turned to You’” (2 Chronicles 20:6-12).
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 100_Pa: In a time of war one must prepare arms, as is common practice, and not rely on a miracle. The Holy One will then do as He pleases.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 101_Pa: When a person chooses a fixed place for prayer, he defeats his enemies.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 102_Pa: Never pray that a person die, even an apostate. It is better that he be killed by the hand of man than through Heaven’s intervention.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 103_Pa: Never provoke a wicked person, especially one upon whom fortune smiles.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 104_Pa: It is permitted to disavow the truth and even dispute it in order to keep the world from being led astray by a wicked person.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 105_Pa: Unwarranted hatred brings great strife and conflict into a person’s home.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 106_Pa: The postponement, distortion or corruption of justice bring to destruction and much pillaging, as does neglecting the study of Torah.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 107_Pa: When a woman at the end of her menstruation period passes in between two men, it causes them to quarrel.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 108_Pa: Pacifying one’s persecutor arouses harsh judgment against him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 0_Part I, 109_Pa: Giving one’s enemies food to eat causes them to be sentenced to punishment by fire.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 0_Par: Those who talk against the Tzaddik bring to increased [interest in] heretical philosophy in the world. The inverse is also true, [as speaking positively of the Tzaddik decreases the study of heretical philosophy].
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 1_Par: There are certain well-known people whose fame comes mainly as a result of conflict and dispute.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 2_Par: A person involved in dispute succumbs to immoral desires.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 3_Par: Whoever defends his faith against many people who argue against him, countering them with convincing arguments, will, because of this, be worthy of many children. His progeny will fill the world.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 4_Par: One who is always scrutinizing the leaders of his generation and examining their behavior with an eye to finding fault will suffer from hunger. “Not a hunger for food” (Amos 8:11), but the hunger of the future, [a hunger for the word of God]. Thus the Hebrew word for hunger, רעב, is formed by placing an ע (ayin, which also means “eye”) between the letters רב (“rabbi” or “leader”).
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 5_Par: By giving charity, a person can defeat his enemies through minimal means [and effort], as God will save him from even their greatest means [and effort].
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 6_Par: Reciting Grace after Meals causes God’s greatness to become known in the world. Grace after Meals also brings the government tranquility from conflict and war.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 7_Par: When a person studies Torah with pure thoughts, so that he eats with such holiness that he is nourished by the sustenance of the angels, his enemies are sentenced to strangulation. This is alluded to [by the verses], “And it was on the third day, in the morning...” (Exodus 19:16); “then in the morning there was a layer of dew” (ibid. 16:13); “And it was at the morning watch...” (ibid. 14:24). (I heard this explanation from the Rebbe’s holy mouth: ‘“And it was on the third day, in the morning’ was said during the Giving of the Torah and refers to a person who studies Torah with pure thoughts. ‘Then in the morning there was a layer of dew’ was said about the manna, the food from which the angels draw sustenance, as our Sages taught (see Yoma 75b). ‘And it was at the morning watch’ was said at the splitting of the Red Sea, when the Egyptians were drowned, which is an aspect of strangulation, as our Sages taught (see Ketuvot 30b).” Rebbe Nachman learned from one “morning” and applied it to the other, thereby deriving the above {insight} from the Torah.)
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 8_Par: The affliction and provocation that a sage suffers cause him to forget his learning.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 9_Par: As a result of quarreling, the less qualified students are accepted into positions of authority prematurely. This corresponds to a miscarriage, to a child being born too early. It leads to poverty and sometimes even death, God forbid.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 10_Pa: Sometimes there is no peace in one’s home and all one’s family members are at odds with each other. Clearly, this is because there are evil forces in the house, and as a result his family suffers.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 11_Pa: A person’s location can at times be the cause of the strife he encounters. This is similarly the reason one does not ask after the well-being of a fellow Jew in an unclean place.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 12_Pa: Grief and depression lead to conflict, whereas joy brings peace to the world.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 13_Pa: The Torah is revealed through peace.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 14_Pa: If, while fasting, a person expends his energy on work or business, it saves him from enemies and murderers.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 15_Pa: Whoever has enemies finds it difficult to concentrate while praying.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 16_Pa: A person who causes a rift between husband and wife—talking to the husband about how beautiful his wife is, and telling the wife degrading things about her husband—will, because of his actions, find it difficult to earn a living.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 17_Pa: When God sees that a certain Tzaddik has the ability to inspire people to devotional service, He stirs up opposition against him. God does this so that the Tzaddik will indeed succeed in inspiring others, which a Tzaddik without enemies cannot do. This can be likened to the times of Mashiach, when people will be at peace and coverts will no longer be accepted.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 18_Pa: Thoughts of idolatry enable one’s enemies to overcome him.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 19_Pa: One whose enemies are elevated succumbs to a lust for food.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 20_Pa: A person whose body itches should realize that he has enemies. Sometimes, the abrasions and scratches he makes on his body [in attempting to relieve the itching] will save him from his enemies; this being in exchange for that.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 21_Pa: There are two types of Tzaddikim: one whose words are the aspect of plowing, and one whose words are the aspect of reaping. Said otherwise, one Tzaddik’s speech corresponds to the male arousal for marital relations, while the other’s corresponds to drawing the seed into the womb, and fetal conception and gestation. Therefore, when there is a quarrel between these two Tzaddikim, an outsider should not meddle in their verbal exchanges, so as not to ruin the deeper intention.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 22_Pa: A person with enemies should take an oath not to drink wine. This will give him mastery over them.
text.55_Conflict and Strife, 1_Part II, 23_Pa: A segulah for a person hoping to be saved from his enemies, whether they are opponents in a dispute or highwaymen whom he fears, is to recite the cantillations that accompany the words of the Torah: pashta, munach, zarka, etc.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: When a person is derisive of others, his livelihood diminishes.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: The words of the Sages bring wealth.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: One’s wealth does not last if he shows no compassion for others.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Whoever withstands a test of his morality merits great wealth in the midst of his enemies.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: An occupation is a great thing; God Himself cautioned mankind to engage in some form of work.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: [Nevertheless, if one has no choice, he should] borrow in order to eat.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: [A farmer] who wants to grow wealthy should plow with a lean animal.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: A person should spend less than what his income allows for food and drink, clothe himself in accordance with his means, and honor his wife and children by spending on them beyond what he can afford.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Poverty in one’s home is worse than fifty plagues.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: A man’s wife won’t die unless he is first approached for money and has none to give.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: The ability that the nations have to steal from the Jews comes from their learning TaNaKh.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Whoever possesses daat will in the end be wealthy.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: One who steals from his fellow Jews is made impure by a chance seminal emission.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: A new insight that comes to a person clearly will be followed by great wealth.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: As soon as the money of a Jew falls into the hands of a gentile it is instantly purged [of the special quality it acquires from Jewish ownership].
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: A person whose children are starving is spared from death by fire, one of the four judicial forms of capital punishment.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: Whoever transgresses a Rabbinical enactment becomes poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: Whoever breaks his desire for food merits beautiful dwellings.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: Providing a person with his livelihood is as difficult [a miracle] as splitting the Red Sea. It is even more difficult than bringing the Final Redemption, and twice as difficult as [the miracle of] childbirth.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: Once a person has been put in charge of the public’s welfare, he becomes wealthy.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: The incense-offering brought wealth [to the one who burnt it in the Temple].
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: You need not worry that someone will interfere with your livelihood. Against his will he will call you by name for you to take what is rightfully yours.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: There are four things that cause a man of means to lose his wealth: delaying to pay his workers’ salaries; outright refusal to pay their wages; shirking an obligation and instead placing the burden on someone else; and a haughty spirit.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: A change of place and a change of name improve one’s livelihood.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: Rain is withheld only because of the following: ceasing to tithe the Holy Land’s produce, speaking slander, arrogance, disrupting Torah study, and the crime of theft.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: Rainfall can be restored through many prayers.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: When there is satiation in the world, sickness is diminished.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 29_Paragraph: Rain is held back only because of those who publicly pledge to charity but don’t give.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: Disgusting behavior in one’s home leads to poverty.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: Three things bring a person to poverty: urinating in the nude in one’s bedroom, taking lightly the requirement to wash one’s hands before eating, and a man’s wife cursing him to his face.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: Tithing is a segulah for wealth specifically in the Land of Israel.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: Honoring the Torah and honoring Shabbat are a segulah for wealth.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: The olive-size helping of bitter herbs eaten on Passover is a segulah for earning a living.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: Writing a Torah scroll is a segulah for earning a living.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: When the daughter of a Kohen marries a regular Jew (Israelite), or when the daughter of a Torah scholar marries a boor, she causes her husband to become poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: Associating with someone upon whom fortune smiles is beneficial for one’s own prosperity.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: A person who loves God in his eating, drinking and other physical pleasures merits sustaining many nations.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: One who despises money merits long life.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: A person who searches for treasures hastens his own death.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 41_Paragraph: Whoever has not rectified the sins of his youth becomes poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: A person who struggles day and night to make a living but still does not have enough can rectify this by bringing people closer to God.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: Whoever accidentally breaks something clearly has sinned.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: Someone with an unquenchable desire to work the land is certainly worthless.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: In whatever you do, ask the Tzaddik to pray on your behalf.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 46_Paragraph: Constant joy is a segulah for success.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: Earning a living requires strengthened effort.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: Whoever makes the Name of Heaven a partner in his distress [by asking for God’s mercy] has his livelihood doubled, and it comes flying into his hands like a bird.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: For the sin of not tithing the Holy Land’s produce, wages are lost and people’s pursuit of livelihood is without success.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: The rains come for the sake of an individual; livelihood, for the sake of the many. But an individual whose merit is powerful is reckoned as the many.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 51_Paragraph: Sanctifying [Shabbat and the Festivals by reciting the blessing] over wine brings rain and causes one’s prayers to be heard.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 52_Paragraph: Whoever keeps in his house a Torah scroll that belonged to his father is rewarded with wealth.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 53_Paragraph: Rain falls in the merit of a single man, a single field and a single blade of grass; as well as in the merit of the land, kind deeds, and because of suffering.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 54_Paragraph: Rainfall is withheld because of idolatry, immorality, because a Tzaddik has not been properly eulogized, and because people interfere with the livelihood of others.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 55_Paragraph: One who suffers poverty is spared the punishment of hell.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 56_Paragraph: Misusing God’s Holy Names brings poverty and death, even to anyone who has the ability to protest their misuse but does not.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 57_Paragraph: The Holy One exacts judgment on behalf of anyone who has a complaint concerning his livelihood against a fellow Jew and is nevertheless silent.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 58_Paragraph: When a person sees that his livelihood is limited, he should give charity.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 59_Paragraph: Worry and distress over one’s livelihood sap a person’s strength.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 61_Paragraph: A Tzaddik who has no mazal when it comes to earning a living will sometimes have opponents sent against him. He is then given the income that was coming to them.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 62_Paragraph: One who works in construction puts himself in danger.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 63_Paragraph: Modest behavior is a segulah for wealth.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 64_Paragraph: Once coveting and envy spread in the world, people began interfering with each other’s livelihood.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 65_Paragraph: A person’s livelihood diminishes when he judges others unfavorably,
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 67_Paragraph: or follows the advice of someone who persuades others to turn against God.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 68_Paragraph: When one sins out of spite, he becomes impoverished, yet no one will believe that he is poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 69_Paragraph: One who makes use of unholy names and sorcery becomes poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 70_Paragraph: When consumption, a disease that weakens the body, affects a member of one’s family, it is a sign of impending poverty.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 71_Paragraph: When a person suffers some embarrassment, it is a sign that he will soon become poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 72_Paragraph: Whoever despises money is shown by Heaven the path that he should follow.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 73_Paragraph: There are times when death by excision at the hand of Heaven is replaced by impoverishment.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 74_Paragraph: A poor person is confused, like a drunkard.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 75_Paragraph: Fraudulent practices cause one to become poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 76_Paragraph: Anyone who acts hastily, without presence of mind, falls into debt.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 77_Paragraph: Interfering with one’s means of income is akin to killing him.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 78_Paragraph: A person should always hold onto his ancestral inheritance, never selling or exchanging it.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 79_Paragraph: One who lusts for money falls from his spiritual level.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 81_Paragraph: A person who is poor should work diligently to provide sustenance for those who seek God.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 83_Paragraph: Pain of the eyes is a sign of poverty.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 84_Paragraph: By being humble, a person livestock multiplies.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 85_Paragraph: By giving charity, a person is rewarded with livelihood.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 86_Paragraph: When a person gives money to sorcerers, his livelihood will require him to work in the homes of non-Jews.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 87_Paragraph: The words of the Tzaddik bring livelihood.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 89_Paragraph: Giving charity will alleviate your financial restraints.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 90_Paragraph: Too much sleep makes one poor.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 91_Paragraph: One who is diligent in Torah study and giving charity merits wealth.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 92_Paragraph: Honor your wife and you will become rich.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 93_Paragraph: Blessing is found in a person’s house only because of the honor he has shown his wife.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 94_Paragraph: When a person charges usury for lending money, his financial worth plummets and never recovers.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 95_Paragraph: Forbidding the singing of frivolous songs lowers prices.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 96_Paragraph: A person without a living should occupy himself with Torah study and then pray for livelihood. His prayers will certainly be accepted.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 97_Paragraph: One should never sell the first property he purchased.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 98_Paragraph: Whoever deprives a fellow Jew of income is considered wicked.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 99_Paragraph: Were it not that he has grown haughty, no Jew would have the audacity to harm a fellow Jew’s livelihood.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 101_Paragraph: Wealth is a masculine principle, whereas poverty is feminine principle.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 102_Paragraph: Pain of the eyes {teeth} is a sign of impending harm to one’s livelihood.
text.56_Money, 0_Part I, 103_Paragraph: Whatever one wants, whether it is wisdom, or wealth, or children, he should strive to attain it through natural means, and plead for mercy that these means prove successful.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: When the year is one of economic prosperity, it augurs physical health.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Whoever has an unquenchable desire to work the land will come to one of three things: either shedding innocent blood, or leprosy, or drunkenness.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Fearing God and acting kindly to others saves one from being harmed by fire, and he merits earning a living.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: A decline in adherence to legal rulings based on the Torah causes a decrease in livelihood. The inverse is also true, [as an increase in adherence to Torah law brings an increase in income].
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Supportive proofs from the Torah for Rabbinical enactments bring abundant prosperity to the world. This is because there are a number of things for which we find no explicit verse in the Torah on which to base them, and the Sages labored to find some supportive reference [as proof for their enactment].
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: The Holy One will at times boast to Satan about a righteous gentile. This is so that God can then provide the Jews with livelihood without any opposition.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: When a person yearns to be buried in the Land of Israel, he is blessed with abundant livelihood.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: A person should expend energy on [the preparations for] a meal to be held in honor of some mitzvah, even chopping firewood. While chopping, he should have in mind that he is breaking apart and separating the bad from the good in the Tree of Knowledge. By doing so, he merits earning a living.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: By returning to God in repentance, one earns his living easily.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: One who fulfills “Your neighbor’s money should be as precious to you as your own” (Avot 2:12) merits praying with an attentive heart.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 10_Paragraph: Living from the fruits of one’s own labor is so great, that one who does so recognizes God’s glory in a way that even the angels cannot.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 11_Paragraph: The changes that take place in the angels—sometimes they are sitting and at other times standing, sometimes they appear as women and at other times as men, as well as all the other changes—are mirrored by the changes that take place in the flow of blessing that descends from heaven. Sometimes the blessings appear as fire, at other times as water, or as stone, or as any of the other forms. All of these changes affect both the world and man. A person’s will also alternates according to these changes, so that at times he wants one thing and at other times he wants something else.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 12_Paragraph: One’s livelihood is in accordance with [the holiness of] one’s marital relations.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 13_Paragraph: The economic prosperity of a generation is in accordance with its elders.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 14_Paragraph: Charging usury causes one to lose his fear of God.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 15_Paragraph: One who charges usury for lending money will not find anyone willing to speak favorably of him.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 16_Paragraph: A person who is careful not to transgress the prohibition against coveting will be saved from anger and haughtiness, and from the lack of faith that results from these two evil traits.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 17_Paragraph: Conducting one’s business affairs faithfully nullifies curses.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 18_Paragraph: One who is obliged to borrow from others is comparable to an animal.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 19_Paragraph: When the agent of someone important cannot convince an ordinary person to sell some object to his client, he should pray that the ordinary person accept the offer and agree to the sale.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 20_Paragraph: When a person controls his evil inclination, his children do not follow evil ways. Because of this his money is plentiful, and consequently he will not come to be tested.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 21_Paragraph: Being on the road brings a person to slander, idolatry, immorality and bloodshed. And these sins diminish one’s livelihood.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 22_Paragraph: The charity a person gives to the poor of the Land of Israel causes him to prosper monetarily.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 23_Paragraph: Fires rage in the world in order to consume the wealth associated with idolatry.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 24_Paragraph: When a new king or minister takes over, people’s livelihood is renewed and changes.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 25_Paragraph: When a person’s livelihood comes from the business he does with gentiles during their holiday season, or even at other times of the year but involves his doing something that strengthens the worship of idolatry, his wife’s menstrual flow will begin soon after her ritual immersion.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 26_Paragraph: A person who causes a rift between husband and wife—talking to the husband about how beautiful his wife is, and telling the wife degrading things about her husband—will, because of his actions, find it difficult to earn a living.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 27_Paragraph: A person is sometimes spared having to rend his garment in mourning because his merchandise and property are spread out and not located in one area.
text.56_Money, 1_Part II, 28_Paragraph: The most successful businessman of a town is the light of the town.
text.57_Miscarriage, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: Fear causes a woman to miscarry.
text.57_Miscarriage, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: A segulah for a woman who miscarries is for her to carry magnets. She should also carry a small piece of wood from the tomb of a Tzaddik, and give charity.
text.57_Miscarriage, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: A woman who miscarries should carry around [melted] dew.
text.57_Miscarriage, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: A segulah against further miscarriages is for a woman to sell her embryo.
text.57_Miscarriage, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: The sin of unwarranted hatred causes a woman to miscarry.
text.57_Miscarriage, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: A woman’s craving for food and drink causes her to miscarry.
text.57_Miscarriage, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A woman with a history of miscarriages should refrain from wearing gold jewelry.
text.57_Miscarriage, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Grinding flour and kneading dough for Passover matzah is a segulah for a woman who miscarries.
text.58_An Informer, 0_Paragraph: Whoever informs against a fellow Jew to the authorities will in the end become a vagabond, have many opponents, and suffer that which he intended to bring upon that other person. Anyone connected with this informer will fall away, and whatever importance he may have had will be taken from him by the family of the wronged party.
text.58_An Informer, 1_Paragraph: Whoever informs against the Tzaddik to the authorities loses his material possessions.
text.58_An Informer, 3_Paragraph: It is forbidden to hand over even a wicked person to be killed.
text.59_Alcohol, 0_Paragraph: When a person steals, his alcohol goes bad.
text.59_Alcohol, 1_Paragraph: This also happens to one who is haughty.
text.60_The Messiah, 0_Paragraph: Telling stories about the Tzaddikim draws the light of Mashiach into the world. It also dispels much darkness and pain from the world. And the teller is rewarded with beautiful clothing.
text.60_The Messiah, 1_Paragraph: Returning to God in repentance causes the spirit of Mashiach to blow against the evil decrees of the government and nullify them completely.
text.60_The Messiah, 2_Paragraph: There will yet be a generation in the world that is entirely righteous.
text.60_The Messiah, 3_Paragraph: Truth hastens the End of Days.
text.60_The Messiah, 4_Paragraph: By keeping Shabbat a person draws upon himself the light of Mashiach. Repentance also has this power.
text.61_A Circumciser, 0_Paragraph: One should seek out a mohel who is both righteous and God-fearing. For when the mohel lacks expertise, the circumcision can, God forbid, cause the infant to be sterile, or an epileptic.
text.61_A Circumciser, 1_Paragraph: A woman who cannot conceive should look at the circumcision blade after it has been used.
text.61_A Circumciser, 2_Paragraph: A mohel infuses the child he circumcises with understanding in Torah.
text.61_A Circumciser, 3_Paragraph: The mitzvah of circumcision has the same powers as the special clothing worn by the high priest.
text.61_A Circumciser, 4_Paragraph: Whoever is born circumcised clearly has a good and wholesome imagination.
text.61_A Circumciser, 5_Paragraph: When a person performs an act of kindness, the name he gives to another has permanence. It is therefore advisable to carry out some charitable deed before naming a newborn baby, thereby ensuring that the name will be everlasting.
text.62_Fame, 0_Paragraph: There are certain famous people whose fame comes mainly as a result of their participating in some conflict.
text.62_Fame, 1_Paragraph: God tests a person in order to then grant him importance and fame.
text.62_Fame, 2_Paragraph: As a result of quarreling, the less qualified students are accepted into positions of authority prematurely. This corresponds to a miscarriage, to a child being born too early. It leads to poverty and sometimes even death, God forbid.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 0_Paragra: A man’s thoughts for a non-Jewish woman prevent his sons from becoming Torah scholars.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 1_Paragra: A woman’s mazal is consistent with her husband’s mazal.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 2_Paragra: Children conceived in a beautiful home will be beautiful and wholesome in appearance.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 3_Paragra: Having sexual relations with a non-Jewess is like intermarrying.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 5_Paragra: When the daughter of a Kohen marries a regular Jew (Israelite), or when the daughter of a Torah scholar marries a boor, the marriage will not go well. She will either be widowed or divorced or childless. He will bury her or she will bury him, or else she will bring him to poverty and shame.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 6_Paragra: It is particularly repugnant when an old man behaves immorally. In the end, he will come to look upon himself with disgust.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 7_Paragra: There are seven who are like outcasts, one of them being a man who has no wife.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 8_Paragra: A person can distance himself from lustful desire only by distancing the desire from his eyes and thoughts.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 9_Paragra: Don’t enter into arguments and counter-arguments with temptation. Allowing an immoral thought to linger in the mind, even in order to reject it, strengthens its attraction and wins one over to it.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 10_Paragr: Most immoral behavior is brought on by drunkenness.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 11_Paragr: Without a wife, a man is not a man. It is almost as if he is guilty of shedding innocent blood and diminishing the Divine Image.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 12_Paragr: A man who causes his wife grief by neglecting her conjugal rights will be punished with death.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 13_Paragr: It sometimes happens that after a couple gets engaged, one of them dies. This is because they were an unsuitable match.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 14_Paragr: When a man marries a woman who was divorced by her first husband because of her wickedness, she will bury him.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 15_Paragr: A woman’s licentiousness destroys the home.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 16_Paragr: A man who commits adultery causes his wife to dream of impure things.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 17_Paragr: When a man marries a woman for the sake of Heaven, it is as if he gave birth to her.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 18_Paragr: Couples whose marital relations are devoid of holiness are punished by fire.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 19_Paragr: Whoever has an opportunity to sin but refrains will have a miracle performed for his sake.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 20_Paragr: When a man marries a woman who is unsuitable for him, it is as if he plowed up the entire earth and planted salt. When the Holy One will rest His Divine Presence upon the Jewish people, confirming the members of each tribe, that man will be left out.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 21_Paragr: Violating the brit is equivalent to violating all the mitzvot.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 22_Paragr: Wearing pants atones for the sins of incest.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 23_Paragr: Where there is immorality, the Tzaddikim fall from stature.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 24_Paragr: By mourning the death of Tzaddikim, one is able to break his love for women.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 25_Paragr: By masturbating, a man creates evil forces that clothe themselves in people who oppose and argue with him and cause him suffering.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 26_Paragr: A person guilty of adultery will eventually be guilty of shedding innocent blood.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 27_Paragr: Whoever rids the world of adulterers rectifies the sins of his ancestors.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 28_Paragr: Whoever desires to guard the sign of the brit will always tell the truth and act kindly even with someone from whom he expects nothing in return.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 29_Paragr: Anyone guilty of blemishing the brit should make amends by pursuing peace.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 30_Paragr: Contentiousness brings a person to blemishing the brit.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 31_Paragr: Immoral thoughts come as a result of [what in Kabbalistic terminology is known as] breaking the vessel of lovingkindness. The amount of immoral thoughts that ensue corresponds to the amount of “sparks” [that fall when the vessel is broken].
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 32_Paragr: A person guilty of transgressing the prohibition against homosexual practices will suffer imprisonment.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 34_Paragr: The child conceived at a time when a husband feels hatred for his wife will turn into an apostate.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 35_Paragr: Immoral behavior leads one to be exiled under the rule of derisive rulers. He also falls into debt.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 36_Paragr: Mashiach will come in the merit of the women having guarded against immorality. At that time, people will not be dependent upon each other [for sustenance], and the glory of the righteous will increase.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 37_Paragr: Unholy divination and sorcery lead to immorality.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 38_Paragr: A man who has relations with a non-Jewess transfers all blessing over to the Other Side.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 40_Paragr: The way to make amends for wasting seed is by striving to bring people back to God in repentance.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 41_Paragr: The Holy One grants merit to a person who guards the brit, even if he has no ancestral merit.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 42_Paragr: {43 Immoral thoughts come from a lack of faith.}
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 43_Paragr: The sins of sorcery and immorality cause the Tzaddik to be taken from the world.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 44_Paragr: Children born from adultery will have need of sorcery.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 45_Paragr: Children born through the use of sorcery will be immoral.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 46_Paragr: Most of those guilty of immoral behavior are opponents of the Tzaddikim.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 47_Paragr: Masturbating is like sacrificing one’s children to idolatry. Such a person is sentenced to stoning.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 48_Paragr: Immoral behavior causes one to lose his memory.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 49_Paragr: Immoral behavior causes one to lose his feelings of shame.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 51_Paragr: A person who sins will afterwards feel remorse because of the holy spark within him. The exception is someone who defiles the brit. He feels no remorse afterwards, because the holy spark has already left him.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 52_Paragr: Whoever keeps from defiling the brit keeps his memory sound.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 53_Paragr: Swearing falsely brings to immoral thoughts.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 54_Paragr: Whoever stands as a guarantor for a wicked individual turns to immorality.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 0_Part I, 55_Paragr: Whoever destroys his seed becomes penniless.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 0_Paragr: Sexual immorality leads to incarceration or pain in one’s legs. A student who, despite being unqualified, instructs others, will also be punished with one of these afflictions, and he will be placed at the mercy of harmful forces.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 1_Paragr: Quarreling causes one to succumb to immoral desires.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 2_Paragr: Marital relations with one’s wife on days when it is prohibited causes a person to be imprisoned.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 3_Paragr: Immoral desires cause constipation, which in turn brings leprosy.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 4_Paragr: Doing favors for others removes one’s lustful desires. The inverse is also true, [as failing to do favors for others brings on those desires].
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 5_Paragr: Whoever guards the brit is the source of blessing [for the entire world].
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 6_Paragr: Whoever guards the brit merits understanding the seventy languages hidden in the Torah.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 7_Paragr: It is forbidden to find merit in those guilty of homosexuality.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 8_Paragr: One’s livelihood is in accordance with [the holiness of] one’s marital relations.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 9_Paragr: When a person is idle, doing nothing constructive, his sexual desires increase and he constantly speaks of filthy matters.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 10_Parag: Whoever guards the brit is permitted to rejoice when seeing his enemies defeated.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 11_Parag: Blemishing the brit brings to the dangers associated with traveling, as hinted in the verse, “You have measured my going about and my lying down [and You are acquainted with all my ways”] (Psalms 139:3).
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 12_Parag: A woman who is the object of a sexual advance, even if nothing comes of it, is affected by the suggestion itself.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 13_Parag: Anyone who closes his eyes so as not to look at evil saves himself from humiliation.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 15_Parag: Promiscuous behavior with gentiles leads to apostasy.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 16_Parag: The daughter of a person whose authority is self-appointed will prostitute herself.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 17_Parag: Most account-keepers are filled with lustful desires.
text.63_Immoral Behavior, 1_Part II, 18_Parag: Whoever refrains from staring at women is rewarded with offspring who will author commentaries on the Torah.
text.64_Menstruation, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A woman with an abnormally heavy menstrual flow will talk a lot. [To lessen the flow], she should refrain from appearing beautiful in public, bathe in spring water, and not overly exert herself—and her husband should perform the mitzvah of hand-washing meticulously. She should also avoid getting angry, and give charity after her ritual immersion—and her husband should study the tractate Nidah and afterwards recite the daily psalm [sung in the Holy Temple]. And she should wash herself with things brought up from the river’s depth, drink goat’s milk, scrub herself with [a brush of] goat’s hair when bathing, and perfume herself with frankincense.
text.64_Menstruation, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: A woman whose menstrual flow is heavy should write down the words 10) לא אחד echod), [from the verse (Job 14:4), “Who can bring the pure from the impure? Lo echod (not one)”] and carry it around with her.
text.64_Menstruation, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: When a woman is promiscuous, her menstrual cycle becomes irregular and she experiences an abnormally heavy flow.
text.64_Menstruation, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: When a woman’s menstrual period is begun by an unexpected show of blood, it is because of a sin that her husband has committed.
text.64_Menstruation, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A woman who has no menstrual cycle should fast.
text.64_Menstruation, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Hospitality is a segulah for restoring a woman’s menses.
text.64_Menstruation, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: When a person’s livelihood comes from the business he does with gentiles during their holiday season, or even at other times of the year but involves his doing something that strengthens the worship of idolatry, his wife’s menstrual flow will begin soon after her ritual immersion.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: In some cases a person falls from his level when he reaches old age.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: When one is appointed to be a tax collector, he falls from his level.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Jealousy causes one to fall from his level.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: A person’s jealousy keeps him from progressing steadily. At times he is able to pray fervently and study diligently, while at other times prayer and Torah study are a heavy burden for him.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: One who blunders with his words, and certainly one who is unable to express them with his usual fluency, clearly will see his livelihood diminish. He is in need of much lovingkindness and salvation in order for God to provide him with livelihood.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: One makes his yearning for something evident through an oath.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: When a person stumbles and falls, it is because he feels secure in his sinful behavior.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: When you wholeheartedly begin performing some mitzvah, you will complete it unharmed.
