text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: One who falls from his fear of God clearly lacked pure fear [in the first place].
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: A person’s lust for money causes him to fall from his level.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Guarding against stealing, swearing and falsehood will keep you from falling from your level.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: When a person prays in a congregation that also includes some wicked individuals, they sometimes bring him down. A segulah for preventing this is to raise one’s hands heavenward while praying.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: A person loses his religious fervor because he despises the Tzaddik.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: The Tzaddik who guides people truthfully will not fall from his importance.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Anyone who receives honor despite his attempts to flee from honor will certainly not descend or fall from prominence.
text.65_A Fall, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: By attaching oneself to the Tzaddikim a person ensures that he will not fall from his level.
text.65_A Fall, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person falls while walking because his guardian angels have left him.
text.65_A Fall, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Whoever desires a non-Jewish woman clearly will suffer some downfall,
text.65_A Fall, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: or some illness will befall his wife and children.
text.66_Obscene Language, 0_Paragraph: Whoever speaks obscenities clearly has been thinking sinful thoughts.
text.66_Obscene Language, 2_Paragraph: Because of the sin of obscene language, suffering and harsh decrees are renewed; the young men of Israel die, God forbid; and orphans and widows cry out, but are not answered.
text.66_Obscene Language, 3_Paragraph: Even a signed verdict for seventy years of good life is turned to evil when one uses obscenities. The bowels of hell are also deepened for him. This fate also awaits a person who hears [obscenities spoken] but remains silent.
text.66_Obscene Language, 4_Paragraph: Speaking obscenities is even worse than carrying out the act.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 0_: Even though the money that a Tzaddik receives from an evil individual might be stolen money, the Tzaddik is permitted to accept it. This is so that this individual does not find himself some wicked scholar to call a Tzaddik, give him the money, and then oppose the true Tzaddik.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 1_: Once it became common practice to take gifts from others, the human lifespan grew shorter.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 2_: Never embarrass a person who has once done you a favor.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 3_: One who employs a heavy hand in exercising authority over the Jewish people will eventually become dependent upon others.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 4_: A person who works for the good of the people may benefit from them, and they should assist him.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 5_: By accepting favors from a fellow Jew you will share in his suffering for his sins.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 6_: One who refuses to accept money from others will merit raising all his children.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 7_: A king may collect his expenses from the people.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 8_: A person should work at some means of livelihood so that he will not in the end be forced to terminate his Torah study.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 9_: It is like stealing when one outright requests the reward he deserves.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 10: The entire world turns dark for one who envies another’s possessions. His life is no life at all.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 0_Part I, 11: Only one with a neshamah can derive pleasure from the sense of smell.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 1_Part II, 0: The labor of one’s own hands is so great that it saves a person from murder.
text.67_Benefitting from Others, 1_Part II, 1: Whoever despises gifts has no fear of being libeled.
text.68_Song, 0_Paragraph: When the fame of the Tzaddikim spreads in the world, new songs are composed.
text.68_Song, 1_Paragraph: The Levites had a particular song for each day of the week. Nowadays, being in exile, we no longer remember these tunes. Yet whenever some tragedy befalls any nation, it revives the particular tune of the Levites that countered this misfortune.
text.68_Song, 2_Paragraph: Tunes that contain the sound of weeping have the ability to free captives, as in, “Motzee asirim bakosharote (He releases prisoners at the most opportune times)” (Psalms 68:7). [The word bakosharote can be read as a compound of be’khy and sheerote—weeping and songs].
text.68_Song, 3_Paragraph: From the songs a person sings one can tell if he has dedicated himself to Torah study.
text.68_Song, 4_Paragraph: Drinking rouses a person to sing and play musical instruments, whereas eating does not. This is because [in the wilderness] the Jewish people sang the praise of God over the well, but not over the manna.
text.69_A Test, 0_Paragraph: God tests a person in order to then grant him importance and fame.
text.69_A Test, 1_Paragraph: When a person wants to inspire others to serve God, but lacks the requisite level of righteousness and has no ancestral merit, he should avoid being tested. He should particularly keep from arousing the jealousy of the wicked.
text.69_A Test, 2_Paragraph: When a person controls his evil inclination, his children do not follow evil ways. Because of this his money is plentiful, and consequently he will not come to be tested.
text.70_An Eternal Flame, 0_Paragraph: In reward for keeping a flame of olive oil burning constantly, people are spared from a decree of forced conversion.
text.71_Counting the Omer, 0_Paragraph: Counting the Omer saves one from being banished.
text.71_Counting the Omer, 1_Paragraph: During the weeks of Counting the Omer it is all the more important to immerse in a mikvah after a seminal emission.
text.71_Counting the Omer, 2_Paragraph: Through counting the Omer it is possible to overcome an informer. This is alluded to by the word L’OMeR, which is an acronym for “Me’igra Rama L’hira O’mikta (from a high place down to a deep pit).”
text.72_Mysteries, 0_Paragraph: By deeply studying the Torah’s mysteries one can bring barren women to bear children and also heal serious disease.
text.73_A Holy Book, 0_Paragraph: When a person who is capable of authoring some holy work refrains from doing so, it is as if he remains childless.
text.73_A Holy Book, 1_Paragraph: Those who author holy works should carefully weigh the contents of their work to see that there is sufficient material for a book. For the value of any book comes only from those parts that were written through a “binding of souls,” as in, “This is the book of the lineage of man” (Genesis 5:1). If but a minimum of the book was written through such binding, it is not worthy of publication.
text.73_A Holy Book, 2_Paragraph: Those with insight are able to determine by looking into a holy book whether its original Torah teachings are solely the insights of the author, or they already existed, having been originated by another, but were insufficient for forming an entire work. [If it is the latter,] then the original ideas were revealed to this author so that he might bring them into print. Yet the truth is that he did not work for these insights, which came to him easily because someone else had already labored over them and brought them to light.
text.73_A Holy Book, 3_Paragraph: When a new book is printed, the crying it took to produce it—which is the aspect of “and mixed my drink with crying” (Psalms 102:10)—defeats the nations’ evil decrees and keeps them from overcoming us. Indeed, the essential strength of their rule stems only from the time Esau cried [when Jacob took his blessing]. This is alluded to in the verse, “And thus mispar h’nai yisrael k’chol hayam (the number of the Jewish people will be like the grains of sand in the sea)” (Hosea 2:1). [The word mispar can also be read mi’sepher, from a holy book; and the first letters of B’nai Yisrael K’chol Hayam spell B’KhiYaH, crying],
text.73_A Holy Book, 4_Paragraph: Whoever refrains from staring at women is rewarded with offspring who will author commentaries on the Torah.
text.73_A Holy Book, 5_Paragraph: It is actually beneficial for the world that many holy books written by righteous authors, including the Mishnaic Sages and other early Tzaddikim, have been lost and forgotten from the world. Their disappearance causes many books by apostates and heretics to be uprooted and erased from existence. The elimination of those holy works also eliminates any jealousy or enmity that exists between a husband and wife who conduct themselves with holiness.
text.73_A Holy Book, 6_Paragraph: When a great book appears in the world, it causes barren women to be remembered by God. This is alluded to in the verse, “This is the book of the lineage of man” (Genesis 5:1).
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 0_Paragraph: The feathers of birds of prey are a segulah for curing diseased lungs and for strengthening one’s life force.
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 1_Paragraph: The heavens change their appearance to match the different colors of the grasses that grow because of them. It is a segulah to stare at these colors.
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 2_Paragraph: Rainwater is a segulah for one who lacks virility.
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 3_Paragraph: Reciting Psalms is a segulah for bringing rain. [We learn this from the Hebrew word for Psalms], TeHiLiM, which is an acronym for “Limtar Hashamayim Tishteh Mayim ([the Land of Israel] drinks water from the rain of heaven)” (Deuteronomy 11:11).
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 4_Paragraph: Hospitality is a segulah for restoring a woman’s menses.
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 5_Paragraph: An abnormally hairy person is susceptible to much harm and misfortune at the hand of the Other Side. A segulah is for him to recite the Torah section read on Yom Kippur (Leviticus 16).
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 6_Paragraph: A person who suddenly loses his ability to speak should have a knife fit for ritual slaughtering passed over his mouth.
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 7_Paragraph: A segulah for eliminating the difficulty a woman has in childbirth is to hang the cemetery key around her neck. This key is also a segulah for healing barrenness.
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 8_Paragraph: Crying over the destruction of the Holy Temple is a segulah for healing a neck ailment.
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 9_Paragraph: A segulah for a person moving to a new house is to bring into it a sword, or a knife, or some other type of weapon. A hint to this is found in the verse, “A house is built with ChoKhMah (wisdom)” (Proverbs 24:3); the letters being an acronym for “Klei Chamas Me’cheiroteihem (weapons are their wares)” (Genesis 49:5). [The explanation of me’cheiroteihem is alternatively] “their swords” or “their places of dwelling.”
text.74_A Divine Remedy, 10_Paragraph: Apples are a segulah for women who have difficult births.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who empathizes with the suffering of the Jewish people and prays for them acquires humility.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: A person’s truthfulness earns him humility.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Having a fixed place in which to pray brings a person to humility and piety.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person’s humility causes his prayers to be heard. It is as if he offered all the various sacrifices.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: One’s prestige and importance grows and grows on account of his humility.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Humility leads to a long life.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: When a person is humble, his deeds are not scrutinized.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: The day you humble yourself is the day that strength, might and exaltedness are added to the hosts on high.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: When you see an increase of humility in the world, you can look forward to the imminent arrival of Mashiach.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: A person’s humility nullifies his fear of enemies.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: When a person is humble, everyone gets along with him.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: A person who is humble is never afraid, even when he finds himself in dire straits.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: A person who is not humble does not fear God.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: Humility causes a person to advance, and keeps him from falling from his level.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: A person with a soft heart is able to greatly humble himself.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: A person’s humility causes God to remember him.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: God fulfills the desires of a humble person.
text.75_Humility, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: The world exists only because of the person who makes himself as nothing.
text.75_Humility, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Humbling oneself is a segulah for having children.
text.75_Humility, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Asa result of extreme haughtiness one will be sodomized.
text.75_Humility, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: A person’s voice indicates whether he is humble or haughty.
text.75_Humility, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Sometimes, by lowering oneself or being humbled by others, a person is spared from a death sentence.
text.75_Humility, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: When a person feels lowly, he should realize that a death sentence has been issued against him.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who has not rectified the sins of his youth is beset with worries.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: A person suffers mainly because of the things he says.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: When you are suffering, talk about it.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: The fear of death befalls a person who carries worries in his heart.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person’s humbleness eliminates misfortune and sorrow.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: When a person is depressed, observing the Tzaddikim will bring joy to his heart.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Entering the house of a gentile leads to depression.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: A person’s face changes because of the evil in his heart.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: When you suffer anguish on a day of joy and all your happiness has ceased, you should know that your ancestral merit has expired.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: A depressed person should regularly give gifts to the Tzaddik.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: Depression leads to an outbreak of fires.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Depression is a sign of some imminent sickness.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: The Holy One does not reside with a person who is depressed.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Depression causes one to experience a seminal emission.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: When a person is depressed, he cannot achieve his goals.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: When a person cries, he cannot eat.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: Anyone who is never depressed, but always happy, will certainly gain prestige.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: It is a good sign when a sick person cries.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: Sadness causes a person’s enemies to be elevated.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: The hasty person is a sad person.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: Closeness to Tzaddikim makes the heart happy.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: A segulah for eliminating depression is to listen to an esteemed Tzaddik singing.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: A person who does not confess his sins will be beset by sighing and worry.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: When a person desires things that are against God’s will, he is given reason to sigh.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 29_Paragraph: Feeling bad over a bad dream nullifies it.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: Sound, sight and smell calm a person’s mind.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: Calling out to God eliminates suffering.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: A person who is depressed brings suffering upon himself.
text.76_Depression, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: Whoever dwells on his suffering more than he should suffers even more.
text.76_Depression, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Depression is felt in the heart. This is because the heart—which designs everything one does, whether good or otherwise—feels its own wrongdoing.
text.76_Depression, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: A person must avoid depression so as not to be given reason to mourn.
text.76_Depression, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Grief and depression lead to conflict, whereas joy brings peace to the world.
text.76_Depression, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: When a person’s happiness is ruined, he becomes sick.
text.76_Depression, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Compassion is a segulah for eliminating depression.
text.76_Depression, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: Taking vows and pledging charity bring happiness.
text.77_Constipation, 0_Paragraph: Constipation leads to thoughts of idolatry.
text.77_Constipation, 1_Paragraph: For any deadly disease one should empty his intestines.
text.78_Sin, 0_Paragraph: There are sins that are caused by one’s location.
text.78_Sin, 1_Paragraph: Whoever deliberately sins will in the end suffer public humiliation. He, in turn, will get angry at those [in whose eyes he has been disgraced].
text.79_Laziness, 0_Paragraph: Being unable to satisfy one’s desires makes a person lazy. The converse is also the case, [as a person’s laziness keeps him from attaining his desires].
text.79_Laziness, 1_Paragraph: Zealousness chases away sleep and revives the mind.
text.80_Punishment, 0_Paragraph: A person is sometimes punished even in the performance of a mitzvah. This is because, previously, he passed up an opportunity to fulfill just such a mitzvah.
text.80_Punishment, 1_Paragraph: A person sometimes unknowingly passes judgment on himself [by being asked to select a fitting punishment for someone else].
text.80_Punishment, 2_Paragraph: There are times when a person is killed because he failed to speak out on behalf of someone who is unjustly despised.
text.80_Punishment, 3_Paragraph: A person will sometimes be punished for having engaged in some illegal business practice, or because [he has been included in] a harsh decree passed against his neighbors or nation.
text.80_Punishment, 4_Paragraph: The Holy One hastens to exact punishment from an ungrateful person, punishing him at the hands of another ingrate.
text.80_Punishment, 5_Paragraph: Aperson bitten by a dog clearly has either accepted malicious gossip or spoken it.
text.81_Advice, 0_Paragraph: Seek advice only from someone well versed in the mysteries of the Torah.
text.81_Advice, 1_Paragraph: It is good to seek the advice of elders.
text.81_Advice, 2_Paragraph: A person who gives a fellow Jew unsuitable advice will be beset by thoughts of idolatry.
text.81_Advice, 3_Paragraph: Do not take advice from someone who is full of evil thoughts.
text.81_Advice, 4_Paragraph: By taking advice from a rabbi, you will be helped.
text.81_Advice, 5_Paragraph: When your friends won’t help you, clearly there is no advice that will help you.
text.81_Advice, 6_Paragraph: When you help other Jews, the advice you receive will be beneficial.
text.81_Advice, 7_Paragraph: Counsel is best taken in open fields.
text.81_Advice, 8_Paragraph: He who follows his wife’s advice [in religious matters] will descend into hell.
text.81_Advice, 9_Paragraph: Seek spiritual advice only from a man, and not from a woman.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: One who turns arrogant clearly sinned on purpose in the past.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: An arrogant person will not accept rebuke.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Arrogance hardens a person’s heart, and clearly he has yet to rectify his ancestors’ sins.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: One can remedy one’s arrogance by wearing tefilin that were on the head of a Tzaddik.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: A devout person is made the object of a wicked man’s disrespect only so that the devout person should scrutinize his own behavior.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: A person who is arrogant clearly is never satisfied with his lot.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Torah study is a rectification for arrogance.
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: A person’s arrogance causes drought. Clearly, he has sinned in the past and will do so again. One is permitted to call him wicked and to despise him. His soul is from the 974 generations [that existed before the world was created].
text.82_Arrogance, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Disrespect, even towards Heaven, helps a person get his way. Yet, arrogance is like a “king with no crown.”
text.82_Arrogance, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Those who see people treating the Torah sages disrespectfully should know that great wars will break out in that country.
text.82_Arrogance, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: A person suffers headaches because he has shown disrespect for one of King David’s descendants.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: Whenever a wicked person is stricken with fear, clearly the Holy One is fulfilling the desire of a Tzaddik.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Trust in God and you will be saved from fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Calling to mind our patriarch Abraham is a segulah for eliminating fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Reciting the words HaShem Tzevaot (God of the Hosts) is a segulah for eliminating fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: A person with intelligence should not be afraid of insignificant sounds.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Even if a person cannot see what is terrifying him, his guardian angel sees. To dispel this fear he should jump four steps from where he is; or recite the Shema Yisraeh, or proclaim, “The goat in the slaughterhouse is fatter than me!” (Megilah 3a).
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: A person who is afraid should sing happy songs.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: Picturing God’s Name Elohim - אלהים - in your mind’s eye will dispel any fear you may have.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Whoever consumes money belonging to Jews will be stricken with fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: A person who is lax in reciting the required blessings before and after eating will be stricken with fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: By trusting in God you will not become frightened.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: The beaten willow branches [of Hoshana Rabbah] are a segulah for dispelling fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: One who is attentive to and fulfills the verdict of a Jewish court is saved from fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: Immersing in a mikvah 310 times eliminates fear. One should also give a gift to a Tzaddik.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: Speaking truthfully saves a person from nighttime fears.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: By being humble you will not become frightened.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: The Other Side clearly has a portion in a house where fear is present.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: When a feeling of fear is followed by a fire, clearly the fear will be dispelled.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: When Jews are united, the nations are afraid of them.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: When the Jews forget God and no longer rely upon Him, they become frightened of the nations.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: The light of a candle is a segulah for dispelling fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: Taking pride in one’s wealth brings to fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: Worry and fear clog the heart.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: Studying Torah while sitting at a meal saves a person from fear.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: When a person is afraid, it is a sign that the Holy One has hidden His face from him and that he has been beset by harsh judgments.
text.83_Fear, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: A person who does not confess his sins will be stricken with fear.
text.83_Fear, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: When a person is stricken with fear, he should know that some trouble has befallen one of his contemporaries.
text.83_Fear, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: A person will sometimes become frightened prior to receiving some good.
text.83_Fear, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Anyone who flees from trouble is wise.
text.83_Fear, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: After a frightening dream at night, don’t take to the road on the following day.
text.83_Fear, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: When a person’s death is imminent, even if he is perfectly healthy and isn’t aware of his fate, he will experience fear and say that his death is at hand.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 0_Parag: A person’s haughty heart causes him to be taken captive.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 1_Parag: One who agrees with idolaters will fall into their hands. Refute whatever they say!
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 2_Parag: Attributing a statement to its originator brings redemption to the world.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 3_Parag: By redeeming captives, that which the redeemer has cast out is also gathered in.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 4_Parag: A person who does not leave his house is like a captive.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 5_Parag: For the sin of homosexuality a person is taken captive.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 6_Parag: When a person shows compassion for captives, God saves him from death.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 7_Parag: Whoever is imprisoned, clearly his soul is also imprisoned on high.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 8_Parag: One who comes to the Tzaddik for advice and later violates that advice will be taken captive.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 9_Parag: When a person feeds the starving, the Holy One saves him from being jailed.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 10_Para: One who does not rectify the sins of his youth will be taken prisoner.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 0_Part I, 11_Para: A person who regularly circumcises children, or who regularly provides the food a poor person needs in order to make a meal in honor of his son’s circumcision, will be saved from imprisonment.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 0_Para: Sexual immorality leads to incarceration or pain in one’s legs. A student who, despite being unqualified, instructs others, will also be punished with one of these afflictions, and he will be placed at the mercy of harmful forces.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 1_Para: Giving charity is a segulah for nullifying these afflictions.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 2_Para: Not pleading for mercy for a fellow Jew causes a person to fall into captivity. He can make amends by providing food for some living creature.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 3_Para: Marital relations with one’s wife on days when it is prohibited causes a person to be imprisoned.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 4_Para: When a Jew is taken captive, his aspect of the wellsprings of wisdom becomes sealed from the sages of the generation. The reverse happens when a person is freed from captivity.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 5_Para: Sometimes, by being taken captive, a person is spared the loss of his children.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 6_Para: A person guilty of slander will suffer imprisonment.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 7_Para: While in captivity, a person’s hair and clothing acquire a foul spirit that makes him both repugnant and despicable.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 8_Para: The effort one makes to redeem captives is a segulah for having children.
text.84_Redeeming Captives, 1_Part II, 9_Para: Whoever works to redeem captives carries [the support of] all the leaders of the generation.
text.85_Abstinence, 0_Paragraph: A person who abstains from worldly pleasures and later retreats from his asceticism will succumb to another desire, in addition to those he had before.
text.85_Abstinence, 2_Paragraph: When a person abstains from sexual relations, it is as if he fasted.
text.85_Abstinence, 3_Paragraph: A person turns sick and spits up blood when he abstains from marital relations on the night of ritual immersion.
text.86_Halakhic Codifiers, 0_Paragraph: Mastering the study of Halakhic codifiers so that one is able to instruct others causes many barren women to conceive.
text.86_Halakhic Codifiers, 1_Paragraph: Studying the Shulchan Arukh brings one to fear God.
text.86_Halakhic Codifiers, 2_Paragraph: Studying Halakhic codifiers nullifies thoughts of idolatry.
text.86_Halakhic Codifiers, 3_Paragraph: Whenever a wicked person prospers, it becomes difficult to develop new logical arguments in disputed matters of Halakhah. Judges’ verdicts also become unacceptable to the litigants.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: I All the charity and kindness that the Jews do in this world creates advocates of merit and leads to great harmony between Israel and their Father in heaven.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Charity is so great that it hastens the Final Redemption,
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: and enables one to receive the Divine Presence.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: [The giver of charity] becomes a creditor for God, as it were.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: and he is called a perfect Tzaddik.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Giving charity enables one to turn from evil ways.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: It is a greater mitzvah to provide for those who occupy themselves with the study of Torah than to provide for those who do not. With regards to the letter of the law, however, no distinction should be made.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Removing a stolen object from a fellow Jew’s possession is like giving charity.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Compromise is a form of judgment that contains the quality of charity.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: Giving charity to a poor person who does not deserve it carries no reward.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Always be grateful to the giver, never saying that it was not his to give, [but God’s].
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: Charity is equal to all the other mitzvot combined.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Getting others to do (give) is even greater than doing (giving) oneself.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: All the pennies one gives to charity make up one large sum.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: Anyone who conceals his charitable deeds is even greater than Moses.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: A person who gives a penny to charity receives six blessings, but one who consoles a poor person is rewarded eleven times over.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: The Holy One makes certain that a person who is eager to give charity has the money to do so, and deserving paupers are sent his way so that he will be rewarded for his benevolence. Such a person is also rewarded with children who will be wealthy, wise and masters of Aggadah.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: On Rosh Hashanah it is determined how much money each person will lose during the coming year. If he is worthy, he gives it to poor people.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: Jerusalem will be redeemed through charity.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: The evil Ahab had half his sins forgiven because he gave charity.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: Hospitality saves one from the sin of idolatry.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: So great is hospitality that [failing to be hospitable] repulses those who are near, while [being hospitable] draws near those who are distant.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: Hosting an idolater in one’s home causes one’s children to suffer exile.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: When people do not give charity, the government issues evil decrees and takes their money from them.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: Give charity with both hands and your prayers will be heard.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: By being generous, you will be able to stand your ground.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 29_Paragraph: Whoever goes about collecting charity removes wrath from the world.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: By giving charity, you will be blessed with children and they will live together peacefully.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: Giving charity causes the land’s produce to grow.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: In a time of trouble, a person’s charitable deeds are recalled for him.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: When you give charity, officials and rulers will be sympathetic to you.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: By giving charity, a person is spared injustice, robbery and misfortune.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: Giving charity brings a person grace.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: A person who encourages others to give charity increases salvation.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: A town in which there is no one to support the poor will experience an outbreak of fires.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: In reward for his generosity, a person is saved from haughtiness.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 41_Paragraph: Faith in God is considered like giving charity.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: By giving charity for the sake of Heaven one attains the quality of modesty.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: A person’s benevolence causes him to feel love for the Tzaddikim.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: Whoever steals from a poor person will be disgraced.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: Giving charity is tantamount to bringing a sacrifice.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: When Jews give charity, they are not exiled from their country.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: When people give charity, the land’s produce is blessed and there is peace in the world.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: By being truthful, your charitable deeds are noticed.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: Giving charity protects a person’s offspring.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 51_Paragraph: When one person prays for another, he is credited with having given charity.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 52_Paragraph: If, despite having all he needs, a person looks disapprovingly at the poor people who approach him with outstretched hands, he will have the following prophecy applied to him: “In the fullness of his sufficiency he will be pained... [Heaven will reveal his sin... The abundance of his house shall depart...] This is the lot of a wicked man...” It will also be fulfilled in a person who enables others to enter into a business venture by giving them half of what they require, but when they, through their efforts, earn enough to repay him and have sufficient livelihood besides, is resentful and pained by their success.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 53_Paragraph: When a person performs kind deeds for those who love God, he rectifies having blemished the brit.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 54_Paragraph: The merit of the poor saves us from the gentiles.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 55_Paragraph: When doing a mitzvah, don’t try to have it not cost you; rather, pay a full price for it.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 56_Paragraph: For the sin of not tithing one’s produce, the heavens are restrained and there is inflation.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 57_Paragraph: Giving charity happily is a sign of wholeheartedness.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 58_Paragraph: Keep giving: for as long as you find [people in need]; for as long as you have [what to give]; and for as long as you have the power [to give].
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 59_Paragraph: Whoever becomes accustomed to supporting one particular Kohen brings hunger to the world.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 60_Paragraph: One who provides a Torah scholar with all his needs earns himself a place in the Academy of heaven.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 61_Paragraph: Charity is greater than all the sacrifices.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 62_Paragraph: Acts of kindness are even greater than giving charity.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 63_Paragraph: Should you think that anyone who is eager to give charity is granted the opportunity and is immediately sent truly deserving paupers, the verse therefore uses the expression “how precious,” to teach that we must exert ourselves and search after such worthy individuals. Indeed, deserving paupers through whom a person can gain merit are hard to find.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 64_Paragraph: Charity has two faces: [The unstinting person who doesn’t have much should give] in line with what he can afford; and [the stingy person who has been blessed with wealth should give] in line with God’s blessing.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 65_Paragraph: When a person has enough for his own needs but chooses instead to take from others, you should know that he will be made to repay after death, being enslaved to the one from whom he took.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 66_Paragraph: Even by giving charity a person has no guarantee that he won’t become impoverished.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 67_Paragraph: When someone closes his eyes to giving charity, it is as if he worships idolatry.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 68_Paragraph: A person who trims his wealth to give charity is spared from the judgment of hell.
text.87_Charity, 0_Part I, 69_Paragraph: Even a poor person should give charity. The signs of poverty will then no longer be his lot.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Sexual immorality leads to incarceration or pain in one’s legs. A student who, despite being unqualified, instructs others, will also be punished with one of these afflictions, and he will be placed at the mercy of harmful forces. Giving charity is a segulah for nullifying these afflictions.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Studying Torah, giving tithes, and observing Shabbat provide material benefits as well.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: By giving charity, a person can defeat his enemies through minimal means [and effort], as God will save him from even their greatest means [and effort].
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Helping a Torah scholar nullifies the dictates of the stars and constellations.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: The merit of those who support the poor saves the masses from plague. Also in their merit, expanded consciousness precedes [rather than follows] constricted consciousness.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: Giving charity mitigates the harsh judgment destined for the Future, that is, for the Day of Judgment in the future to come.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: There are those whose acts of kindness sometimes have a negative effect. This corresponds to the warning given to the Kohanim— who personify the aspect of lovingkindness—not to take large steps [while performing the Temple service]. When people pretend not to see the harm brought on by their kindness, they cause the harsh judgment from on high to be without moderation. The inverse is also true. When care is taken that no harm comes from their kindness, it fosters moderation in the judgment.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: Those who would reveal original Torah insights must study the Codifiers beforehand and then again afterwards. This study of Torah law will protect their insights from foreign influences. The same procedure should also be followed when a person wants to performs some act of charity.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: Originating Torah insights arouses the giving of charity, and vice versa.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: So great is the power of tithing that it can turn a curse into a blessing.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 11_Paragraph: A person whose deeds are filled with kindness has no need of ancestral merit.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 12_Paragraph: Doing favors for others brings a person long life.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 13_Paragraph: Certain prayers are accepted on high only after sufficient money, equivalent to the number of letters in the relevant prayer, is given to charity. For example, when a person prays, “Give me children,” he must contribute the sum equal to the letters of these very words.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 14_Paragraph: By giving charity one merits having children.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 15_Paragraph: Whoever provides support for many people draws a blessing from the Land of Israel to the Diaspora.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 16_Paragraph: One who gives charity to the poor people of the Land of Israel will prosper monetarily.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 17_Paragraph: When a person moves to a new place, he should distribute meat to the poor inhabitants there. Doing so will earn him favor in the eyes of the town’s officials.
text.87_Charity, 1_Part II, 18_Paragraph: Giving Shekalim saves a person from the evil inclination.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 0_Parag: Don’t be surprised when you find that the Tzaddik has left something unperfected. This is God’s doing, so that the Tzaddik leaves an area through which his son can later gain prominence.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 1_Parag: There are times when the interruption of Torah study strengthens it.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 2_Parag: [A Tzaddik will] accept gifts from the wicked so that they might repent.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 3_Parag: The Tzaddikim use their merit to benefit the world, but not themselves.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 4_Parag: It is common for one Tzaddik to do something that will make him another Tzaddik’s teacher.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 5_Parag: Seeing the faces of the generation’s leaders is of great benefit.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 6_Parag: A Tzaddik will be punished when he fails to pray for his generation.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 7_Parag: A person who teaches Torah to an unsuitable student is called wicked.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 8_Parag: The manner in which the Sages speak brings prosperity and healing. A person should therefore learn to speak as they did.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 9_Parag: When a person teaches Torah to others, the Torah is revealed to him with minimum effort.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 10_Para: It is common for a Tzaddik to complain when one of his disciples draws closer to another Tzaddik in order to gain prestige.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 11_Para: When drawing closer to Tzaddikim requires overcoming difficulties, it is all the more beneficial for serving the Creator.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 12_Para: There are times when Heaven shows the Tzaddik something that is only imaginary.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 13_Para: Doing a favor for someone who is unaware of it is like “throwing a stone at Mercury” (a form of idol worship).
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 14_Para: Each person should practice [the Torah] as it was taught to him by his teacher.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 15_Para: There are times when God will bring a number of Tzaddikim together in one place so that the irritation caused by their mutual infringement brings them to fully mature.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 16_Para: Anyone who does not delay answering nature’s call merits having students.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 17_Para: It happens that a Tzaddik’s fame spreads far and wide, yet afterwards he falls. This is because of his desire for wealth.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 18_Para: Anyone who holds God important will record in a book all the names of the Tzaddikim, the Mishnaic Sages and the God-fearing, in order to remember them.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 19_Para: “Why do the Tzaddikim accept benefits from others so that their family members can live in affluence and splendor? Wouldn’t it be better to forgo such a lifestyle and not be obliged to take from others?” This should not trouble you. For whatever pleasure and broadness the Tzaddik experiences expands his soul, thereby providing the Holy One’s Divine Presence with a tranquil place to reside. Therefore, one should never come to the home of a Tzaddik empty-handed.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 20_Para: When you want a Tzaddik to pray for you, go to a Tzaddik who is compassionate.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 21_Para: You must refer to the most prominent leader of your generation as “my master,” even if you are greater than him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 22_Para: When a Tzaddik suffers some misfortune, he should ask another Tzaddik to pray on his behalf.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 23_Para: Even if those who travel to be with the Tzaddik do not receive any Torah lessons from him, they are rewarded for having made the journey.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 24_Para: Whoever does not attend to the needs of Torah scholars deserves to die.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 25_Para: The Tzaddik can elevate the dead to a very high level.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 26_Para: By journeying to be with a Torah scholar, a person rectifies any spiritual damage he caused by [failing to recite] the Birkhot HaNehenin.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 27_Para: When a person is in a position to protest [against the actions of the wicked] but does not, he is punished for their sins.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 28_Para: It is inappropriate to accept the authority of others while in the Tzaddik’s presence.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 29_Para: One who is apathetic at the eulogy of a Torah scholar will not live long.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 30_Para: The Tzaddik’s ability to exact punishment is proportional to his mazal.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 31_Para: When a Tzaddik dies, the void he leaves behind is consistent with the attributes by which he lived.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 32_Para: The disciples of a Tzaddik earn their livelihood in his merit.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 33_Para: When a person hears a Torah lesson from the Tzaddik, it is as if he delivered it himself.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 34_Para: The death of a Tzaddik is as much a tragedy as the burning of God’s Temple.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 35_Para: If a Torah scholar is fitting, learn from him; if not, part from his company.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 36_Para: One should not stare at his teacher’s nakedness in the bathhouse, or in any other similar situation.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 37_Para: There are times when two Tzaddikim are on equal par, yet great mysteries are revealed to only one of them. You should know that the reason the other is not shown is because his merit is needed elsewhere, to protect others.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 38_Para: It is better to draw close to a Tzaddik who is compassionate.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 39_Para: In the merit of attending to the needs of a great person, one is saved from death.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 40_Para: A person who issues a Halakhic ruling in the presence of his teacher deserves to die, and by right should be bitten by a snake. He is called a sinner and should be removed from a position of status. He will descend into hell, childless.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 41_Para: Once you’ve made certain that the source from which you draw wisdom—namely, your teacher—is blessed and fitting, don’t substitute or exchange it for another.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 42_Para: Each person should behave in a manner consistent with the blessing given to his tribe [by the patriarch Jacob].
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 43_Para: The wellspring of Torah departs from the Tzaddik when there is a wicked person in his home.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 44_Para: In the merit of the Tzaddikim buried in their midst, also those buried outside the Holy Land will merit resurrection without suffering.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 45_Para: Benefitting the Tzaddik with one’s money is tantamount to performing the service of the Holy Temple.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 46_Para: There are some Tzaddikim who are never known by the title “rabbi.”
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 47_Para: When the Tzaddik says something that remains unfulfilled because its time has not yet come, his words are engraved on high but lack luster. However, once the time comes for his words to be realized, they begin to shine brightly.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 48_Para: One who benefits a Torah scholar has to strengthen [his faith] so as not to lose his respect for that scholar.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 49_Para: Denying one’s student Torah is tantamount to stealing his ancestral inheritance. Even a fetus in its mother’s womb curses such a teacher, whose body will be riddled with holes, like a sieve. Conversely, by teaching his student, he is rewarded with great blessing, like Joseph, and merits teaching Torah in the World to Come.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 50_Para: A person who does not use his wealth to benefit a Torah scholar will never see a blessing in what he owns.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 51_Para: One who ridicules the words of the Sages is punished with death.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 52_Para: Being close to the Tzaddikim is beneficial in both this world and the next.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 53_Para: The Tzaddik has the power to decree heaven for one person and hell for another.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 54_Para: It is worthwhile expending even a great deal of time in order to spend but a single hour in the proximity of a Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 55_Para: When a person begins losing the use of his physical senses, he should worry that death, or some other misfortune, is near.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 56_Para: There are those who can create beautiful Torah expositions and yet not be in tune with the truth.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 57_Para: One Tzaddik can elevate the Torah lesson of another Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 58_Para: The insight that a Tzaddik originates in Torah, God repeats in his name.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 59_Para: The words of wise Tzaddikim are dearer than the words of Torah and the Prophets. You must hearken to and obey them even if these Tzaddikim do not impress you with any miracle.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 60_Para: One who praises the Tzaddik will have blessings placed on his head.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 61_Para: Everything that happens in a town depends on the Tzaddik living there.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 62_Para: A Tzaddik may have a student of Halakhah attend him, provided he teaches this student something new.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 63_Para: Whoever brings a boor under the Tzaddik’s influence will be rewarded.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 64_Para: One who goes out to greet his teacher will never see the netherworld.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 65_Para: There are times when a person’s prayers help as long as he keeps praying. Once he stops, the Holy One does as He sees fit.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 66_Para: Giving a gift to a Torah scholar is like bringing a first-fruit offering.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 67_Para: Do not try to force God’s hand.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 68_Para: One who loves the Tzaddik must keep him from getting a bad name.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 69_Para: The Tzaddik despises all the favors of wicked men.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 70_Para: Do not beseech or bother your Master as long as it is possible to achieve what you seek through your own efforts.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 71_Para: While a Tzaddik is still in this world, his portion in the Garden of Eden is being used by the Tzaddikim already there.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 72_Para: There are certain disciples whose very essence is dependent on the merit of the Tzaddik. When the Tzaddik dies, they also die, or are punished.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 73_Para: Those who were followers of the Tzaddik during his lifetime will be his followers even after his death, or after theirs.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 74_Para: When a person is close to one Tzaddik and then becomes a follower of a second Tzaddik, the Torah taught to him by the first Tzaddik troubles him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 75_Para: There are times when a Tzaddik must die in order to suppress some harsh decree on high.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 76_Para: Who merits the World to Come? The one whom people honor for his wisdom.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 77_Para: A person who gives charity is able to turn from evil ways.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 78_Para: You need not chastise and chase away a student who refuses to follow the proper path. Rather, bring him closer to you. This will benefit your other pupils, and eventually he too will take heed.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 79_Para: A person sometimes dies before his time because of the Tzaddik’s complaints against him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 80_Para: It is possible for a person to be a great Tzaddik even without being very learned.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 81_Para: A person who does not believe in the words of the Tzaddikim, and certainly one who ridicules them, deserves to be punished.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 82_Para: The Tzaddik is permitted to discourage a person who wants to get closer to him but raises questions unnecessarily.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 83_Para: Before publicly delivering a Torah lesson, the Tzaddik may say things that will endear his words to his listeners.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 84_Para: [Although decreed in heaven,] even a person’s first marriage partner can be changed through prayer.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 85_Para: In this world, whoever wants to get closer can do so. But in the World to Come, the only ones brought close are those who already were.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 86_Para: When a person rejects the Tzaddik’s attempts to draw him closer, the Tzaddik has every right to push him away.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 87_Para: The Tzaddik can punish his offender with death even for a slight offense, and even if that offense was accidental.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 88_Para: That which you hear directly from the Tzaddik is more beneficial than that which you learn from a book.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 89_Para: A person is better able to understand when he sees the face of the speaker.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 90_Para: The Tzaddik’s simple statement opens up a great light, making it easy for common people to understand exalted wisdom.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 91_Para: When a person behaves improperly, it is permitted to make him your servant.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 92_Para: The Tzaddik will sometimes elevate a person only to later lower his status. This is for that person’s own good.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 93_Para: Some Tzaddikim are called good, while others are not. Likewise, some evil men are called wicked, while others are not.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 94_Para: It is a disgrace and a humiliation for the generation when its leader has no one tending to his affairs.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 95_Para: Teaching others [to perform mitzvot] is preferable to practicing oneself.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 96_Para: Be careful not to display piety in front of a great person.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 97_Para: You can determine a person’s inner character from his affiliation, when you see which Tzaddik he follows.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 98_Para: A Tzaddik should not endanger himself by being the only one to pray on his behalf. Rather, he should ask a second Tzaddik to pray with him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 99_Para: The Tzaddik’s prayer has the power to save a person from sinning.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 100_Par: The Tzaddik is the image of God for his generation.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 101_Par: In their time of trouble, the Tzaddik bears the suffering of those who support him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 102_Par: A person can be a Tzaddik even if he hasn’t perfected his trust in God.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 103_Par: The Tzaddik is able to enjoy physical pleasure without fearing the evil inclination, because his Torah study will protect him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 104_Par: A person who does not rise in the presence of his teacher is called wicked. He will not live a long life and will forget his learning.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 105_Par: Do not burden the Holy One when you can find help by some other means.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 106_Par: Sometimes, pleasing the Tzaddik just once, and only slightly, is enough to earn the World to Come.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 107_Par: A person who has perfect faith in God is capable of pleasing the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 108_Par: One who is free of idolatrous thoughts will always yearn to save the Tzaddikim.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 109_Par: When a person wants to benefit the Tzaddik, the Holy One gives him the ability to do so.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 110_Par: A Torah scholar who rejects his teachers has his years shortened.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 111_Par: A person who assumes the position of rabbi when there is someone greater than himself has his years cut short.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 112_Par: When a Tzaddik must pray for something but is afraid of those who will dispute his righteousness, he should ask for the very opposite of what he wants.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 113_Par: When a wicked person who has done some evil comes to the Tzaddik seeking his approval, the Tzaddik may save himself by telling the wicked person that he has done well.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 114_Par: Preventing others from coming under the wings of the Divine Presence (i.e., serving God) causes a person’s children to fall into servitude.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 115_Par: There are times when the mercy one must seek for a sick person is that he die.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 116_Par: The Holy One first reveals a hidden teaching in the Torah to the Tzaddik and then repeats that teaching in the Tzaddik’s name.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 117_Par: There are times when the fasting and prayers of the Tzaddik are to no avail.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 118_Par: The Tzaddik may violate the boundaries set by others in order to establish his own path [in serving God].
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 119_Par: There are times when among those who’ve been sentenced to death in heaven is someone whom the Tzaddik loves. The Tzaddik has the power to pray for him and save him by putting someone else in his place.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 120_Par: The Tzaddik has the power to take from one person and give to another.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 122_Par: Each Tzaddik has a particular devotion that another Tzaddik, even one greater than him, is unable to match.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 123_Par: The reason Tzaddikim travel from place to place collecting money is that the words of Torah are poor (concise) in one place and rich (extensive) in another.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 124_Par: Torah scholars live long when they show each other respect.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 125_Par: The prayers of a Tzaddik who is the son of a wicked person cannot compare to the prayers of a Tzaddik who is the son of a Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 126_Par: Testing the Tzaddik is like testing God.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 127_Par: All the demands for money that the gentiles make of the Jews are only on account of the disrespect that the Jews have shown the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 128_Par: It is a great honor for the Tzaddik when those who are God’s enemies also speak against and argue with him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 129_Par: Faith in the Tzaddik mitigates harsh judgment.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 130_Par: The Tzaddik uses God’s Torah to teach Him how to act towards us.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 131_Par: A prayer that a person prays while binding himself to the Tzaddikim will be answered.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 132_Par: The Holy One pardons the sins of the Jews because of the Tzaddikim.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 133_Par: A person’s derisiveness prevents him from going to the Tzaddikim
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 134_Par: By giving charity, a person merits coming closer to the Tzaddikim.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 135_Par: There is no Tzaddik who is free from controversy and scrutiny.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 136_Par: The wicked person who is too embarrassed to repudiate the Tzaddik himself will instead berate those who follow the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 137_Par: Seeing the face of the Tzaddik sharpens the mind.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 138_Par: Whoever protects the Tzaddik from suffering merits respect and will benefit from the Tzaddik’s righteousness.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 139_Par: By hearing a Torah lesson from a Tzaddik one receives vitality.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 140_Par: A wicked person who has sinned often can make amends by doing things that bring vitality to the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 141_Par: When a wicked person humbles himself before the Tzaddik, clearly some punishment had been decreed against the Tzaddik, but now that punishment will no longer come.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 142_Par: When you fear the Tzaddik, you merit turning away from evil.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 143_Par: When a wicked person prays for mercy on behalf of a Tzaddik who is in pain, he merits standing at the gates of the righteous.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 144_Par: The Holy One will sometimes ignore the Tzaddik’s prayers in order to push aside the wicked, so that they will remain with their evil ways.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 145_Par: Those who quarrel with the Tzaddik forget the Torah.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 146_Par: Praising the Tzaddikim is like praising God.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 147_Par: Neither the sound of war nor turmoil nor bad news is heard in a city that obeys the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 148_Par: Opposition to the Tzaddikim stems from the opposition the Tzaddikim show for each other.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 149_Par: God makes the Tzaddik dependent upon the masses for his livelihood so that he should have some connection to them. Thus, when God remembers the Tzaddik, He also remembers everyone else.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 150_Par: Mashiach’s coming is dependent on our getting closer to the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 151_Par: The soul’s perfection depends mainly on getting closer to the Tzaddikim.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 152_Par: When a person’s drawing closer to the Tzaddik lacks sincerity, he will later turn into the Tzaddik’s adversary.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 153_Par: While in the presence of the Tzaddik, a liar’s heart wonders how he will ever be able to speak afterwards.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 154_Par: People who speak against the Tzaddik eventually have their words turn on them. They also fall ill.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 155_Par: Whoever humbles himself before the Tzaddik arouses the Tzaddik’s love for him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 156_Par: Telling stories about the Tzaddikim brings a person closer to them.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 157_Par: The more God rests a spirit of holiness upon a Tzaddik, the more that Tzaddik receives support from the wealthy; and the more support they give him, the better the Tzaddik is able to bring the wicked back to God in repentance.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 158_Par: The Tzaddikim are made to suffer so that in the World to Come the wicked will have no claim against the good that God will give the righteous.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 159_Par: When God-fearing people join with the Tzaddik, they cause the Holy One and His Divine Presence to unite face to face; after which, there is no descent [from this elevated state].
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 160_Par: Praising the Tzaddikim causes the wicked to suffer a great downfall.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 161_Par: The Tzaddik dies on account of the sins of sorcery and immoral behavior.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 162_Par: People guilty of immoral behavior are usually opponents of the Tzaddikim.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 163_Par: When the Tzaddik passes away, people are left in a state akin to impurity and their righteousness is repulsive in God’s eyes.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 164_Par: When people rise up against the Tzaddik, they incite Heaven’s wrath and promote an outbreak of fires.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 165_Par: There are times when Tzaddikim are made to wander from place to place in order to reveal the existence of some hidden Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 166_Par: There are times when the Tzaddik is made to suffer in order to lessen the suffering of the Jewish people.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 167_Par: The masses filling their stomachs brings about the loss of the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 168_Par: The suffering of the Tzaddikim atones for all of Israel.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 169_Par: God grows angry with, and strikes fear into, a person who refuses to accept the authority of the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 170_Par: God grants contentment to anyone who brings a gift to the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 171_Par: By bringing a gift to the Tzaddik, a person defeats his enemies and nullifies the evil spirit that has rested upon him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 172_Par: The Holy One shows favor to a person who prostrates himself on the grave of a Tzaddik, even if he does not deserve it.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 173_Par: God performs acts of lovingkindness for a person who relates stories about the Tzaddikim.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 174_Par: The Tzaddik is able to lead people because of the fear of God that he possesses.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 175_Par: A person must stand while receiving the Tzaddik’s blessing.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 176_Par: A king may raise the funds needed for his expenditures by taxing his nation.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 177_Par: The respect shown for the Tzaddik’s offspring awakens the Holy One’s will to bring Mashiach.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 178_Par: Traveling to visit the Tzaddik subdues one’s enemies.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 179_Par: Anyone who violates the Tzaddik’s instructions falls from esteem.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 180_Par: When a person uses his possessions to benefit the Tzaddik, it is as if he benefits all Jews and he will be saved from death.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 181_Par: Objecting to the words of the Tzaddik is tantamount to seeking advice from a sorcerer.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 182_Par: When a person possesses genuine wisdom, God is with him and people fear him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 183_Par: One who provides all sorts of support for the Tzaddik will be close to and near this Tzaddik in the World to Come.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 184_Par: Aperson who provokes the Tzaddik will in the end be caught in an evil trap.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 185_Par: When one relates stories about the Tzaddikim, his own righteousness is remembered [by God].
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 186_Par: A Tzaddik is able to give even something that does not yet exist.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 187_Par: The Tzaddik takes possession of wherever he sets his foot.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 188_Par: By offering advice to Tzaddikim at a time they face opposition, a person’s achievements will be established and will never be undone.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 189_Par: While observing the Tzaddik, a person should gaze with reverence so that he will not be punished by Heaven.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 190_Par: A person’s fear of Heaven makes him yearn to draw closer to the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 191_Par: Sitting at the table of the Tzaddik eliminates war.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 192_Par: A fraudulent person eventually joins those who oppose and quarrel with the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 193_Par: There are times when the Tzaddik will contract leprosy because he has recently gotten some person to repent.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 194_Par: Whoever says of the Tzaddik that he is wicked, and of a wicked person that he is a Tzaddik, will fall ill. Through this he also causes an eclipse of the sun, and of the moon.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 195_Par: Binding oneself to the Tzaddik is a great healing.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 196_Par: It is very difficult for a person to achieve the assistance he needs when there is a Tzaddik in his city and he does not ask the Tzaddik to pray for him.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 197_Par: It sometimes happens that although a person is very close to the Tzaddik, he doesn’t feel any fear of God. He should know that were he not close to the Tzaddik, he would not even deserve to be alive.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 198_Par: There are times when the Tzaddik is too embarrassed to ask God to relieve his suffering. What does God do? He brings similar suffering upon a wicked person so that he comes to the Tzaddik and asks the Tzaddik to pray for him. In this way, the Tzaddik, too, is relieved of his suffering.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 199_Par: Whoever disagrees with a Tzaddik to his face clearly has no fear of Heaven.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 200_Par: Sometimes, the strife a Tzaddik encounters is definite proof of his righteousness.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 201_Par: There are wicked people who are successful. But when they persecute the Tzaddik, the evil forces themselves take revenge against them.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 202_Par: The difference between a Tzaddik and a person who fears God is that the God-fearing person is not given permission to reveal God’s secrets, whereas the Tzaddik is.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 203_Par: Whoever speaks against the Tzaddik clearly is arrogant.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 204_Par: When the Holy One wants a Tzaddik to teach the proper path to people, He indicates this to the Tzaddik through his livelihood.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 205_Par: TheTzaddik, while praying for a person, isable to understand which sin is the cause of that person’s particular misfortune.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 206_Par: One who guards his sexual purity certainly cherishes the Tzaddik.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 207_Par: When the Tzaddik serves God but shows no concern for teaching the common people, he will fall from his spiritual level.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 0_Part I, 208_Par: By financially supporting the Tzaddik, all a person’s sins are pardoned, just as when the Kohanim eat from a sacrifice and the sins of the animal’s owners are atoned.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 0_Para: Telling stories about the Tzaddikim draws the light of Mashiach into the world. It also dispels much darkness and pain from the world.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 1_Para: And the teller is rewarded with beautiful clothing.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 2_Para: During the seven days of mourning after the Tzaddik’s death, God fills the mourners with the light that has been hidden away since the Six Days of Creation.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 3_Para: It should not surprise you that a human being, despite being such a miniscule creation, has all the worlds dependent upon him. For this is true of wherever the Divine Presence resides: The little sustains the much.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 4_Para: Each person’s portion in the Garden of Eden is pictured in the shine of his face.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 5_Para: Generally, the God-fearing have to roam from place to place to obtain their livelihood.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 6_Para: There are times when a Tzaddik must wander from place to place so that he will later recall all of them when he enters the World to Come. Through this, prosperity will come to those places.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 7_Para: Whoever knows the names of the living descendants of the Tzaddikim knows everything that is going to happen.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 8_Para: A person who justifies the actions of others will have all his wishes fulfilled, without any interference.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 9_Para: When a Tzaddik loses his strength, so that he cannot fulfill the will of his Creator the way he once did, he should know that God no longer wants him to teach the path of repentance to the wicked.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 10_Par: The Tzaddik’s power is strongest when harsh judgment is mitigated—that is, through God’s Oneness.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 11_Par: When the fame of the Tzaddikim spreads in the world, new songs are composed.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 12_Par: When a person sacrifices himself for the Jewish people, his directives cannot be annulled. Whatever he decrees will come to be.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 13_Par: Tending to the needs of the Tzaddik brings freedom and nullifies curses.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 14_Par: Those close to God-fearing people similarly merit fear and daat.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 15_Par: When the Tzaddik becomes wealthy, the wicked return to God in repentance.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 16_Par: When God sees that a certain Tzaddik has the ability to inspire people to devotional service, He stirs up opposition against him. God does this so that the Tzaddik will indeed succeed in inspiring others, which a Tzaddik without enemies cannot do. This can be likened to the times of Mashiach, when people will be at peace and coverts will no longer be accepted.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 17_Par: There are two types of Tzaddikim: one whose words are the aspect of plowing, and one whose words are the aspect of reaping. Said otherwise, one Tzaddik’s speech corresponds to the male arousal for marital relations, while the other’s corresponds to drawing the seed into the womb, and fetal conception and gestation. Therefore, when there is a quarrel between these two Tzaddikim, an outsider should not meddle in their verbal exchanges, so as not to ruin the deeper intention.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 18_Par: When visiting a Tzaddik’s gravesite, a person needs some merit in order to gather the Tzaddik’s spirit and soul to the grave, so that it will be as if he were alive. Without this merit, the Tzaddik’s spirit and soul ascend on high to join the other Tzaddikim.
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 19_Par: Mentioning the names of the Tzaddikim has the power to bring about a change in the Act of Creation, altering Nature. This is alluded to through [a combination of the verses]: “These are the generations of heaven and earth” (Genesis 2:4) and “These are the names of the Children of Israel” (Exodus 1:1).
text.88_A Righteous Person, 1_Part II, 20_Par: One who knows of the Holy Land, who has really tasted the Land of Israel, can recognize in another whether he has been with the true Tzaddik for Rosh HaShanah. For when a person merits being with the true Tzaddik for Rosh HaShanah, wherever he focuses his attention he transforms the air there into an aspect of the air of the Land of Israel. Therefore, one who knows the taste of the Holy Land, each according to his own level, will of necessity feel the Land of Israel when he comes together with this person who has been with the true Tzaddik for Rosh HaShanah, through whom the air becomes an aspect of the Holy Land.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: Cursing brings to mourning, God forbid.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: One may not curse another person unless he can foresee the future generations of the one he curses.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Do not take the curse of an ordinary person lightly.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: It is the intention behind the curse that matters.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: There are times when a Tzaddik’s curse lasts as long as he is alive, but not after he dies.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: An unjustified curse eventually turns back on the curser.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: The wise person’s curse, even if unjustified, and even if conditional, comes to be.
text.89_A Curse, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Even a gentile who blesses a Jew will be blessed.
text.89_A Curse, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person who is always cursing comes from the World of Emptiness, while a person who is wont to bless is from the World of Rectification.
text.89_A Curse, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Investigating the World of Emptiness—namely, what is above and what is below, what preceded this world and what follows it—brings a curse. But guarding against such investigation brings blessing.
text.89_A Curse, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: A person who is accustomed to cursing will not have clothing for Shabbat.
text.89_A Curse, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: A curse has no effect on a person of distinguished ancestry.
text.89_A Curse, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Tending to the needs of the Tzaddik brings freedom and nullifies curses.
text.89_A Curse, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: Conducting one’s business affairs faithfully nullifies curses.
text.89_A Curse, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: When one person curses another during a time of panic, the curse proves very damaging.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: The letters of the word ATaH - אתה - defeat the forces of evil.
