text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Writing on parchment the verse, “God, when Your hand is uplifted, they will not see” (Isaiah 26:11), protects a woman who has just given birth.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Evil forces are prevalent in ruins and destroyed buildings.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: The light of a candle overpowers the rule of the evil forces.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person’s mazal protects him from harm.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Reciting the “seven voices” that David recited upon the waters (Psalm 29) subdues the evil spirit.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Harmful forces are as prevalent in ditches as they are in fields.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Demons frequent uninhabited places, even during the day. In the city, however, people need not fear even at night.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Many demons are revealed to a person out of the north.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Reading the Torah portion Noah is a segulah for chasing away the spirit of unholiness.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 0_Part I, 10_Paragrap: The breath of an evil person causes those who talk with him to turn vulgar and crass.
text.90_Forces of Evil, 1_Part II, 0_Paragrap: There are demons found in a person’s house that destroy domestic harmony by bringing anger and quarreling into the home. This is the why the woman is most often the initiator of dispute, as she is the essence of the home, as in: ‘“His house’ refers to his wife” (Yoma 2a). However, sometimes, the demons attach themselves to the other members of the household, causing them to suffer as a result of their quarreling and contentiousness. This is explicitly found in the verse, “Their homes are peaceful, without fear...” (Job 21:9), about which the Sages teach: “without fear”—these are the demons. And this is “peaceful, without fear,” because peace and fear are opposites; fear being the demons that destroy peace. Thus, the verse concludes, “and the rod of God is not upon them,” which alludes to the abovementioned suffering.
text.91_Envy and Jealousy, 0_Paragraph: When envy is eliminated, it will herald the ingathering of the Jews from exile.
text.91_Envy and Jealousy, 1_Paragraph: Jealousy brings to an outbreak of fires.
text.91_Envy and Jealousy, 2_Paragraph: Envy leads to the shedding of innocent blood.
text.91_Envy and Jealousy, 3_Paragraph: Anyone who is envious of another person’s wealth turns foolish.
text.91_Envy and Jealousy, 4_Paragraph: Visiting the Tzaddik will eliminate your jealousy.
text.91_Envy and Jealousy, 5_Paragraph: Jealousy causes a person’s bones to rot.
text.91_Envy and Jealousy, 7_Paragraph: A person whose jealousy leads him to take revenge destroys his own home.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 0_Parag: A person will experience a seminal emission after having spoken of immoral matters or after losing his faith in God.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 1_Parag: One who spills his seed will in the end go naked.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 2_Parag: Depression causes one to experience a seminal emission.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 3_Parag: A person who is careful not to eat food about which there is some Halakhic question is protected from being made impure by a seminal emission.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 4_Parag: One who has experienced a seminal emission should immerse in a mikvah before eating at the Tzaddik’s table.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 5_Parag: Rejoicing in the good that befalls the Tzaddik is a rectification for wasting one’s seed.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 6_Parag: By mocking others, a person will come to pollute himself with a seminal emission.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 8_Parag: A wasteful emission of seed is brought on by eating garlic and eggs,
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 0_Part I, 9_Parag: or by engaging in idle talk, or by using obscene language.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 1_Part II, 0_Para: Drunkenness causes exile and leads to the wasteful emission of seed.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 1_Part II, 1_Para: Embarrassment comes from having spilled one’s seed.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 1_Part II, 2_Para: The inability to pronounce one’s words properly, speaking only half words, is the same aspect as the wasting of seed.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 1_Part II, 3_Para: A man who experiences a seminal emission [should be concemed that] his children will die.
text.92_A Seminal Emission, 1_Part II, 4_Para: Reciting the following ten psalms on the day one experiences a seminal emission provides great remedy and rectification: Psalms 16, 32, 41, 42, 59, 77, 90, 105, 137, and 150. You can be certain that these ten psalms are very, very beneficial for rectifying this sin. A person who is careful to recite the psalms as prescribed needs no longer fear. He will definitely make the necessary amends, for these ten psalms are a very great rectification.
text.93_Difficulty in Childbirth, 0_Paragraph: A woman who eats radishes during pregnancy will have difficulty giving birth.
text.93_Difficulty in Childbirth, 1_Paragraph: Giving a woman to drink from the waters of seven wells is a segulah for preventing difficulty in childbirth.
text.93_Difficulty in Childbirth, 2_Paragraph: [Other segulot that are beneficial for alleviating difficulties in childbirth are:] keeping her other children out of the house during labor,
text.93_Difficulty in Childbirth, 3_Paragraph: whispering the letters of the Holy Name SaG (Yud Vav Dalet, Heh Yud, Vav Aleph Vav, Heh Yud) into her ear,
text.93_Difficulty in Childbirth, 4_Paragraph: not placing her bed in the western or southern part of the room,
text.93_Difficulty in Childbirth, 5_Paragraph: and putting around her neck some bitter herbs leftover [from the Passover Seder].
text.93_Difficulty in Childbirth, 6_Paragraph: Whispering into a woman’s ear the letters peh aleph, vav aleph vav, ayin yud nun, heh aleph is also [a segulah for easing the difficulties of childbirth].
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 0_Pa: The Tzaddik brings a blessing when he enters the house of a wicked person, but only if the house is suitable for a blessing.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 1_Pa: Keep away from the wicked so that you won’t be caught up in their punishment.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 2_Pa: Showing a bit of friendliness to the wicked is permitted in order to avoid hostility.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 3_Pa: There are certain times when doing something good for a totally wicked person pleases God.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 4_Pa: It is forbidden to praise the wicked. However, when such praise also reflects positively upon the Tzaddik, limited praise is permissible.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 5_Pa: One who finds good in the wicked is also called wicked.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 6_Pa: We do not rely on a wicked person even if he has done something properly and in accordance with Torah law.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 7_Pa: Whoever stands as a guarantor for a wicked person succumbs to lustful desires and sickness.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 8_Pa: A wicked person who has completely forsaken God clearly will never have worthy offspring.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 9_Pa: Have no mercy on an enemy of God when he falls into your hands.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 10_P: Avoid associating with people who are known for telling lies and you will be worthy of detecting deceivers.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 11_P: Whoever despises those who entice people away from God is assured that he won’t be affected by their words.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 12_P: The study of Torah drives a wedge between wicked people who have joined forces.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 13_P: The Holy One rescues a person who keeps his distance from the wicked.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 14_P: When the wicked are scattered, it is a sign of salvation.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 15_P: Avoid living in a house once inhabited by a wicked person.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 16_P: Don’t talk to those who try to lure you away from God, even to admonish them and bring them closer to Him.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 17_P: The wicked joining forces is detrimental to one’s serving God.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 0_Part I, 18_P: It is fitting and right for God’s holy ones to create barriers and obstacles that will chase away all tyrannical and wicked people from them.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 1_Part II, 0_P: One who does not see through the deception of the wicked is detested [by God].
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 1_Part II, 1_P: Imposters cause those whom they deceive to suffer pain of the eyes.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 1_Part II, 2_P: A person should avoid exchanging kisses with the wicked, for the kiss creates a bond that lasts even after death.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 1_Part II, 3_P: There are people who, despite being filled with heresy and atheism, are able to keep their thoughts hidden. [Their deception is so clever that] a person who comes in contact with them has no idea that he has to protect himself from them. However, when a person possesses the quality of modesty, he will be saved from such atheists.
text.94_Distancing the Wicked, 1_Part II, 4_P: The wicked disrupt our serving God more by the mitzvot they do than by the sins they commit. This is the reason a gentile who observes Shabbat deserves death.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 0_Par: Whoever shows compassion for the poor merits consolation from God.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 1_Par: He will also always be victorious.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 2_Par: When there is no compassion, the world suffers from hunger.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 3_Par: There is also an increase in theft.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 4_Par: A person who prays fervently merits having compassion for the poor.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 5_Par: One who has no compassion goes crazy.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 6_Par: One who repays bad with good lives a long life.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 7_Par: By being compassionate, your lustful desires will be eliminated.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 8_Par: By ignoring your brother when you see that he is in trouble, it is as if you were responsible for that trouble.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 9_Par: One who sees a fellow Jew suffering should pray for mercy on his behalf.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 10_Pa: By praying for God’s compassion a person merits bringing together suitable marriage partners.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 0_Part I, 11_Pa: Anyone who judges others favorably merits celebrating the Festivals properly.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 1_Part II, 0_Pa: Not pleading for mercy for a fellow Jew causes a person to fall into captivity. He can make amends by providing food for some living creature.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 1_Part II, 1_Pa: A person suffers a toothache because he has been cruel to animals.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 1_Part II, 2_Pa: Compassion is a segulah for eliminating depression.
text.95_Compassion and Mercy, 1_Part II, 3_Pa: A person should avoid inflicting pain upon living creatures, as this will bring him harm.
text.96_Vision, 0_Paragraph: The eye can see only what it is allowed to see. Even if the thing is right in front of him, a person won’t notice it until he is granted permission from on high to see it.
text.96_Vision, 1_Paragraph: The waning of the moon and its eclipse are damaging to those with weak vision.
text.96_Vision, 2_Paragraph: Sanctifying the new moon is a segulah for curing weak vision.
text.96_Vision, 3_Paragraph: Reciting Tikkun Chatzot is also a segulah for curing weak vision.
text.96_Vision, 4_Paragraph: Pain of the eyes comes because a person has made some vow.
text.96_Vision, 5_Paragraph: Imposters cause those whom they deceive to suffer pain of the eyes.
text.96_Vision, 6_Paragraph: When an important person suffers pain of the eyes, he should know that either his son or his student has committed some sin.
text.96_Vision, 7_Paragraph: Anyone who closes his eyes so as not to look at evil saves himself from humiliation.
text.96_Vision, 8_Paragraph: A person who is afraid of immoral thoughts because of the beautiful women he sees while out in the street should recite the verse: “Behold, the mighty ones will cry outside” (Isaiah 32:7). This will save him from wandering eyes.
text.96_Vision, 9_Paragraph: Staring at an etrog is a cure for pain of the eyes.
text.96_Vision, 10_Paragraph: When those with clear vision look at the knives used by ritual slaughterers, they can see the vessels of the Holy Temple.
text.96_Vision, 11_Paragraph: Those with clear vision can tell who a person’s Torah teacher is merely by looking at him, provided they already know what his teacher looks like. When a student learns the Torah’s laws from his teacher, his face takes on a resemblance to the one teaching him. This is because Halakhah is the wisdom that makes a person’s face shine (cf. Ecclesiastes 8:1). By receiving the law, he receives a portion of his appearance, their resemblance increasing with each additional law the student receives.
text.96_Vision, 12_Paragraph: Pain of the eyes is sometimes harmful.
text.97_Healing, 0_Paragraph: Know! each and every herb has its own unique power to heal a specific illness. But this is only for a person who did not guard his faith and sexual purity, and did not keep from transgressing “Do not despise any man” (Avot 4:3). However, when one has complete faith and also maintains sexual purity and fulfills “Do not despise any man,” his cure is not dependent upon particular types of herbs. Rather, he is healed by all food and drink, as in “And He blessed your bread” (Exodus 23:25). He does not have to rely upon receiving particular herbs to be cured.
text.97_Healing, 1_Paragraph: By deeply studying the Torah’s mysteries one can bring barren women to bear children and also heal serious disease.
text.97_Healing, 2_Paragraph: Salty things aggravate leprosy, whereas fresh water cures it. This is alluded to in the verse (Job 36:27), “When He diminishes the drops of water”—namely, leprosy, which stems from blood overpowering the water in the body—then, “yazoku matar I’eido (the rain is distilled into His cloud).” The word yazoku, “distilled,” can alternatively be translated as “causing harm.”
text.97_Healing, 3_Paragraph: Staring at an etrog is a cure for pain of the eyes.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 0_Paragr: When a person performs a mitzvah joyously, it is a sign that his heart is wholly with God.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 2_Paragr: An increase in joy strengthens the intellect. Eating and drinking are excellent means for instilling the heart with joy and for distancing depression and worry.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 4_Paragr: The joy of a mitzvah strengthens a person.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 5_Paragr: When you see a wicked person suddenly smile, clearly it is because he has come up with some scheme for sinning.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 6_Paragr: By giving good advice, you will be rewarded with happiness.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 7_Paragr: Dancing or energetically moving your body about will awaken feelings of happiness inside you.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 8_Paragr: When you find your heart suddenly feeling happy, it is because some Tzaddik has just been born.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 9_Paragr: Fear of God brings to religious fervor.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 10_Parag: A person who is lowly in his own eyes will come to religious fervor.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 11_Parag: Intention of the heart brings joy.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 12_Parag: Whoever is accustomed to frivolity clearly is distant from God’s greatness.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 13_Parag: Music will make you happy and bring you to religious fervor.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 14_Parag: By making the Tzaddik happy, you will be able to serve God with joy.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 15_Parag: A person who spreads the Tzaddik’s fame merits happiness.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 17_Parag: Energetically moving your body about fosters religious fervor.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 18_Parag: Complete faith in God brings you to a level where you’ll desire to serve Him in body and soul.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 19_Parag: A person who is supremely humble merits religious fervor.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 21_Parag: A person’s joy is a sign that he is from a lineage blessed by God.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 22_Parag: Rain falls in the merit of bringing joy to a groom and bride.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 23_Parag: God protects a person when he rejoices in performing a mitzvah.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 24_Parag: By rejoicing on Simchat Torah, a person is rewarded with serving God out of love.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 25_Parag: When happiness comes to a person spontaneously, clearly kindness and help are on the way.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 0_Part I, 26_Parag: By being happy, a person’s fame spreads and he merits daat.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 1_Part II, 0_Parag: A person who is always happy is successful.
text.98_Joy and Happiness, 1_Part II, 1_Parag: Taking vows and pledging charity bring happiness.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person who gets drunk falls from his spiritual level.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Drinking wine will eventually lead one to taking bribes.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Drunkenness leads a person to disavow the truth and consent to falsehood.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: God loves a person who does not become intoxicated.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: Oil is an antidote for drunkenness.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: Seeing [a wine’s redness] increases its power to intoxicate.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Drunkenness brings one to immoral thoughts.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: A drunk is unable to mitigate harsh judgments.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: The Torah’s secrets are not revealed to a drunk.
text.99_Drunkenness, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: A mix of wine and frankincense will unhinge the mind.
text.99_Drunkenness, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: A person with a burning desire to work the land will come to one of three things: bloodshed, leprosy or drunkenness.
text.99_Drunkenness, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Drunkenness causes exile and leads to a wasteful emission of seed.
text.99_Drunkenness, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: When a person gets drunk, mishap becomes inevitable.
text.99_Drunkenness, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: A person who gets drunk forgets the directives of our teacher, Moses. This is because Moses is enclothed in the 248 organs of the human body and he instructs each and every organ to heed the mitzvot applicable to it. This is the reason Moses was called m’chokek (lawgiver), which has a numerical value of 248.
text.99_Drunkenness, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Drunkenness strips the mind from the chassadim (benevolences) that enclothe it, and covers it in powerful judgments, God forbid.
text.99_Drunkenness, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: A person with enemies should take an oath of abstinence from wine. This will give him mastery over them.
text.100_Public Officials, 0_Paragraph: When a person sells diluted wine, public officials will treat him unfairly.
text.100_Public Officials, 1_Paragraph: Not judging a fellow Jew favorably is tantamount to killing him. One who does so will be treated unjustly by public officials.
text.100_Public Officials, 2_Paragraph: Reciting the Hallel prayer and giving charity are a segulah for finding favor in the eyes of public officials.
text.100_Public Officials, 3_Paragraph: Eating bread baked by a non-Jew causes [those in charge] to prohibit using the forest to chop firewood.
text.100_Public Officials, 4_Paragraph: There are four things that cause a person’s possessions to be handed over to the government: [holding on to a paid IOU, charging usury for lending money, being in a position to object to some wrongdoing and not doing so, and pledging charity in public but not giving it].
text.101_Bribery, 0_Paragraph: A city in which the people take bribes will be set upon by invading armies.
text.101_Bribery, 1_Paragraph: Bribery causes a person’s prominence to disappear.
text.101_Bribery, 2_Paragraph: Bribery leads to an outbreak of fires.
text.102_Peace, 1_Paragraph: By pursuing peace, a person will be rewarded with honor in this world and life in the World to Come.
text.102_Peace, 2_Paragraph: Anything that is done to foster peace does not fall into the category of “distance yourself from falsehood.”
text.102_Peace, 3_Paragraph: Getting others to give charity increases the peace of the government.
text.102_Peace, 4_Paragraph: Pursuing peace brings to trust in God.
text.102_Peace, 6_Paragraph: The rebuilding of Jerusalem is dependent upon peace.
text.102_Peace, 8_Paragraph: Where there is reproof, there is peace.
text.102_Peace, 10_Paragraph: Murky waters are a sign that there is no peace.
text.102_Peace, 11_Paragraph: When there is no peace, people’s prayers are not accepted.
text.102_Peace, 12_Paragraph: Through peace, people merit a revelation of the prophet Elijah.
text.102_Peace, 13_Paragraph: When there is no peace, women do not give birth to sons.
text.102_Peace, 14_Paragraph: In a time when people are forced to flee their homes, a person who lends to others what they need will escape.
text.102_Peace, 15_Paragraph: The existence of peace indicates the existence of life.
text.102_Peace, 16_Paragraph: By pursuing peace a person saves his children from death and exile.
text.102_Peace, 18_Paragraph: When there is peace, there is no fear.
text.102_Peace, 19_Paragraph: When there is peace among the wicked, they have the best of everything.
text.102_Peace, 20_Paragraph: There are times when God uses the wicked as a means for fostering peace among the Jews.
text.102_Peace, 21_Paragraph: The existence of peace indicates the existence of prosperity.
text.102_Peace, 22_Paragraph: When the ministers on high quarrel, this same dispute immediately breaks out among the nations, and among Torah scholars.
text.103_Oaths, 0_Paragraph: A city in which people take oaths will be destroyed and demolished, God forbid.
text.103_Oaths, 1_Paragraph: Swearing falsely causes a person to fall from faith.
text.103_Oaths, 2_Paragraph: Studying the tractate Shavuot is a segulah for bringing rainfall.
text.103_Oaths, 3_Paragraph: Swearing falsely leads to immoral thoughts.
text.103_Oaths, 4_Paragraph: A person who is always taking oaths will be constantly bothered by evil thoughts.
text.103_Oaths, 5_Paragraph: Victory in battle cannot be achieved when an oath has been broken.
text.103_Oaths, 6_Paragraph: Whoever violates an oath clearly has no respect for God-fearing people.
text.103_Oaths, 7_Paragraph: Whereas a person must pay for having committed any of the sins mentioned in the Torah, punishment for violating an oath is exacted not only from him, but also from his family and the entire world—though he will be punished immediately.
text.103_Oaths, 8_Paragraph: Swearing falsely will destroy even those things that fire and water cannot.
text.103_Oaths, 9_Paragraph: The angel Gabriel has been put in charge of fire, to destroy as well as to save.
text.104_The Sabbath, 0_Paragraph: Studying Torah, giving tithes and observing Shabbat provide material benefits as well.
text.104_The Sabbath, 1_Paragraph: A person who is accustomed to cursing will lack clothing for Shabbat.
text.104_The Sabbath, 2_Paragraph: When a city’s inhabitants are careful not to walk beyond the Shabbat limit [from the city’s edge], meat will sell cheaply there.
text.104_The Sabbath, 3_Paragraph: By keeping Shabbat a person draws upon himself the light of Mashiach. Repentance also has this power.
text.104_The Sabbath, 4_Paragraph: A person who observes Shabbat is like a son who apologizes to his father and is given everything he wants. Such a person can also decree and the Holy One will give him what he wants. In addition, the reward he enjoys for his good deeds is drawn against his earnings, whereas the principal remains intact for him to enjoy in the World to Come.
text.105_Sleep, 0_Paragraph: The holier a person is, the less sleep he requires.
text.105_Sleep, 1_Paragraph: Too much sleep and slumber causes a person to be pushed away from the seat of holiness. His face changes and his Godly image is marred.
text.105_Sleep, 2_Paragraph: Reciting each of the fifteen psalms that begin “A song of ascent” (Psalms 120-134) is a segulah for eliminating sleepiness.
text.105_Sleep, 3_Paragraph: A person who finds that he cannot sleep should think about his belief in the resurrection of the dead.
text.106_A Ritual Slaughterer, 0_Paragraph: When ritual slaughterers are devout, [the meat they provide brings] people to have compassion for one another. The inverse is also the case, [as the meat of ritual slaughterers who are not devout causes people to lack compassion].
text.106_A Ritual Slaughterer, 1_Paragraph: When a ritual slaughterer fulfills the commandment to honor one’s father, God protects him from inadvertently distributing non-kosher meat. The inverse is also the case, [as transgressing this commandment leads to his inadvertently distributing non-kosher meat].
text.106_A Ritual Slaughterer, 2_Paragraph: Wicked slaughterers who distribute non-kosher meat bring about an increase of theft in the world.
text.106_A Ritual Slaughterer, 3_Paragraph: When those with clear vision look at the knives used by ritual slaughterers, they can see the vessels of the Holy Temple.
text.106_A Ritual Slaughterer, 4_Paragraph: A person who suddenly loses his ability to speak should have a knife fit for ritual slaughtering passed over his mouth.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: Fasting is beneficial for all things.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: A person who is devoid of good deeds cannot get others to separate from their evil ways.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: Fasting is harder [on the body] than the sword.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Repentance should ideally entail the very same thing [through which one sinned].
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: When a person thinks to himself, “By doing this and that I will achieve such and such,” his thought will not materialize.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: When a person is humble, it is as if he offered all the various sacrifices.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Anyone who confesses his sins has a share in the World to Come.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Whoever teaches Torah to the son of a fellow Jew, it is as if he created the child, created the words of Torah, and also created himself.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: Rabbi Papa fasted for having referred to a Torah scholar in a disrespectful manner.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: One should never even jokingly say, “I am going to commit such and such a sin,” because his words have the power to compel him to action.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: When a person cries at night, his voice is heard, and the stars and constellations cry with him.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: Punishment by flogging exempts those who would otherwise deserve death by excision.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: A person should consider his sins to be the cause of the world’s suffering.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Each article of clothing made for the Tzaddik carries its own special power of atonement.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: Once a man takes a wife, his sins are contained.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: When a Jew sees or hears about the suffering of a gentile, he should think of repenting.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 17_Paragraph: Whoever lives in the Land of Israel resides without sin.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: It is best to make it easier for sinners to repent.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: Given the possibility of performing one of two mitzvot, choose the one that involves overcoming your evil inclination.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: A person who causes the Tzaddik suffering should fast.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: A person who feels heartache is close to shedding tears.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: When a person brings others back to God in repentance, he is rewarded with a place in the heavenly Academy and the Holy One annuls a harsh decree for his sake.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: Dismay does more [for achieving repentance] than fasting.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: A person who sins and feels remorse is forgiven for all his sins.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: A person who conducts his business affairs honestly is forgiven for all his sins.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: A person’s original intentions help him carry out and conclude his actions in holiness. But if his original thoughts lacked holiness, he will encounter mishap after mishap to the very end.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: The table upon which guests are served atones for sins.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: There are times when a person who has begun to repent encounters suffering. This is because he had previously delayed returning to God.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: When one sighs, he becomes a new person.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: The love that people have for the Tzaddikim enables the Tzaddikim bring the masses back to God in repentance.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: In the merit of a person who brings the masses to repent, fear and controversy disappear from the world.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: By helping orphans, a person breaks the power of the nations. And by breaking them, wicked Jews return to God in repentance.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: A person who brings others to repent is saved from imprisonment.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: He is also honored by God
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: and achieves fame among the nations.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: When a person perpetually brings others to repent, the disturbing thoughts of the generation’s leaders are eliminated in his merit.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: One who brings wicked people back to God in repentance merits observing Shabbat.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: He will also not be harmed by a snake.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 41_Paragraph: By teaching the proper path to a wicked person’s son, you will have the power to nullify harsh decrees.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: Falsehood strengthens the hand of the wicked.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: Whoever repents wholeheartedly, the Holy One gives him a heart through which to know Him.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: Hearing the shofar blown by a devout individual breaks the evil inclination and awakens repentance throughout the world.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: A person who wants to repent should avoid being in debt.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 46_Paragraph: One who loves the Tzaddikim is capable of bringing people back to God in repentance.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: When a person confesses his sins, God loves him benevolently and removes His anger from him.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: The nations bring us to repent.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: Studying Torah atones for one’s sins.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: A person on a high spiritual level can attain perfection with but a minimum of effort.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 51_Paragraph: Whenever you are beset by suffering, scrutinize your actions.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 52_Paragraph: When a person wants to perform a good deed but encounters obstacles, God rewards him as if he had succeeded. However, when a person doesn’t do even what he is capable of, he is punished for it.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 53_Paragraph: By bringing merit to the masses a person becomes God’s partner in Creation.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 54_Paragraph: A mitzvah, no matter how great, which a person does and thereby brings merit only to himself cannot compare to even a minor mitzvah through which he brings merit to the masses.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 55_Paragraph: [Insufficient] income, enemies, sickness and great wealth are obstacles that deter a person from attaining perfection and his ultimate purpose.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 56_Paragraph: When you are the cause of some damage, it is a sign that your evil inclination has control over you.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 57_Paragraph: One who lures a fellow Jew from the proper path will be punished by fire.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 58_Paragraph: A segulah for anyone who cannot bring himself to cry is to sit at the spot where the flow of two rivers meet and become one.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 59_Paragraph: One who brings people back to God in repentance merits wisdom.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 60_Paragraph: A person’s laziness leads him to believe that the path of repentance is hidden from him.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 61_Paragraph: By disclosing his secret, it becomes difficult to carry it out.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 62_Paragraph: When a person is embarrassed by his sins, God deals charitably with him.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 63_Paragraph: When fasting is not accompanied by daat, it is not considered fasting.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 64_Paragraph: From the moment a person considers repenting, his prayers are accepted, even if he hasn’t yet returned to God.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 65_Paragraph: When you want to repent, ask the Tzaddik to bring you before God.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 66_Paragraph: Sins are atoned through lovingkindness and truth.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 67_Paragraph: Asking God for His love causes Him to cover over your transgressions.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 68_Paragraph: A person who confesses his sins is spared from having to sell what he inherited from his ancestors.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 69_Paragraph: When rebuking others for not rectifying the sins committed in their youth, include yourself among them and your words will be accepted.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 70_Paragraph: The best way to rectify the spiritual damage caused by one’s sins is through humility.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 71_Paragraph: A person must give himself rebuke each morning.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 72_Paragraph: Each day a person serves God during his youth is more valuable than many years of such devotion when he is old.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 73_Paragraph: During a person’s lifetime it is impossible for him to know if his repentance has been accepted.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 74_Paragraph: We often see that a person is beset by suffering when he begins serving God. The reason for this is that his initial motivation stemmed from his fear of justice.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 75_Paragraph: When a person begins serving God, the Holy One says to him: “I know that your desire and will is to serve Me, but what assurances do I have that tomorrow you won’t leave Me? If so, how can I draw you closer by virtue of your will alone? And how can I immediately reveal hidden things to you? Rather, you must do as follows: Start by showing your love for Me in the present situation, and perform My mitzvot even though you do not comprehend them. And serve Me with simplicity, without sophistication. After you’ve done this for some time, I will then believe you and reveal to you the reason and wisdom behind each and every thing. I will also draw you closer in all kinds of ways. For the extended time you served Me previously will guarantee that you won’t leave Me.”
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 76_Paragraph: The way a person can tell that he truly wants to serve God is that he has no desire for recognition.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 77_Paragraph: Whoever doesn’t know the way of God should humble himself.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 78_Paragraph: By crying out your prayers God will forgive you.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 79_Paragraph: Falsehood prevents a person from improving his ways.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 80_Paragraph: A person who cannot eliminate his evil inclination by “dragging it to the house of study” (see Sukkah 52b) should know that he hasn’t abandoned his evil ways.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 81_Paragraph: God prefers those mitzvot that are also pleasing to people over those that are exclusively between man and his Maker.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 82_Paragraph: It is better to perform a mitzvah to whatever degree possible than to not do it at all.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 83_Paragraph: Caring for the body precedes rectifying the soul.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 84_Paragraph: One who cries over and mourns the passing of a devout individual has all his sins forgiven.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 85_Paragraph: It is a mitzvah to warn people about any transgression. Should you fear that they will not listen to you, tell it to them in the name of a Tzaddik so that they will take heed.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 86_Paragraph: When anyone attentively recites the verses of Va’yechulu (Genesis 2:1-3) and prays with concentration, the ministering angels ask God to pardon his sins.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 87_Paragraph: When a person responds “Amen, may His name be great!” with all his might, even if he has in him a bit of idolatry, he will be forgiven.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 88_Paragraph: The following are spared the suffering of hell: the extremely poor, those who suffer intestinal disease, and those oppressed by creditors or the government.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 89_Paragraph: Perform even more mitzvot than you are capable of.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 90_Paragraph: A monetary loss exonerates a person from physical punishment.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 91_Paragraph: Thirst rectifies the sin of idle chatter.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 92_Paragraph: Repentance brings healing to the world.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 93_Paragraph: When a person’s repentance is motivated by a fear of God, his intentional sins are reckoned as errors. But when he is motivated by a love for God, they are transformed into merit.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 94_Paragraph: Repentance hastens the Final Redemption and lengthens a person’s days and years.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 95_Paragraph: When an individual repents, he is forgiven and so is the whole world.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 96_Paragraph: God is appeased by a person’s confession of his sins, which is like his having built an altar and brought a sacrifice.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 97_Paragraph: Whoever overlooks personal affronts has all his transgressions overlooked.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 98_Paragraph: Torah and acts of kindness atone for a person’s sins.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 99_Paragraph: Screams and cries for God’s mercy are most effective at night.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 100_Paragraph: A baal teshuvah should pray for rain and all his transgressions will be pardoned.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 101_Paragraph: Jews who fast are not answered by God unless there are some wicked people among them.
text.107_Repentance, 0_Part I, 102_Paragraph: The path that a person should choose is to love reproof and be steadfast in faith.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Like Yom Kippur, the day a person repents is beyond time and elevates all his days beyond time.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Repentance causes the spirit of Mashiach to blow against governmental decrees, nullifying them.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: Repentance also brings an end to a great heat wave.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Getting the young to return to God is easier than getting the old.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: [Wherever possible] a person should use money as a means of coercing the wicked into repentance.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: By returning to God in repentance you will be able to earn a living easily.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: The outstanding and sharp minds of the generation cause the fear of Heaven to shine. This fear sparks the merit of ancestors, which in turn awakens the world to return to God.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: God forms “paths in the sea” in order to suppress our sins and bring forth our righteous deeds.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: When the Tzaddik becomes wealthy, the wicked return to God in repentance.
text.107_Repentance, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: By keeping Shabbat a person draws upon himself the light of Mashiach. Repentance also has this power.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: When a person rebukes others, he should bind his rebuke to their root and then his words will be accepted.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: Do not rebuke an apostate —it won’t help.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: When a person rejects rebuke, his place of dwelling will be destroyed.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: One who rebukes people unwisely elicits exile and oppression at the hands of the nations, God forbid.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: A person should never exclude himself from the community.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: For the sin of withholding rebuke, God retracts the good that He already guaranteed.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: Where you know that people will not accept rebuke, leave them be.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: When a person refrains from rebuking others because he is afraid of them, God will eventually break him in their presence.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: When a person knows how to warn others but does not, he will be made to pay for their blood.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: By giving charity you will merit accepting ethical reproof.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: A person who rejects ethical reproof has a death sentence issued against him.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: By giving rebuke, you will rest in your grave free from the suffering of hell and merit the Garden of Eden.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: It is permissible to emphatically reject someone who won’t accept your rebuke.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: As long as there is rebuke in the world, contentment and good and blessing come to the world.
text.108_Rebuke, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: Rebuke mitigates harsh judgment and promotes loving-kindness.
text.108_Rebuke, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: When a person wants to inspire others to serve God, but lacks the requisite level of righteousness and has no ancestral merit, he should avoid being tested. He should particularly keep from arousing the jealousy of the wicked.
text.108_Rebuke, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Anyone who brings those distant from God to serve Him is given the power to bless others.
text.108_Rebuke, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: A person who rejects rebuke should know that he will have to borrow from others. This is alluded to through [a combination of the verses in Proverbs]: “Words of rebuke will not move a slave to correct his ways” (29:29), and “A borrower becomes a slave to the lender” (22:7).
text.108_Rebuke, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: One person will not be able to convince another of anything unless he first attaches his soul to that of the other person.
text.108_Rebuke, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: Going out to greet an important person summons forth the Ten Statements through which the world was created. Bringing Jews who are distant from God closer to Him does this as well.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 0_Paragraph: A person should hope and long for the good of the community, even though he himself stands to lose by it.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 1_Paragraph: When a person prays in a synagogue, it is as if he brought a pure meal-offering.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 2_Paragraph: God can be found in the synagogue.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 3_Paragraph: Flattery prevents a person’s prayers from being heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 4_Paragraph: When a person studies Torah despite difficult circumstances, his prayers are heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 5_Paragraph: When you pray for a fellow Jew even though you require the very same thing, God will answer your need first.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 6_Paragraph: A humble person’s prayers won’t be scorned.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 7_Paragraph: Don’t wait for trouble to begin before starting to pray.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 8_Paragraph: Whenever anyone devotes his strength to prayer below, in this world, his adversaries are unable to accuse him from on high.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 9_Paragraph: One should always entreat God for mercy that all things support his efforts [in prayer], that the ministering angels assist him in requesting mercy, and that he have no opposition from on high.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 10_Paragraph: Another person’s prayer is more effective than when one prays for oneself. Even a Tzaddik needs the prayer of others.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 11_Paragraph: One is permitted to pray for a slanderer’s death, or that he forgets his Torah studies, or that he will have no share in the World to Come, or any wise children.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 12_Paragraph: God fulfills the wishes of anyone who occupies himself with Torah study.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 13_Paragraph: It is good to cry out to God, whether before or after the decree has been issued.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 14_Paragraph: A person should not excessively pray for anything.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 15_Paragraph: When rain falls, it is a time of increasing salvation in the world and the advocates of merit are granted an audience before God.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 16_Paragraph: The prayers of an individual are not listened to unless he prays with an attentive heart. But the prayers of a congregation are heard even if they don’t all pray wholeheartedly.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 18_Paragraph: It is forbidden to burden God [by praying that] He alter the dictates of Nature.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 19_Paragraph: When a person overlooks personal affronts, his prayers are heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 20_Paragraph: One who praises God excessively will be uprooted from the world.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 21_Paragraph: A synagogue in which people calculate business accounts will in the end be the site of a deserted corpse [whose burial becomes the obligation of those who find it.]
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 22_Paragraph: Anything holy requires preparation and readiness.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 23_Paragraph: When asking for one’s needs, a person should not be so brazen as to ask for something great. However, with regard to Torah or the fear of God, a person should ask for all that he desires.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 24_Paragraph: It is a mitzvah to wear respectable clothing while praying.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 25_Paragraph: One should accustom himself to reciting the blessings in this world, so that he will be familiar with them in the World to Come.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 26_Paragraph: A person should ask for mercy that he not become impoverished.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 27_Paragraph: Through prayer a person has the ability to alter his fate.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 28_Paragraph: Speaking in a loud voice brings feeling and movement to all one’s limbs.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 29_Paragraph: One who thinks about entreating God thereby finds favor in His eyes.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 30_Paragraph: A person’s trust in God causes Him to listen to his prayers.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 31_Paragraph: Don’t pray in a place built by a contentious person.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 32_Paragraph: Before starting to pray, give charity and bind yourself to the Tzaddikim of the generation.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 33_Paragraph: The amount of bounty and spiritual strength a person receives depends upon the particular place in which he prays.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 34_Paragraph: While the community prays, it is a time of favor.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 35_Paragraph: One who has a synagogue [nearby] but doesn’t go there to pray, brings exile upon his descendants.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 36_Paragraph: Whatever you need, whether major or minor, pray for it.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 37_Paragraph: Come early and stay late in the synagogue so that you will live long.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 38_Paragraph: One who is capable of requesting mercy for a fellow Jew but does not is called a sinner.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 39_Paragraph: When a person answers nature’s call, washes his hands, dons tefilin, recites the Shema Yisrael and prays, it is tantamount to having built an altar and brought a sacrifice on it. It is also as if he immersed in a mikvah.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 40_Paragraph: Whoever avoids speaking of holy things in an unclean place will be rewarded with long life.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 41_Paragraph: Prayer is even greater than good deeds and sacrifices.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 42_Paragraph: Torah study, good deeds, prayer and engaging in worldly matters all require encouragement.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 43_Paragraph: Pray only in a place that has windows.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 44_Paragraph: Giving charity with both hands causes a person’s prayers to be heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 45_Paragraph: While praying, a person should spread out his hands as if he were receiving something.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 46_Paragraph: Stealing or embarrassing a fellow Jew prevents a person’s prayers from being heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 47_Paragraph: Shabbat and the new moon are especially beneficial times for elevating prayers.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 48_Paragraph: When a person is detained, it is a sign that his prayers are not being accepted.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 49_Paragraph: The yearning for God that a person expresses at night makes it easier for him to pray in the morning.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 50_Paragraph: A prayer accompanied by tears will be accepted.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 51_Paragraph: When asking God for something, mention the merit of your ancestors.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 52_Paragraph: When God punishes a wicked person whom He knows won’t repent and the Tzaddik prays excessively for that person, the Tzaddik too will be punished.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 53_Paragraph: When a person falls into a state of constricted consciousness while praying, it is a sign that his prayers will not be accepted.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 54_Paragraph: When you are not at peace with the world, your prayers will not be accepted.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 55_Paragraph: You should pray that there be peace in the city in which you live.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 56_Paragraph: Whoever prays joyously, God honors him and punishes those who oppress him.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 57_Paragraph: By reciting Tikkun Chatzot we remind God of the good that He guaranteed to the Jewish people.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 58_Paragraph: Whoever speaks favorably of the Jewish people arouses salvation, and this salvation will come about through him.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 59_Paragraph: Whoever doesn’t pray when Jews suffer is called a sinner.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 60_Paragraph: A person should pray for his children and for all his descendants.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 61_Paragraph: It is forbidden for a person to deny the good he has received, whether from a Jew or a gentile.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 62_Paragraph: When a person prays for the Jewish people, God pardons all his sins.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 63_Paragraph: When a sick person tearfully prays for himself, God will certainly heal him and accept his prayers.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 64_Paragraph: When you want to elevate your own prayers, pray for the Jewish people.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 65_Paragraph: The Holy One requests that a person pray to Him.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 66_Paragraph: Saving a poor person from someone stronger than him makes it easy for one to put energy into the letters of prayer.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 67_Paragraph: When a person trusts in God, his prayers are heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 68_Paragraph: A person who is humble is capable of crying out from the heart while praying.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 69_Paragraph: By being happy your prayers will reach the chamber of the King.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 70_Paragraph: One who gets no pleasure from his prayers should sing joyously while praying.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 71_Paragraph: Godlistens to theprayers of a person who prays energetically.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 72_Paragraph: The prayers of a person who has made some vow will not be accepted until he fulfills his vow.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 73_Paragraph: The prayers of a faithless person are not heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 74_Paragraph: When a person brings joy to the Tzaddik, his prayers are heard.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 75_Paragraph: Before praying a person should bind his spirit to the Creator. On account of this attachment the words will emerge from his mouth of their own accord.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 76_Paragraph: In reward for remaining silent when disgraced God will answer your requests.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 77_Paragraph: Whoever prays for a fellow Jew, God doubles his prosperity.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 79_Paragraph: One who mourns the Temple’s destruction merits praying with his heart and body.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 80_Paragraph: A joyous prayer is both pleasing and sweet to God.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 81_Paragraph: When a person is humble, God will fulfill his prayers even if he prays only in thought.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 82_Paragraph: There are times when God won’t accept the Tzaddik’s prayers on behalf of another person. This is because He knows that this person will eventually draw the Tzaddik into his own sinful ways.
text.109_Prayer, 0_Part I, 83_Paragraph: Thoughts follow only the one who serves God. (This can be explained as follows: When a person serves God, he attracts and is trailed by confusing thoughts, more so than other people.)
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 0_Paragraph: Not pleading for mercy for a fellow Jew causes a person to fall into captivity. He can make amends by providing food for some living creature.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 1_Paragraph: Prayer is most effective when one faces heavenward.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 2_Paragraph: A person who requests compassion for his generation is rewarded with a revelation of the Divine Presence.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 3_Paragraph: Reciting the hymns and praises of God draws His Divine Presence below.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 4_Paragraph: The prayer leader’s supplication contains an aspect of warfare.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 5_Paragraph: When one fulfills “Your neighbor’s money should be as precious to you as your own” (Avot 2:12), he merits praying with an attentive heart.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 6_Paragraph: Reciting Psalms is a segulah for bringing rain. [We learn this from the Hebrew word for Psalms], TeHiLiM, which is an acronym for “Limtar Hashamayim Tishteh Mayim ([the Land of Israel] drinks water from the rain of heaven)” (Deuteronomy 11:11).
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 7_Paragraph: When a person feels the suffering of other Jews and prays for them, even if he directs his words against Heaven, he will not be punished.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 8_Paragraph: Certain prayers are accepted on high only after sufficient money, equivalent to the number of letters in the relevant prayer, is given to charity. For example, when a person prays, “Give me children,” he must contribute the sum equal to the letters of these very words.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 9_Paragraph: Through prayer a person can exchange the marriage partner decreed for him in heaven.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 10_Paragraph: When the masses pray together, their prayers are more effective than when they pray in separate places.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 11_Paragraph: There are times when salvation will come only when many people pray for it; an individual’s prayers are not enough.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 12_Paragraph: A person with enemies finds it difficult to concentrate while praying.
text.109_Prayer, 1_Part II, 13_Paragraph: One should be careful to utter God’s Name in holiness and purity. That is, he should sanctify his speech to such a degree that it becomes an aspect of the spirit of prophecy. This spirit will go out and defeat those who put their trust in emptiness and vanity. Thus the verse “B’sheim YHVH Eloheinu Nazkir (we will utter the Name of God, our Lord)” (Psalms 20:8) [the first letters of which spell NAVY, the Hebrew word for prophet,] is followed by “they were subdued and defeated” (ibid. 20:9; see Glossary, “B”).
